While the correspondence was thus going on between the Government and the owners’ solicitors with reference to the quarantine, and while the passengers on board the two vessels were being subjected to grave inconvenience and hardship, an agitation was being got up in Durban with a view to prevent the landing of the quarantined passengers.
('2', 32, 1, 5, 74822) The following notice appeared in The Natal Advertiser, for the first time on the 30th December, above the signature of “Harry Sparks, chairman of preliminary meeting”, one of Her Majesty’s commissioned officers:
('2', 32, 2, 6, 75034) Wanted every man in Durban to attend a meeting to be held in the large room at the Victoria Cafe, on Monday the 4th January at 8 o’clock for the purpose of arranging a demonstration to proceed to the Point and protest against the landing of Asiatics.
('2', 32, 2, 7, 75285) This meeting was ultimately held in the town hall of Durban.
('2', 32, 2, 8, 75346) Inflammatory speeches were made, and some commissioned officers, besides Captain Sparks, also took part in the animated proceedings.
('2', 32, 2, 9, 75479) The meeting is said to have been attended by about 2,000 persons, mostly of the artisan class.
('2', 32, 2, 10, 75574) The following resolutions were passed at the meeting:
('2', 32, 3, 11, 75628) That this meeting is strongly of opinion that the time has come to prevent the landing of any more free Indians or Asiatics in this Colony, and now calls upon the Government to take steps to have returned to India, at the Colony’s expense, the Asiatics at present on board the Naderi and Courland, and to prevent any other free Indians or Asiatics being landed in Durban.
('2', 32, 4, 12, 76000) Every man at this meeting agrees and binds himself, with a view to assisting the Government to carry out the foregoing resolution, to do all his country may require of him, and with that view, will, if necessary, attend at the Point any time when required.
('2', 32, 5, 13, 76257) The following are extracts from the speech of Dr. MacKenzie, the mover of the second resolution, and one of those who, as stated above, were called by Mr. Escombe to determine the period of quarantine:
('2', 33, 0, 1, 76459) 34 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 33, 1, 2, 76500) Mr. Gandhi, (prolonged hissing and hooting) that gentleman came to Natal and settled in the borough of Durban.
('2', 33, 1, 3, 76611) He was received here freely and openly; all the privileges and advantages which the Colony could afford him were at his disposal.
('2', 33, 1, 4, 76741) No contracting or circumscribing influence was brought to play upon him any more than on the audience or himself (the speaker), and he had all the privileges of their hospitality.
('2', 33, 1, 5, 76921) In return, Mr. Gandhi had accused the Colonists of Natal of having dealt unfairly with Indians, and of having abused and robbed and swindled them.
('2', 33, 1, 6, 77068) (A voice, ‘You can’t swindle a coolie.’) He (the doctor) quite agreed with that.
('2', 33, 1, 7, 77149) Mr. Gandhi had returned to India and dragged them in the gutters, and painted them as black and filthy as his own skin.
('2', 33, 1, 8, 77269) (Applause.) And this was what they might call, in Indian parlance, an honourable and manly return for the privileges which Natal had allowed him .
('2', 33, 1, 9, 77416) It was the intention of these facile and delicate creatures to make themselves proprietors of the only thing that the ruler of this country had withheld from them—the franchise.
('2', 33, 1, 10, 77594) It was their intention to put themselves in Parliament and legislate for the Europeans; to take over the household management, and put the Europeans in the kitchen .
('2', 33, 1, 11, 77760) Their country had decided that they had enough Asiatics and Indians here, and they were going to treat them fairly and well, provided they behaved themselves; but, if they were going to associate themselves with such men as Gandhi, and abuse their hospitality, and act in the way he had done, they might expect the same kind of treatment that was to be meted out to him.
('2', 33, 1, 12, 78131) (Applause.) However great a misfortune it might be for those people, he could not get over the distinction between black and white.
('2', 33, 1, 13, 78263) — The Natal Advertiser, 5th January.
('2', 33, 2, 14, 78300) Comment is superfluous.
('2', 33, 2, 15, 78324) That Mr. Gandhi has done nothing to justify the remarks about him will have been seen from what has preceded.
('2', 33, 2, 16, 78434) That the Indians want legislative powers and that they want to put the Europeans in the kitchen, are but the products of the gallant doctor’s fertile imagination.
('2', 33, 2, 17, 78597) These and such utterances would not have been noticed here but for the hold they had on the popular mind.
('2', 33, 2, 18, 78703) The Government wired the following reply to Capt.
('2', 33, 2, 19, 78753) Sparks’ telegraphic communication giving the text of the above resolutions:
('2', 33, 3, 20, 78829) In reply, I am to state that the Government has at present no power, apart from such as may be conferred by the Quarantine Laws, to prevent the landing in the Colony of any class of Her Majesty’s subjects.
('2', 33, 3, 21, 79035) I am to state, however, that the closest attention has been, is being, and will be given to this question, the extreme importance of which the Government most completely recognizes.
('2', 33, 3, 22, 79217) Government is in full sympathy with the consensus of
('2', 34, 0, 1, 79270) VOL. 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 35
('2', 34, 1, 2, 79312) public opinion in this Colony as regards the desirability of preventing the overrunning of the Colony by Asiatics.
('2', 34, 1, 3, 79427) Government is carefully discussing and considering this question with a view to future legislation; but I am to point out that its action will be thwarted rather than helped by any action or demonstration of the character indicated in the second resolution.
('2', 34, 2, 4, 79685) Thus it would appear that the quarantine was meant more to harass the passengers into returning to India than to protect the Colony against the introduction of the bubonic plague.
('2', 34, 2, 5, 79865) The chairman then telegraphed the Government as follows:
('2', 34, 3, 6, 79922) I am instructed by the Committee to thank you for wire, and have now to ask Government to convey to the Asiatics on board the Naderi and Courland the strong popular feeling against their landing, and request them to return to India at the Colony’s expense.
('2', 34, 4, 7, 80179) Another meeting, convened by Captain Sparks, was held on the 7th January, again in the Town Hall, when the following resolutions were passed:
('2', 34, 5, 8, 80321) That this meeting requests the Government to call a special session of Parliament to take steps to temporarily stop the importation of free Indians, pending the passing of law giving Government these powers; (and) that we proceed by demonstration to the Point on the arrival of the Indians, but each man binds himself to conform to the orders of the leaders.
('2', 34, 6, 9, 80680) The speeches at the meeting clearly show that the Government were in full sympathy with its objects, that they would not oppose the mutinous tendency of the meeting, that the imposition of quarantine was nothing but a means to prevent, if possible, the landing of the passengers, and that a special session was to be called in order to pass a Bill indefinitely extending the quarantine.

('2', 37, 2, 7, 87776) Your Memorialists may here remark that the town, during the first week in January, was in a perfect state of excitement.
('2', 37, 2, 8, 87897) It was a time of terror and anxiety for the Indian residents, and collision between the two communities was to be feared at any moment.
('2', 37, 2, 9, 88033) On the 8th January, 1897, the owners and agents of the ships sent a petition to the Government drawing their attention to the state of public feeling that existed in Durban against the landing of Indians, and asking for “the protection of the Government for passengers and property against the lawless acts of any persons whoever they may be,” and signifying their readiness “to co operate with the Government in taking all the necessary steps for the landing of passengers quietly and unknown to the public in order to render unnecessary any act on the part of the Government which might tend to intensify the excitement” which then existed.
('2', 37, 2, 10, 88676) Q.) A letter was sent on the 9th January, further drawing the attention of the Government to the circulation of the document hereinbefore referred to for the forcible resistance against the landing of the passengers, as also to the fact that the railwaymen, being employees of the Government, were to take part in the Demonstration, and praying for assurance of the Government that “Government servants will be prohibited from taking any part in the Demonstration”.
('2', 37, 2, 11, 89142) R.) On the 11th January, the Principal Under Secretary thus wrote in reply:
('2', 37, 3, 12, 89218) Your proposals for the landing of the passengers quietly and unknown to the public is impossible.
('2', 37, 3, 13, 89316) The Government understand that you have requested the Port Captain not to bring the vessel inside without special instructions.
('2', 37, 3, 14, 89444) This action on your part, and your letters now under reply, show that you are aware of the intense feeling throughout the Colony against the landing of the Indians, and they certainly should be informed of the existence and strength of that feeling.
('2', 37, 3, 15, 89694) S.) Your Memorialists here cannot help regretting that the
('2', 38, 0, 1, 89753) VOL. 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 39
('2', 38, 1, 2, 89795) Government should have made the concluding remarks in that letter.
('2', 38, 1, 3, 89862) Instead of giving an assurance of protection when it is asked, the Government advise the owners, in so many words, to induce the passengers to return.
('2', 38, 1, 4, 90013) This letter, more than anything else, in your Memorialists’ humble opinion, shows that the Government indirectly countenanced the agitation, and betrayed their weakness, where a strong expression of opinion might have stifled it and produced a healthy confidence in their just intentions in the minds of the Indian community, apart from their policy with regard to the unrestricted immigration of Her Majesty’s Indian subjects.
('2', 38, 1, 5, 90441) On the 10th January, the Honourable Mr. Harry Escombe being in Durban, Mr. Laughton, of the firm of Messrs Goodricke, Laughton & Cooke, the owners’ solicitors, took the opportunity to interview him, and wrote a letter to the honourable gentleman, embodying the substance of their conference.
('2', 38, 1, 6, 90733) T.) From that letter it would appear that Mr. Escombe repudiated the statement attributed to him by Mr. Wylie and referred to above.
('2', 38, 1, 7, 90866) It would also appear that the following propositions were recognized by the Government:
('2', 38, 2, 8, 90954) That upon the requirements of the quarantine being carried out, pratique must be granted to the steamers Courland and Naderi; that upon pratique being granted, the steamers were entitled to discharge their passengers and cargo at the wharf, either by the steamers being brought inside, or by means of tugs and lighters; that the Government is responsible for the protection of passengers and cargo from the violence of rioters.
('2', 38, 3, 9, 91382) The reply to the letter dated the 11th January (App.
('2', 38, 3, 10, 91435) U) said that the interview referred to therein was, it was understood, to be regarded as a private meeting, and did not accept as correct Mr. Laughton’s record of what was said by the Honourable Mr. Escombe and Mr. Laughton.
('2', 38, 3, 11, 91660) On the 12th January, Messrs Goodricke, Laughton and Cooke wrote in reply, explaining how the interview came to be regarded as not private by Mr. Laughton, and in order to avoid misunderstanding, applied for the correction of the alleged inaccuracies committed by Mr. Laughton in recording the interview.

('2', 38, 3, 14, 92158) S.) Their letter expressed surprise at there being no reference in that communication to the various points brought to the notice of the
('2', 39, 0, 1, 92295) 40 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 39, 1, 2, 92336) Government.
('2', 39, 1, 3, 92348) It contained the following paragraph:
('2', 39, 2, 4, 92386) The steamers have now been at the outer anchorage for 24 days, at a cost of £150 per diem to us; and this being so, we trust you will see the reasonableness of your giving us a full answer by noon tomorrow.
('2', 39, 2, 5, 92593) And we think it right to inform you that failing a definite reply giving us an assurance that we shall be paid £150 per diem from Sunday last, and that you are taking steps to suppress the rioters so as to enable us to disembark the steamers, preparations will be at once commenced to steam into the harbour, relying on the protection which, we respectfully submit, Government is bound to give us.
('2', 39, 3, 6, 92991) Mr. Escombe wrote as follows in reply, from the Point, at 10.45 a.m., on the 13th:
('2', 39, 4, 7, 93074) The Port Captain has instructed that the steamers shall be ready to cross the bar inwards at 12 o’clock today.
('2', 39, 4, 8, 93185) The Government needs no reminder of its responsibility for the maintenance of order.
('2', 39, 5, 9, 93270) This was the first assurance that the owners received from the Government with regard to the safety of the passengers, and as will appear hereinafter, after all the resources, including threats of violence to induce the passengers to return to India, had been exhausted.

('2', 39, 5, 13, 93761) But the pratique was not granted until after the noon of the 11th January, 1897. On the same day a letter was received by the master of the Courland, dated the 8th January, 1897, and signed “Harry Sparks, Chairman of Committee”, which reads:
('2', 39, 6, 14, 94003) Neither you nor your passengers may be aware that the feeling in the Colony against the inflow of Asiatics has been running very high lately, and has culminated on the arrival of your ship and the Naderi.

('2', 46, 2, 5, 111528) Your Memorialists would beg to draw your attention to the distinction between the causes that led up to the Demonstration and that have been alluded to hereinbefore, and the immediate causes described above.
('2', 46, 2, 6, 111736) It is quite possible that the Demonstration may not have taken place but for the above mentioned statements which appeared in the Press.
('2', 46, 2, 7, 111873) They were, however, absolutely without ground.
('2', 46, 2, 8, 111920) Even if they were true, your Memorialists submit, the action of the Demonstration Committee could not be justified.
('2', 46, 2, 9, 112036) As it was, the members of the Committee did an injustice to the European, native, and the Indian communities in the Colony as well as to themselves and Mr. Gandhi: to the European community, because their action created a lawless spirit amongst them; to the native, because the presence of that element at the Point, no matter by whom brought about, tended to excite their passions and warlike spirit, over which, when once aroused, they have little control; to the Indian, because they were subjected to a severe trial, and the bitterness of feeling against them was considerably accentuated owing to the action of the Committee; to themselves, because they took upon themselves the tremendous responsibility of defying law and order, without ascertaining the truth of their statements; and to Mr. Gandhi, because owing to gross misrepresentations, no doubt made unwittingly, about him and his doings, he very nearly lost his life.
('2', 46, 2, 10, 112969) Instead of there being 800 passengers for Natal, there were only 600 in all, of whom about 200 were for Natal, the rest being for Delagoa Bay, Mauritius, and the Transvaal; and of these 200, over 100 were old residents of Natal who had gone to India and returned, and less than 100 were newcomers, including about 40 ladies, being wives and relations of the Indian residents of Natal; and the remaining 60 were either storekeepers, their assistants, or hawkers.

('2', 49, 1, 3, 119031) It is surely a fair inference that these continued arrivals of fresh batches of Indians in Natal are the result of the knowledge having reached them that their predecessors had fared well in their new conditions.
('2', 49, 1, 4, 119244) Now, it may be asked, how could the earlier contingents of Indians have prospered in Natal had they not been, one way or another, assisted by the European settlers?
('2', 49, 1, 5, 119409) And it may be taken for granted that the Europeans could not thus have assisted the Indian immigrants to prosper had they not, at the same time, been thereby helping on their own prosperity as well.
('2', 49, 1, 6, 119608) The Indians who come to Natal are of two classes, the indentured and the free.
('2', 49, 1, 7, 119687) Both these classes have found, despite their superficial antagonism, that the Europeans have been ready to employ or “support” them, and have thereby not merely made them satisfied with their own amelioration but have thus encouraged further arrivals.
('2', 49, 1, 8, 119939) The indentured Indians are, for the most part, utilized by the European agriculturists; the free Indians who desire to engage in trade are supported by the European merchants, while the remainder are, in one way or another, encouraged to come and to remain in the country for domestic purposes.
('2', 49, 1, 9, 120234) That the indentured Indian has proved to be an absolute necessity in Natal, owing to the indifferent and unreliable labour procurable from the Kaffir population, is evidenced by the fact that they are employed in thousands as farm and domestic servants, and that further indentures for hundreds more go to India by almost every mail.
('2', 49, 1, 10, 120568) “But,” it is often said, “the objection is not to the indentured, but to the free Indian.” In the first place, however, the indentured coolie is destined ultimately to become free.
('2', 49, 1, 11, 120749) So that, while importing them under indentures, the people of Natal are thus practically ensuring large and continuous contributions to the free Indian population.
('2', 49, 1, 12, 120913) An attempt has been made, it is true, to compel the return of indentured Indians at the conclusion of their contract, but the law could not be made compulsory.
('2', 49, 1, 13, 121073) Then, as regards the free Indians, these are engaged either in commerce, agriculture, or domestic service.
('2', 49, 1, 14, 121180) In none of these directions could they possibly succeed except through the direct help of the Europeans.
('2', 49, 1, 15, 121285) As regards the Indian trader, he receives his initial “support” from the European merchants.
('2', 49, 1, 16, 121378) It would probably be difficult to find a single commercial house of any standing in Durban which has not scores of Indians as “clients”.
('2', 49, 1, 17, 121515) The coolie “farmer” is encouraged and maintained by the Europeans in two ways: he has to rent or buy his land from the original European possessor, and his products are, for the most part, consumed in the European households.
('2', 49, 1, 18, 121741) If it were not for the coolie market gardeners and hawkers, the people of Durban (and other parts of the Colony) would find themselves very badly off for many kitchen requisites.
('2', 49, 1, 19, 121920) Then, with respect to the Indian domestic servants, the only remark necessary is that, as a
('2', 50, 0, 1, 122012) VOL. 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 51
('2', 50, 1, 2, 122054) body, they have proved themselves to be much superior, in capacity, reliability and obedience, to the average Kaffir.
('2', 50, 1, 3, 122172) It would probably be found, on close examination, that several of those who have associated themselves with the recent agitation have Indians in their employ.
('2', 50, 1, 4, 122331) Indians are also largely engaged in Government service, while the Government also provides them with the means of education, and consequently of advancement.
('2', 50, 1, 5, 122489) Seeing, then, that the Europeans are primarily responsible for the benefits that have accrued to those Indians already in the Colony, it has the appearance of unreasonableness on their part to suddenly oppose the landing of any more.
('2', 50, 1, 6, 122723) But, in addition to all this, there is the Imperial aspect of the question.
('2', 50, 1, 7, 122799) This is the most formidable of all.
('2', 50, 1, 8, 122835) So long as Natal remains a part of the British Empire (a circumstance which depends on Britain and not Natal), so long will the Imperial Government insist that the laws of the Colony shall not be repugnant to the general welfare and development of the Empire.
('2', 50, 1, 9, 123095) India is part of the Empire; and the Imperial and Indian Governments are imbued with a determination to prove to the civilized world that the retention of India by Britain is for the benefit of the Indians.
('2', 50, 1, 10, 123302) This, however, would not be the case if something could not be done to relieve the congested districts of India of their surplus population.
('2', 50, 1, 11, 123443) This can only be effected by encouraging the Indians in those parts to emigrate.
('2', 50, 1, 12, 123524) Britain has not the power nor the wish to force the surplus Indian population upon any country.
('2', 50, 1, 13, 123620) But she certainly has the power to decline to allow any portion of the British Empire, where her Indian subjects are sought for by one section of the community, to shut its gates against them at the behest of another section of the same community.
('2', 50, 1, 14, 123868) And so far as Natal is concerned, judging from the number of requisitions that go to India for further supplies of Indian labour, were anything to take place by which that supply was stopped, Natal and not India would be the greater sufferer.—Star, Friday, 8th January, 1897.

It would perhaps assist Her Majesty’s Government in coming to a conclusion if certain facts were placed before them pertaining to the matter.
('2', 65, 1, 5, 166838) The demand for restriction of free immigration of Indians has been based on the supposition that, of late, there has been a very large influx of Indians into the Colony, irrespective of any organization.
('2', 65, 1, 6, 167042) Your Memorialists, however, have no hesitation in saying that the alarm is not justified by facts.
('2', 65, 1, 7, 167141) It is not correct to say that more Indians have come to the Colony during the last year than during the last but one.
('2', 65, 1, 8, 167259) Formerly, they came by the German boats as well as by those of the B.I.S.N. Co.
('2', 65, 1, 9, 167339) Since the latter boats transshipped their passengers in other boats at Delagoa Bay, the Indians came in small batches and were, naturally, not much noticed.
('2', 65, 1, 10, 167496) Two Indian merchants bought steamers last year and established a fairly regular and direct service between Bombay and Natal.
('2', 65, 1, 11, 167621) Most of the Indians wishing to come to South Africa availed themselves of this service, and thus, instead of being divided into small batches, they came all at once, and thus drew attention.
('2', 65, 1, 12, 167812) Moreover, no one seemed to take any notice of those that returned to India.
('2', 65, 1, 13, 167888) From the following list it will be clear that there has not been a material addition to the free Indian population; certainly not in any way large enough to justify the alarm.
('2', 65, 1, 14, 168064) It is also worthy of note that the European immigration is and has almost always been in excess of the free Indian immigration.
('2', 65, 2, 15, 168192) A return signed by Mr. G. O. Rutherford, Acting Protector of Immigrants, shows that from August last to January seven steamship firms deported 1,298 free Indians from the Colony; the same companies introduced 1,964 Indians in the same time, most of the immigrants coming from Bombay.—The Natal Mercury, 17th March, 1897. ('2', 66, 1, 4, 169066) As to the competition between the Indian and European traders, it has been well said, in some of the extracts quoted above, that, if there is any competition, it is rendered possible by the large support given by the European merchants.
('2', 66, 1, 5, 169303) But the very fact that the European merchants are willing, nay anxious, to support Indian traders, shows that they do not compete with them to any appreciable extent.
('2', 66, 1, 6, 169470) They, really speaking, act as middlemen and begin where the Europeans leave.
('2', 66, 1, 7, 169547) The Commissioners, who were specially appointed to report upon Indian matters nearly 10 years ago, thus report as to the Indian traders:
('2', 66, 2, 8, 169684) We are convinced that much of the irritation existing in the minds of European Colonists against the whole Indian population of the Colony has been excited by the undoubted ability of these Arab traders to compete with European merchants, and specially with those who have chiefly directed their attention to the supply of articles, notably rice, largely consumed by the Indian immigrant population.
('2', 66, 3, 9, 170084) We are of opinion that these Arab traders have been drawn to Natal by the presence therein of those Indians who have been introduced under the immigration laws.

('2', 66, 4, 16, 171025) (The italics are your Memorialists.) .

('2', 66, 4, 18, 171178) They are thrifty by nature and submissive to the law.
('2', 66, 4, 19, 171232) Mr. Saunders, one of the Commissioners, says in his additional report:
('2', 66, 5, 20, 171303) So far as concerns free Indian traders, their competition and the consequent lowering of the price of articles of consumption by which the
('2', 67, 0, 1, 171442) 68 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 67, 1, 2, 171483) public benefits (and yet, strange to say, of which it complains), it is clearly shown that these Indian shops have been and are most exclusively supported by the larger firms of white merchants who thus, practically employ these men to dispose of their goods.
('2', 67, 2, 3, 171743) Stop Indian immigration if you will, if there are not enough unoccupied houses now, empty more by clearing out Arabs or Indians, who add to the productive and consuming power of a less than half peopled country, but let us trace results in this one branch of the enquiry taking it as an example of others, trace out how untenanted houses depreciate the value of property and securities, how after this must result stagnation in the building trade, and those other trades and stores for supplies dependent on it.
('2', 67, 2, 4, 172255) Follow out how this leads to a reduced demand for white mechanics, and with the reduction in spending power of so many, how fall of revenue is to be expected next, need of retrenchment, or taxation, or both.
('2', 67, 2, 5, 172463) Let this result and others far too numerous to be calculated on in detail be faced, and if blind race sentimentalism or jealousy is to prevail, so be it.
('2', 67, 2, 6, 172617) At a meeting lately held in Stanger, one of the speakers (Mr. Clayton) said:
('2', 67, 3, 7, 172694) Not only the coolie labourer, he said, but the Arab storekeeper had been of benefit to the Colony.
('2', 67, 3, 8, 172793) He knew it was an unpopular view to take, but he had looked at the question from every point of view.
('2', 67, 3, 9, 172895) What did they find?
('2', 67, 3, 10, 172915) The erven round the Market Square were bringing in a good percentage through the presence of Arab storekeepers.
('2', 67, 3, 11, 173027) The owners of land had been benefited by the coolies taking up land that would never be taken up by anybody else.
('2', 67, 3, 12, 173141) At the auction sale, the other day, erven abutting on the Market Square fetched a price that would have been out of the question years ago.
('2', 67, 3, 13, 173281) The Indians had created a trade—a trade that would never have been brought here by the old system of storekeeping.
('2', 67, 3, 14, 173396) He was quite willing to admit that here and there an European storekeeper had been ruined by the Indians, but their presence here was better than the old days when a few storekeepers had the monopoly.
('2', 67, 3, 15, 173597) Wherever they met with an Arab, they always found him amenable to law.
('2', 67, 3, 16, 173668) They had heard it said that the Colonists should not give away their birthright— that the Indians should not be allowed to enter upon the possession of their lands.
('2', 67, 3, 17, 173833) He was pretty confident that his children, rather than have to work any land he might be able to leave them, would prefer to let it to Indians at reasonable rents.
('2', 67, 3, 18, 173997) He did not think that that meeting was justified in coming to a wholesale condemnatory resolution of the Asiatics.
('2', 67, 3, 19, 174112) A regular correspondent of The Natal Mercury thus writes:
('2', 68, 0, 1, 174170) VOL. 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 69
('2', 68, 1, 2, 174212) We brought the coolies here as a necessity, and, undoubtedly they have been a great help towards the progress of Natal.
('2', 68, 2, 3, 174332) Twenty five years ago, in the towns and townships, fruit, vegetables, and fish could hardly be bought.
('2', 68, 2, 4, 174435) A cauliflower sold for half a crown.
('2', 68, 2, 5, 174472) Why did not farmers go in for market gardening?
('2', 68, 2, 6, 174520) There may have been some laziness, but on the other hand, to grow wholesale was useless.
('2', 68, 2, 7, 174609) I have known the case of cart loads of fruit, etc., sent a long way, but in good condition to the city, unsaleable.
('2', 68, 2, 8, 174725) The party who would give half a crown for a stray cauliflower would naturally demur to give a shilling for one, when he saw a wagon load of them.
('2', 68, 2, 9, 174871) Here we needed an industrious class of hawkers who could live cheaply and find pleasure and profit in supplying these wants, and we got it in the time expired indentured coolie.
('2', 68, 2, 10, 175049) And for waiters and cooks, public or private, the coolie has supplied the want, for in these matters the mass of our natives are awkward, and when not, as soon as carefully taught, are off to their kraals.
('2', 68, 3, 11, 175255) The free coolie labourer, if an artisan, will work longer hours and take a lower wage cheerfully than the European mechanic, and the coolie trader will sell a cotton blanket three half pence cheaper than the white storekeeper.
('2', 68, 3, 12, 175482) That is all.
('2', 68, 4, 13, 175495) Surely the great economic cry of supply and demand, your patriotic league of British subjects, your glorious cry of Free Trade, which John Bull pays through the nose for to show his faith in, all forbid this outcry.
('2', 68, 5, 14, 175711) Australia has forbidden coloured immigration.
('2', 68, 5, 15, 175757) The strikes and band smashes do not make that a grand example.
('2', 68, 5, 16, 175820) Coolies wear lighter clothes and slippers than Europeans; anyway, that is an advance on our location native, and, many years ago, boots were rarely seen on white men or women on farms, or children even among the uppish classes of the city, except when they went to the park or meeting.
('2', 68, 5, 17, 176106) Their feet seemed none the worse, though bad for shoemakers.
('2', 68, 5, 18, 176167) Coolies don’t eat meat or drink beer, etc.
('2', 68, 5, 19, 176210) Again, I dare say, bad for butchers and licenced victuallers.
('2', 68, 5, 20, 176272) Depend upon it, all these things will find their level, but to force by Act of Parliament (beyond what decency and sobriety call for the common weal) what people are to eat and drink and wear is tyranny, not beneficent legislation.
('2', 68, 5, 21, 176504) Crowds of white immigrants are kept out.
('2', 68, 5, 22, 176545) Are they?
('2', 68, 5, 23, 176555) With our native population, unless you can shunt the whole lot, white men will not work for a mere living wage in this Colony.
('2', 68, 5, 24, 176682) They would rather be loafers.
('2', 68, 6, 25, 176712) We cannot get out of it.
('2', 68, 6, 26, 176737) Ours is a black Colony, and much as I like our natives in their proper place, and the coolies [sic], too, who is more willing to keep it [sic] in his, the While man’s role is and must be to be boss.
('2', 68, 6, 27, 176936) Stop at that, I do not want to talk of how poor farmers cannot afford to pay their fashionable friends, the town artisans, their price, and are very glad to put up with even indifferent work by an off coloured mechanic; but I would appeal to
('2', 69, 0, 1, 177178) 70 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 69, 1, 2, 177219) the skilled workmen to be content to regulate their own tariffs, and not be afraid of indifferent opposition—a good man is always worth his full value— but avoid, because they are numerically strong in the towns, a class agitation, a race quarrel.
('2', 69, 1, 3, 177467) It is the same with the good tradesmen, and though the owners of country stores may have to cut their prices finer, they won’t be ruined.
('2', 69, 1, 4, 177605) Four hundred gallons of treacle for cash per week isn’t bad.
('2', 69, 1, 5, 177666) Talk of the federation of the Empire, and we are tabooing our fellow subjects of India, whose warriors have fought shoulder to shoulder with ours, whose armies have upheld the honour of the flag on many a gory field!
('2', 69, 1, 6, 177883) There are plenty of European stores in India, and well patronized and flourishing, too.
('2', 69, 2, 7, 177971) It is, in your Memorialists’ humble opinion, because the Indians sell the wares for the European merchants, that there are so many large European houses which afford employment to hundreds of European clerks and assistants.
('2', 69, 2, 8, 178195) Your Memorialists submit that an industrious and frugal class of men, as the Indians are admitted to be even by their most virulent opponents, cannot but on the whole add to the general prosperity, wealth, and consequently material happiness of the place they go to.
('2', 69, 2, 9, 178462) The Star sums up the situation with regard to the Uitlanders in the Transvaal—the class of people who so inconsistently object to the presence of the Indians in South Africa, in the following words:
('2', 69, 3, 10, 178661) South Africa is a new country.
('2', 69, 3, 11, 178692) It should therefore be open to all.
('2', 69, 3, 12, 178728) Poverty should be no bar to admission.
('2', 69, 3, 13, 178767) The vast majority of those now in affluence, came here originally with only the proverbial half crown in their pockets.
('2', 69, 3, 14, 178887) By all means let us keep the population reputable; do so however, by the just and stringent enforcement of local laws against vagrancy and roguery, and not by the arbitrary exclusion of new arrivals before it is possible to know whether under the better conditions of a new country they might not take their place amongst useful citizens of the land.
('2', 69, 4, 15, 179238) These remarks with the necessary changes are word for word applicable to the Indian community; and if the position there taken up is correct and acceptable with reference to the Uitlanders, much more, your Memorialists venture to submit, should it be in the present case.

('2', 75, 19, 27, 196537) Nor is this all.
('2', 75, 19, 28, 196554) There will be no finality to the anti Indian legislation, if Her Majesty’s Government do not intervene on behalf of the Indian British subjects residing in the Colony.
('2', 75, 19, 29, 196722) The Corporations have applied to the Government for powers to enable them to remove Indians to locations, to refuse to issue licences (this is practically covered by one of the Bills quoted above), and to refuse to sell or transfer immovable property to the Indians.
('2', 75, 19, 30, 196989) It is believed that the Government have not returned an encouraging reply to the first and the last proposals; still, the proposals are there; and there is no guarantee that, because the Government feel disinclined to entertain the proposals at present, for reasons best known to them, they will remain in the same mood for ever.
('2', 76, 0, 1, 197319) VOL. 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 77
('2', 76, 1, 2, 197361) In conclusion, your Memorialists pray that, in view of the events narrated and the restrictive legislation forecasted above, a timely pronouncement of the policy with reference to the status of the Indian British subjects, or a confirmation of the despatch referred to above, be made so as to remove and prevent restriction on Her Majesty’s Indian subjects residing in the Colony of Natal, or grant such relief as may meet the ends of justice.
('2', 76, 1, 3, 197805) And for this act of justice and mercy, your Memorialists shall, as in duty bound, ever pray.
('2', 76, 1, 4, 197898) ABDUL CARIM HAJEE ADAM (DADA ABDULLA & CO.) AND THIRTY ONE OTHERS

('2', 80, 9, 11, 209024) DEAR SIR,
('2', 80, 10, 12, 209034) Neither you nor your passengers may be aware that the feeling in the Colony
('2', 80, 11, 13, 209110) against the inflow of Asiatics has been running very high lately, and has culminated
('2', 80, 12, 14, 209195) on the arrival of your ship and the Naderi.
('2', 80, 13, 15, 209239) Following on that, public meetings have been held in Durban, at which the
('2', 80, 14, 16, 209313) enclosed resolutions were carried with acclamation.
('2', 80, 14, 17, 209365) So largely attended were these
('2', 80, 15, 18, 209396) meetings that all desiring it could not get into the Town Hall.
('2', 80, 16, 19, 209460) Almost every man in Durban has signed signifying his intention to prevent
('2', 80, 17, 20, 209534) those on board your ship and the Naderi landing in the Colony and we are most
('2', 80, 18, 21, 209612) desirous there should, if possible, be avoided a conflict between the men of Durban
('2', 80, 19, 22, 209696) and your passengers, which will most assuredly happen if they attempt to land.
('2', 80, 20, 23, 209775) As your passengers are ignorant of the state of feeling, and have come here in
('2', 80, 21, 24, 209854) ignorance, and we have it from the Attorney General that if your people are willing to
('2', 80, 22, 25, 209941) return to India, the Colony will pay the expense.
('2', 80, 23, 26, 209991) We shall therefore be glad to receive an answer from you before the ship comes
('2', 80, 24, 27, 210070) alongside the wharf, whether the passengers elect to return to India at the Colony’s
('2', 80, 25, 28, 210155) expense or to endeavour to force a landing against the thousands of men who are ready
('2', 80, 26, 29, 210241) and waiting to oppose their landing.
('2', 80, 27, 30, 210278) Yours truly,
('2', 80, 28, 31, 210291) (Sd.) HARRY SPARKS

('2', 81, 5, 5, 211087) That the said steamer, laden with a cargo of general merchandise and carrying 350 passengers, left the Port of Bombay on the 30th [28th?] day of November last and dropped anchor in the outer anchorage of this Port at noon on the 18th day of December, 1896.
('2', 81, 6, 6, 211344) Before leaving Bombay, the crew and passengers were inspected and counted and a bill of health and port clearance was granted.
('2', 81, 7, 7, 211471) Throughout the voyage, the passengers and crew were free from sickness save the saloon cook who suffered from swollen feet but who, on being examined on the 19th December by the doctor, was reported to be suffering from a complicated disease of the liver and kidneys of which he died on the 20th December, and upon arrival here, the said appearer handed to the Health Officer of this Port the usual documents as to the health of all on board, and in reply to the said appearer’s enquiries, the Health Officer informed him that the said vessel would be placed in quarantine for five days in order to made 23 days from the time of leaving the Port of Bombay.
('2', 81, 8, 8, 212128) On the following day the decks, passengers’ and crew’s quarters were washed and disinfected.

('2', 81, 11, 11, 212516) On the 22nd December, the decks were washed and the water closets, latrines, etc., were disinfected.

('2', 87, 13, 15, 223605) How long after contraction would the symptoms of bubonic fever or plague be manifest?
('2', 87, 13, 16, 223691) The period of incubation varies from a few hours to a week (Crook shank’s, 4th Edition, 1896).
('2', 87, 13, 17, 223786) I have killed guinea pigs in 24 hours by inoculating with the cultivation.

('2', 88, 3, 3, 224271) December 22, 1896
('2', 88, 4, 4, 224289) DEAR SIR,
('2', 88, 5, 5, 224299) For your information regarding the plague now prevalent in Bombay, I will answer your questions seriatim.
('2', 88, 6, 6, 224405) Firstly, the incubation period is generally considered to be from 2 to 8 days, though Sir Walter Broadbent considers the period from a few hours to 21 days.
('2', 88, 6, 7, 224562) Twenty one days appears to be the outside limit the disease can require to make itself manifest after contraction.
('2', 88, 7, 8, 224677) Secondly, in my opinion, if there was beyond doubt a clean bill of health during a 21 days’ voyage, there would be no danger of the disease in that boat.
('2', 88, 8, 9, 224831) Thirdly, the keeping closely packed of a large number of persons in a confined space is always liable to lead to ill health, and therefore to be avoided if possible.
('2', 88, 10, 10, 224997) Faithfully yours,

('2', 93, 0, 1, 231327) 94 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 93, 1, 2, 231368) it that this is your reason.
('2', 93, 1, 3, 231397) Presuming this to be a good ground in law, it would certainly have to be based on reasonable grounds.
('2', 93, 2, 4, 231499) Dr. Crookshank, in his recent edition on bacteriology, says “that the period of incubation varies from a few hours to a week.” Drs.
('2', 93, 2, 5, 231631) Prince and Harrison, in their respective reports which we annexed to our clients’ petition to the Government, say much the same, and you, we are informed, give the period of twelve days.
('2', 93, 2, 6, 231818) It is now 26 and 28 days respectively since the vessels left Bombay, and they have now, and have had, ever since the commencement of their respective voyages, an absolute clean bill of health; and yet, despite these facts, you declare it as your intention to refuse pratique until a period of twelve days have [sic] elapsed after you have disinfected the passengers and ships.
('2', 93, 2, 7, 232195) Our clients instruct us to protest against such a course, and to inform you that you will be held responsible for all loss caused to them by reason of your refused pratique, and also for the injury to the health of the passengers, which is likely to ensue from being confined to the steamers for a lengthened period.
('2', 93, 3, 8, 232512) We are, likewise, instructed to draw your attention to the fact that the steamers have now been at the outer anchorage for upwards of eight days, and that it would appear from your letter of today that no steps have been taken to disinfect them, although on Thursday morning last you informed the writer that you would probably do it that afternoon; for this delay you will also be held responsible.
('2', 93, 4, 9, 232912) With regard to placing the passengers in quarantine on shore at the expense of the owners of the vessels, we have to inform you that our clients regard your refusal of pratique as an illegal action, and they will, therefore, be no party to your proceedings, further than to request you, without one hour’s unnecessary delay, to take such steps as you may think proper for what you are pleased to call disinfecting the vessels.

('2', 94, 5, 6, 234251) We are the owners of the Courland s.s., and we represent the owners of the Naderi s.s., which steamers left Bombay for this port on the 30th November last, 1 and arrived here, respectively, on the 18th ultimo at 5.30 p.m.
('2', 94, 5, 7, 234473) and 2 p.m., having on board, respectively, 255 and 356 of Her Majesty’s Indian subjects.
('2', 94, 6, 8, 234562) On the following morning, a Gazette Extraordinary was issued by the Government, containing a Proclamation of the Governor, proclaiming Bombay an infected port.
('2', 94, 7, 9, 234722) The above steamers had absolutely clean bills of health on arrival, and during the whole of their respective voyages, but they were refused pratique on grounds which the Acting Health Officer of the Port refused to give, but which, we presume, were given to us by telegram from the Principal Under Secretary, dated the 24th ultimo, as follows: “That the Medical Committee has advised Government that the period of incubation of the bubonic plague being sometimes as much as twelve days, the quarantine should be of that period after all chances of disinfection [sic] have been destroyed, and Committee has also recommended the thorough disinfection of immigrants and their clothing, and the burning of all old rags and dirty clothing.
('2', 94, 7, 10, 235457) Government has approved the Committee’s Report, and has instructed the Health Officer to act upon it, and not to grant pratique to the ships until he is satisfied that the conditions of the Report have been fulfilled.” The steamers lay at anchor in the outer anchorage from the 18th ultimo, until the 28th ultimo, without any steps whatever being taken to disinfect them, but on the 29th ultimo, we believe, disinfection was completed, in terms of the above mentioned report of the Medical Committee.
('2', 94, 8, 11, 235958) This delay in disinfection cost the owners of the steamers one hundred and fifty pounds per diem, or a sum of £1,650.

('2', 95, 1, 3, 237017) During the last few days, two meetings of excited European townspeople have been held at Durban, called together under the following notice which appeared in several issues of The Natal Advertiser: “Wanted every man in Durban, to attend a meeting to be held in the large room at the Victoria Cafe, on Monday evening next, the 4th January, at 8 o’clock, for the purpose of arranging a demonstration to proceed to the Point and protest against the landing of Asiatics, Harry Sparks, Chairman of Preliminary Meeting.” The two meetings were largely attended, and in spite of the unlawful objects of such meetings clearly indicated in the above notice, the Town Hall of Durban was opened for such meetings.

('2', 96, 6, 11, 240865) “He had come to the meeting in a bit of a hurry, but he thought he had placed before them the leading points, and it meant this, that they were going to back the Government up in this matter, that they believed the Government would co operate with them, and that not a soul would be allowed to land from those two ships in the harbour of Durban.
('2', 96, 6, 12, 241211) (Loud applause.)”
('2', 96, 7, 13, 241229) We extract the following from the report of the proceedings at the second meeting held on the 7th instant contained in The Mercury of today:
('2', 96, 8, 14, 241370) MR. J. S. WYLIE: “Somebody said ‘sink the ships,’ and he had heard a naval man say he would give a month’s pay for one shot at the ships.” (Cheers and laughter.) “Was every man prepared to put down a month’s pay in this matter?
('2', 96, 8, 15, 241598) (Cries of ‘Yes,’ and ‘Unanimous’.)”
('2', 96, 9, 16, 241634) MR. SYKES: “They must make up their minds to lose both time and money; they must be prepared to leave their work and proceed to Demonstration.
('2', 96, 9, 17, 241777) It must be done on an organized system—they must obey their leader.
('2', 96, 9, 18, 241845) It was no good for everyone to throw one another overboard.
('2', 96, 9, 19, 241905) (Laughter.) They must strictly obey orders.
('2', 96, 9, 20, 241949) At the word of command, ‘fall in’, and do what they were commanded.” (Cheers, laughter and encores).
('2', 96, 9, 21, 242050) He moved: “That we proceed by demonstration to the Point on the arrival of the Indians, but each man binds himself to conform to the orders of his leaders.
('2', 96, 9, 22, 242206) (Cheers).”
('2', 96, 10, 23, 242217) MACKENZIE: “Since they last met, the position had become less acute.
('2', 96, 10, 24, 242286) They had advanced the line laid down, and they knew exactly the position of the Government, the willingness of the Government to assist them by all the power they had at their disposal.
('2', 96, 10, 25, 242472) As far as the Government was concerned, he was thoroughly satisfied.
('2', 96, 10, 26, 242541) The Government on this point were absolutely at one with the burgesses of
('2', 97, 0, 1, 242615) 98 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 97, 1, 2, 242656) Durban, and therefore, they had to set aside any question as to difficulty of conflict with the gentlemen whom the electors had placed, for the time being, in the position of the Government.
('2', 97, 1, 3, 242847) They were in accord with the Colony, and that was a matter for congratulation.
('2', 97, 1, 4, 242926) Unfortunately, the Government was so placed that they could not insist on the Indians not landing here, and being sent back in the ships in which they came.
('2', 97, 1, 5, 243083) That was practically impossible; and the Committee pointed out to Mr. Escombe that this condition of things was an anomaly.
('2', 97, 1, 6, 243207) There must be some short fall in the Constitution of the Colony when the best interests and absolute desires of the Colonists could not be achieved and met by the machinery of Government.
('2', 97, 1, 7, 243395) (Cheers.) They pointed out that the Colonists would insist that that condition of things should cease, and that the Government should be placed in the position of being able to meet the wishes and necessities of the country.
('2', 97, 1, 8, 243620) Mr. Escombe agreed with them, and they had heard what steps had been taken to meet the urgency of the case.
('2', 97, 1, 9, 243728) Government was taking all the steps it could, and, within a day or two, he hoped that every meeting held throughout the Colony would show one unanimous desire for and immediate summoning of Parliament.
('2', 97, 1, 10, 243930) The men of Durban were unanimous.

('2', 97, 2, 18, 244873) One passenger might be reasonably expected to have had some suspicion of that point.

('2', 97, 4, 22, 245153) “They had a right to shut the door, and they intended to shut the door.
('2', 97, 4, 23, 245225) They would deal fairly also with these people now in quarantine—they would even be fair in dealing with respect to that solitary individual, but he hoped there would be a marked distinction between the dealing.

('2', 97, 4, 25, 245706) They did not intend to lay down the agitation until they achieved something.

('2', 98, 1, 2, 245864) burgesses of Durban to be ready at any time, as they had been in the past, to go down to the Point when called upon to make a demonstration, and they would show the people who came by these boats what the Colonists of Natal meant, and they would also have a further object, which would be gained from instructions of the leaders when they were there.

('2', 98, 11, 23, 248157) The meeting appears to have been greatly encouraged, in the carrying out of
('2', 98, 12, 24, 248233) their demonstration, by the report made to the meeting of a Committee which had
('2', 98, 13, 25, 248313) waited on Mr. Escombe, Her Majesty’s Minister of Defence in this Colony.

('2', 98, 16, 28, 248492) over two hours, in a fair and reasonable manner.

('2', 98, 17, 31, 248637) But you must be careful

('2', 99, 0, 1, 248746) 100 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 99, 1, 2, 248788) is a very different thing to spurring a willing horse to death.’ Then the Committee
('2', 99, 2, 3, 248872) said: ‘If the Government did nothing, Durban would have to do it herself, and go in

('2', 99, 10, 13, 249515) It is not for us to express our opinion regarding such words as these, if they were actually uttered by the Minister of Defence, but we would most respectfully draw your attention to the extreme danger of allowing a large body of excited men to proceed to the point, however peaceful their original intentions may have been, and more especially, when from the utterances of the speakers and the comments thereon of the meeting, the gravest cause of anxiety must be aroused regarding the objects of the Demonstration, and the safety of the passengers on the two steamers.
('2', 99, 11, 14, 250086) We would respectfully submit that as law abiding inhabitants of this Colony, we have endeavoured cheerfully to submit to the requirements of the Government, despite serious loss to us, and that having so complied, we are entitled, on obtaining pratique, to discharge our steamers’ passengers at the wharf, and that in so doing, we are entitled to the protection of the Government for passengers and property against the lawless acts of any persons, whoever they may be.
('2', 99, 11, 15, 250556) But, in order to render unnecessary any act on the part of the Government which might tend to intensify the excitement which exists, we are ready to co operate with the Government in taking all necessary steps for the landing of passengers quietly and unknown to the public.
('2', 99, 11, 16, 250831) We shall be glad to hear if this suggestion meets with your approval, and if so, what is required of us in carrying it out.
('2', 99, 12, 17, 250955) We have the honour to be, Sir, Your obedient servants, (Signed) DADA ABDOOLLA & CO.

('2', 101, 6, 10, 253447) (APPENDIX T)
('2', 101, 7, 11, 253460) Copy DURBAN, January 10, 1897
('2', 101, 8, 12, 253490) TO THE HONOURABLE HARRY ESCOMBE
('2', 101, 9, 13, 253522) DEAR SIR,
('2', 101, 10, 14, 253532) We have duly advised our clients, Messrs Dada Abdoolla and Co., of the result of Mr. Laughton’s conference with you of yesterday, whereat you repudiated Mr. Wylie’s public statement of what had fallen from you at your conference with the Committee of the Demonstration, and said that your statement to such Committee was to this effect: That, if the Ministers were unable to cope with a Durban riot, they would be unfitted to hold office, and would resign.
('2', 101, 11, 15, 253989) At your conference with Mr. Laughton, you also laid down the following propositions as recognized by the Government:
('2', 102, 0, 1, 254106) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 103
('2', 102, 1, 2, 254148) 1. That upon the requirements of the quarantine being carried out, pratique must be granted to the steamers Courland and Naderi,
('2', 102, 2, 3, 254277) 2. That upon pratique being granted, the steamers were entitled to discharge their passengers and cargo at the wharf, either by the steamers themselves being brought inside or by means of tugs and lighters.
('2', 102, 3, 4, 254484) 3. That the Government is responsible for the protection of passengers and cargo from the violence of rioters.
('2', 102, 4, 5, 254595) On the other hand, you were informed by Mr. Laughton that, inasmuch as Indians had to dwell in this Colony with Europeans, our clients recognized it as desirable that, in the landing of passengers, as little as possible should be done which would tend to intensify a feeling, which at present apparently exists amongst a certain class of Europeans against the Indians; and, therefore, that he felt sure, that our clients would co operate with the Government to the extent of postponing the disembarkation for a reasonable time to enable the Government to make proper arrangements.
('2', 102, 5, 6, 255176) We are instructed to inform you that the time of quarantine expires today, and that, under ordinary circumstances, our clients would have proceeded with disembarkation today, but that they are willing to postpone it for a reasonable time to suit the convenience of the Government, provided the loss sustained by them in so doing, that is to say £150 per dies, is borne by the Government.
('2', 102, 6, 7, 255564) We trust you will see the reasonableness of this proposal, and that it will be adopted by the Government.
('2', 102, 7, 8, 255670) We draw your attention to the fact that several gentlemen holding Her Majesty’s commission in Volunteer Forces are organizing the intended riot, called by them a “Demonstration”, and have allowed themselves to be advertised in the newspapers and by placards, as being in command of sections of the intending rioters; also, that Captain Sparks has taken the same means of advertising himself as the Chief in command of the proposed riot.
('2', 102, 8, 9, 256107) We would most respectfully and reluctantly give it as our opinion that, if the organization had at an earlier stage been proclaimed as illegal, instead of being allowed to swell itself under false hopes, the same excitement would not now exist, and there would have been little difficulty in landing the passengers in due course; and that the organization, or the objects of it, having been publicly declared to have the sympathy of the Government, which declaration was apparently confirmed by Government officers being in command, and by Government employees being in the ranks, it has obtained a hold on the public mind which otherwise it could not have done.
('2', 102, 9, 10, 256770) We have the honour to be, Sir, Your obedient servants,
('2', 102, 10, 11, 256825) (Signed) GOODRICKE, LAUGHTON & COOKE

('2', 104, 11, 11, 259546) We cannot but acknowledge the feeling, which at present exists among a certain class in Durban, against the landing of the Indians.
('2', 104, 11, 12, 259678) But, at the same time, we must most respectfully inform you that this feeling has been fostered by the Government, rather than discouraged, in the manner pointed out to you in our letters of the 8th and 9th instant.
('2', 104, 12, 13, 259894) We beg to express our surprise at your making no reference to the following facts brought to your notice in our above mentioned letters:
('2', 104, 13, 14, 260031) 1. That meetings with illegal objects have been held and are being held by certain persons in Durban, without any attempt on the part of the Government to inhibit them.
('2', 104, 13, 15, 260200) 2. That Dr. MacKenzie, one of the Medical Board, has been one of the most energetic instigators of the objects of these meetings.
('2', 104, 13, 16, 260330) 3. That it had been stated at some of those meetings that the Government was in sympathy with the objects of the meetings.
('2', 104, 13, 17, 260453) 4. That the Minister of Defence had stated to the Committee of the organization, practically, that the Government would take no steps to hinder the
('2', 105, 0, 1, 260601) 106 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 105, 1, 2, 260643) rioters in attaining their illegal objects.
('2', 105, 1, 3, 260687) 5. That we claimed the protection of the Government for passengers and property against the lawless acts of persons, whoever they may be.
('2', 105, 1, 4, 260825) 6. To the “Declaration” of the rioters, set out in our letter of the 9th instant.
('2', 105, 1, 5, 260907) 7. To railway employees of the Government taking part with the rioters.
('2', 105, 1, 6, 260979) 8. To the leadership of the riot being under Captain Sparks and others of Her Majesty’s commissioned officers taking subordinate positions under him.
('2', 105, 1, 7, 261129) 9. To our request that we should receive an assurance of the Government that Government servants will be prohibited from taking any part in the demonstration.
('2', 105, 1, 8, 261288) 10. To our proposal to postpone the disembarkation for a reasonable time to suit the convenience of the Government, provided the loss sustained by us in so doing, that is to say £150 per diem, is borne by the Government.
('2', 105, 2, 9, 261509) We now beg for a reply to each of these allegations and questions, and to request that you will inform us what steps, if any, have been taken to protect the disembarkation of the steamers.
('2', 105, 3, 10, 261698) The steamers have now been at the outer anchorage for 24 days, at a cost of £150 per diem to us; and this being so, we trust you will see the reasonableness of your giving us a full answer by noon tomorrow.
('2', 105, 3, 11, 261905) And we think it right to inform you that, failing a definite reply giving us an assurance that we shall be paid £150 per diem from Sunday last and that you are taking steps to suppress the rioters, so as to enable us to disembark the steamers, preparations will be at once commenced to steam into the harbour, relying on the protection which, we respectfully submit, Government is bound to give us.
('2', 105, 4, 12, 262304) In order that there may be no mistake in the minds of the Government as to the objects of the rioters, we beg to enclose the copy of a notice signed by Captain Sparks, and served yesterday by his deputies, Captain Wylie and others, on the Captain of the Courland, s.s.
('2', 105, 4, 13, 262573) (This letter appears elsewhere.
('2', 105, 5, 14, 262605) The effect of this notice signed by Captain Sparks has been to make many passengers afraid of their lives in the event of landing at this port.
('2', 105, 6, 15, 262749) We, likewise, beg to enclose a copy of a memorandum written by Captain Wylie and served upon the Captains of each of the steamers for their signatures, and represented by him as embodying the only terms upon which the ships will be allowed to disembark.
('2', 105, 7, 16, 263003) We beg most respectfully to ask, in conclusion, if the Government will allow such flagrant acts to proceed which can only end in injury, if not death, to many of Her Majesty’s subjects.
('2', 105, 7, 17, 263189) We have the honour to be, Sir, Your obedient servants, (Signed) Dada Abdoolla & Co.

('2', 106, 3, 4, 263468) Terms agreed between the Captain of the s.s.
('2', 106, 3, 5, 263513) Naderi and the Committee of the Point Demonstration: 1. The Naderi shall not leave the outer anchorage to come into the port of Durban.
('2', 106, 3, 6, 263649) 2. All wives and children of Natal Indians to be allowed to land.
('2', 106, 3, 7, 263715) 3. All old Natal Indians to be allowed to land, on the Committee being satisfied that they are returning here.
('2', 106, 3, 8, 263826) 4. All others to be transferred to the s.s.
('2', 106, 3, 9, 263870) Courland and so many as the Courland cannot take, to be taken back by the Naderi to Bombay.
('2', 106, 3, 10, 263962) the Committee pay the ship the exact amount of passage money required to send back to India the Indians the Courland cannot take.
('2', 106, 3, 11, 264092) 5. The Committee pay to the Indians the exact value, and no more, of the clothing and effects destroyed at this port.
('2', 106, 3, 12, 264210) 6. The Committee pay to the Naderi the extra expense she may be put to in having to coal and take provisions at the outer anchorage instead of in the harbour, and such additional expense as the ship may be put to through the Committee not allowing the Naderi to leave the anchorage.

('2', 107, 0, 1, 264914) 108 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 107, 1, 2, 264956) (APPENDIX Y)
('2', 107, 3, 3, 264969) I observe, in your leader in this morning’s issue of The Mercury, you give it as your opinion that Mr. Gandhi was ill advised in landing and coming through Durban on Wednesday last; and, as I was certainly a party to his coming ashore as he did, I shall feel obliged by your giving me an opportunity of answering your remark.
('2', 107, 3, 4, 265295) Hitherto it has been useless to speak unless you were prepared to adopt the programme of the Demonstration party and its particular mode of attaining its ends; but, now that the Committee is dissolved, and the minds of men are no longer being inflamed, I trust that my letter will receive calm and thoughtful consideration.
('2', 107, 3, 5, 265619) Let me commence by saying that, while the agitation was proceeding, I obtained a copy of Mr. Gandhi’s pamphlet published in India, and concerning which we received Reuter’s cable some months ago, and I can assure your readers that Reuter not only misrepresented the pamphlet, but misrepresented it so much that, on reading the two, I cannot but come to the conclusion that the writer of the cable had not read the pamphlet.
('2', 107, 3, 6, 266043) I can say, further, that there is nothing in the pamphlet which anyone could take exception to on the ground of untruthfulness.
('2', 107, 3, 7, 266171) Anyone can obtain a copy and read it if he chooses.
('2', 107, 3, 8, 266223) Let your readers do so and answer honestly: Is there anything in it untrue?
('2', 107, 3, 9, 266299) Is there anything in it which a political opponent was not justified in saying in support of his cause?
('2', 107, 3, 10, 266403) Unfortunately, the mind of the public was inflamed by Reuter’s version of it, 1 and throughout the recent disturbances, there was not a man to point out to the public the difference between the true and the untrue.
('2', 107, 3, 11, 266618) I don’t wish to hurt any man’s feelings by repeating the words which he uttered in the hour of excitement and which, I know, in his calmer moments he will deeply regret, but, in order that the position may be understood, I must place before your readers, shortly, what Mr. Gandhi’s position was before he took the step of landing and coming into town.
('2', 107, 3, 12, 266970) I shall, therefore, without mentioning names, give the effect of just a few of the public statements made concerning him: (1) That he had dragged our reputations through the gutters of India, and had painted them as black and filthy as his own face.
('2', 107, 3, 13, 267220) (2) That he might be allowed to come ashore that we might have the opportunity of spitting at him.
('2', 107, 3, 14, 267319) (3) That some special treatment, at the word of command, should be meted out to him and that he should never be allowed to land in Natal.
('2', 107, 3, 15, 267457) (4) That he was engaging himself, on board the quarantined ship, in getting briefs from passengers against the Government.
('2', 107, 3, 16, 267580) (5) That when three gentlemen, representing the Committee of the Demonstration, went on board the Courland, he was in such a ‘funk’ that he was stowed away in the lowest hold; and, on another occasion, that he was seen sitting on the deck of the Courland in a most dejected mood.
('2', 107, 3, 17, 267860) These are only a few of the things stated against him, but I take them as sufficient for my purpose.
('2', 107, 4, 18, 267961) 1 Vide "Memorial to Secretary of State for the Colonies", 15 3 1897.
('2', 108, 0, 1, 268030) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 109
('2', 108, 1, 2, 268072) If the above charges wee true, if, in other words, he was a cowardly
('2', 108, 2, 3, 268141) calumniator, stabbing us when at a safe distance, and if he had acted so that he was a
('2', 108, 3, 4, 268228) fit object to be spat at, and afraid to return and face the consequences, then he was
('2', 108, 4, 5, 268314) unfitted to be a member of an honourable profession, or to hold the position of leader
('2', 108, 5, 6, 268401) in a great political question in which his countrymen take as much interest as we do
('2', 108, 6, 7, 268486) and are as much entitled to ventilate their political views as we are.
('2', 108, 6, 8, 268557) Before he went to
('2', 108, 7, 9, 268575) India, I had met him in business matters on several occasions, and was struck with the
('2', 108, 8, 10, 268662) anxiety shown by him to avoid litigation and to put matters in dispute on a fair basis,
('2', 108, 9, 11, 268750) and with the honourable manner in which he dealt with business matters, so much so
('2', 108, 10, 12, 268833) that I formed a very high opinion concerning him.
('2', 108, 10, 13, 268883) I say this advisedly and I have no
('2', 108, 11, 14, 268918) doubt my words will be approved by the members of the profession who know Mr.
('2', 108, 12, 15, 268996) Gandhi.
('2', 108, 12, 16, 269004) It was once said by an eminent judge that success at the Bar was not attained
('2', 108, 13, 17, 269082) by endeavouring to injure opponents at the Bar, but only by so qualifying one’s self
('2', 108, 14, 18, 269167) as to be equal or superior to such opponents.
('2', 108, 14, 19, 269213) So, in political matters, we must give
('2', 108, 15, 20, 269252) fair play to an opponent, and answer his argument by counter argument, and not by
('2', 108, 16, 21, 269334) heaving half a brick at his head.
('2', 108, 16, 22, 269368) I have found Mr. Gandhi, both in legal matters and
('2', 108, 17, 23, 269419) on the Asiatic question, a fair and honourable opponent, obnoxious to us as his
('2', 108, 18, 24, 269499) contentions may be, who would scorn to hit below the belt.
('2', 108, 18, 25, 269558) To vindicate himself
('2', 108, 19, 26, 269579) before the public then, it was decided that he should not give his enemies an
('2', 108, 20, 27, 269657) opportunity of saying that he was ‘funking it’ on board the Courland, where he could
('2', 108, 21, 28, 269742) have stayed for a week, if he had chosen; that he should not sneak into Durban like a

('2', 108, 24, 32, 269989) simply as a member of the Bar, to testify, by so doing, that Mr. Gandhi was an
('2', 108, 25, 33, 270068) honourable member of an honourable profession, in order that I might raise my voice

('2', 108, 28, 38, 270383) He Might have
('2', 108, 29, 39, 270397) kept to the boat at Cato’s Creek, when he saw the crowd collecting to receive him; he

('2', 109, 4, 8, 271448) LAUGHTON.—The Natal Mercury, 16th January, 1897.
('2', 109, 5, 9, 271497) There has been a good deal said about Reuter’s cabled summary of Mr. Gandhi’s
('2', 109, 6, 10, 271575) Indian pamphlet, within the last day or two .
('2', 109, 6, 11, 271621) The general impression that is
('2', 109, 7, 12, 271652) conveyed by these summaries is unquestionably different to the impression created in
('2', 109, 8, 13, 271737) the minds of those who read the pamphlet .
('2', 109, 8, 14, 271780) Frankly, it may be admitted that Mr.
('2', 109, 9, 15, 271817) Gandhi’s pamphlet is not an unfair statement of the position of the Indian in South
('2', 109, 10, 16, 271901) Africa from an Indian’s point of view.
('2', 109, 10, 17, 271940) The European refuses to recognize the Indian as
('2', 109, 11, 18, 271988) an equal’ and the Indian, as a British subject, considers he has a right to all the
('2', 109, 12, 19, 272072) privileges of the British subjects of European birth in the Colony, and under the
('2', 109, 13, 20, 272154) Proclamation of 1858, he is legally entitled to that claim.
('2', 109, 13, 21, 272214) That there is a prejudice in
('2', 109, 14, 22, 272243) South Africa against the Indian, it would be folly to deny, but at the same time, Mr.
('2', 109, 15, 23, 272329) Gandhi, we think, might make greater allowance for the fact that, as whole, his
('2', 109, 16, 24, 272409) countrymen in South Africa are not of a class that, even in India, would be allowed to
('2', 109, 17, 25, 272496) ride in first class railway carriages or admitted into the best hotels .
('2', 109, 17, 26, 272569) Coming back
('2', 109, 18, 27, 272581) to the pamphlet and the cabled summaries, these latter might have been as correctly
('2', 109, 19, 28, 272665) written of some pamphlet describing the treatment of the Armenians by the Turks,
('2', 109, 20, 29, 272746) and, in fact, Reuter’s cable read by itself gives some such impression.
('2', 109, 20, 30, 272818) When the
('2', 109, 21, 31, 272827) pamphlet written by Mr. Gandhi, however, is read in its entirety, the context reveals
('2', 109, 22, 32, 272913) the fact that, while there are instances of real hardship given, the bulk of it is made up
('2', 109, 23, 33, 273004) of political grievances in many cases similar to those the Uitlanders complain of in
('2', 109, 24, 34, 273089) the Transvaal.
('2', 109, 24, 35, 273104) The pamphlet, in short, contains practically nothing that Mr. Gandhi
('2', 109, 25, 36, 273173) did not publish previously in Natal, and nothing that is not generally known.
('2', 109, 26, 37, 273251) other hand, it is useless for Mr. Gandhi, or anyone else, to endeavour to have the
('2', 109, 27, 38, 273334) Indian accepted in South Africa at his own estimate.
('2', 109, 27, 39, 273387) There is no use being
('2', 109, 28, 40, 273409) hypocritical in the matter.
('2', 109, 28, 41, 273437) There is strong and deeply rooted prejudice against Indians
('2', 109, 29, 42, 273497) flocking into the country, and against their customs and mode of life.
('2', 109, 29, 43, 273568) They may be
('2', 109, 30, 44, 273580) British subjects by law, but they are aliens by what is stronger than law.
('2', 109, 30, 45, 273655) viz., racial
('2', 109, 31, 46, 273668) traditions and instincts.—The Natal Mercury, 18th January, 1897.
('2', 109, 32, 47, 273733) It is now beginning to be admitted that the outcry against Mr. Gandhi was much more bitter and violent than warranted by the facts and that his statement, although perhaps exaggerated, did not amount to such a wilful and deliberate attempt to blacken the character of the Colonists as to justify the vindictive attitude assumed, doubtless, under a misconception, by some extremists.
('2', 109, 32, 48, 274116) Mr. Gandhi is endeavouring to perform for his compatriots similar services to those which Englishmen have
('2', 110, 0, 1, 274222) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 111
('2', 110, 1, 2, 274264) always been ready to perform, and, when time has been afforded for cool reflection, it will be recognized that, however mistaken his methods, or however untenable his theses, it is the worst possible policy to treat him as an outcast and a pariah, because he is striving to secure what he considers to be the rights of his fellow countrymen.
('2', 110, 1, 3, 274606) It has always been the boast of Englishmen that they can take up a side without abandoning all fair play to their opponents.
('2', 110, 1, 4, 274731) Colonists know that it would be dangerous to the well being of the Colony to grant what Mr. Gandhi demands; they know that the fundamental and abiding racial distinctions between the Asiatic and European for ever preclude anything like social equality, and that no argument will ever bridge the gulf; they know that, even though abstract justice may apparently be against them, the instinct of self preservation warns them that theirs is the only safe position; in short, they know that the Colony cannot remain a white Colony if no limit is put to Asiatic immigration.
('2', 110, 1, 5, 275301) All this, however, may be admitted, without spoiling our case by unfair and unnecessary harshness towards those who quite naturally, take other views.
('2', 110, 1, 6, 275452) Harm has been done already by the accentuation of the personal element, and it is to be hoped that Colonists will, in future, exhibit that dignity and self restraint in the conduct of the campaign, without which we cannot expect the approval of disinterested observers.—The Natal Mercury, 19th January, 1897.
('2', 110, 2, 7, 275761) Mr. Gandhi’s statements to the Advertiser interviewer 1 have been read with considerable interest, and show that he has a good deal to say for himself.
('2', 110, 2, 8, 275913) If his assertions are correct, there seems to have been a good deal of exaggeration in the statements made about him and his proposed scheme to swamp the Colony with Indians, which have had much to do with the irritation of the public mind against him.
('2', 110, 2, 9, 276166) In the interests of justice it is to be hoped this matter will be cleared up.
('2', 110, 2, 10, 276244) It has been asserted that the Government have information in their possession to prove the existence of this scheme.
('2', 110, 2, 11, 276361) If so, the evidence ought to be brought forward, because this really constitutes the gravamen of the charges against Gandhi.
('2', 110, 2, 12, 276486) Mr. Gandhi admits that “the leaders of the Demonstration Committee, and anybody in Natal, would be perfectly justified in getting up a constitutional agitation if there was an organized attempt to swamp the Colony with Indians.” So that, if the scheme can be proved, as some people state, Mr. Gandhi’s mouth will be closed .
('2', 110, 2, 13, 276811) Then, again, he totally denies the assertion that he was instigating legal proceeding against the Government for unlawful detention.
('2', 110, 2, 14, 276944) If there is any proof for that charge, it, too, should be produced.
('2', 110, 2, 15, 277012) He denies, further, that a printing press and compositors were brought ever by him, or that the number of passengers for Natal is anything like so great as alleged.
('2', 110, 2, 16, 277177) These matters are surely capable of direct proof or disproof, and it would be well if they were settled, because, if what Mr. Gandhi says is true, it would
('2', 110, 3, 17, 277333) 1 Vide “Interview to The Natal Advertiser”, 13 1 1897.
('2', 111, 0, 1, 277388) 112 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 111, 1, 2, 277430) seem that the recent agitation was started on insufficient grounds, and incorrect information .
('2', 111, 1, 3, 277526) It will be necessary, if the aid of the Imperial Government is to be obtained, to have hard facts to go upon.
('2', 111, 1, 4, 277636) It will not advance our cause to raise an outcry that the country is being swamped, and to talk about thousands of Indians coming across in one or two vessels, and then, when it is all boiled down, find there are only one or two hundred.
('2', 111, 1, 5, 277874) No good will be gained by exaggeration .
('2', 111, 1, 6, 277915) There is no getting away from the fact that this brutal outrage was committed on the very day of the Demonstration, under the influence of feelings excited by the Demonstration, and what led up to it, and also in defiance of the assurance of the representative of Government that the passengers were absolutely safe.
('2', 111, 1, 7, 278232) The incident shows what might have happened on a larger scale if the Demonstration had been carried to the lengths which were at first intended.
