('2', 113, 1, 2, 280467) 14. PETITION TO NATAL LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY 1
('2', 113, 2, 3, 280512) DURBAN, March 26, 1897
('2', 113, 3, 4, 280535) TO THE HONOURABLE THE SPEAKER AND MEMBERS OF THE HONOURABLE
('2', 113, 4, 5, 280595) THE LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY OF THE COLONY OF NATAL IN PARLIAMENT
('2', 113, 5, 6, 280657) ASSEMBLED,
('2', 113, 6, 7, 280668) PIETERMARITZBURG
('2', 113, 7, 8, 280685) THE PETITION OF THE UNDERSIGNED REPRESENTING THE
('2', 113, 8, 9, 280734) INDIAN COMMUNITY IN THIS COLONY
('2', 113, 9, 10, 280766) HUMBLY SHEWETH: That your Petitioners hereby venture to lay before this Honourable House the feeling of the Indian community with reference to the Quarantine, Trade Licences, Immigration and Uncovenanted Indians Protection Bills 2 that are now, or soon will be, before this Honourable House for consideration.
('2', 113, 9, 11, 281076) Your Petitioners understand that the first three Bills herein above referred to are meant, directly or indirectly, to restrict the immigration of Her Majesty’s Indian subjects into the Colony.
('2', 113, 9, 12, 281269) Strange as it may appear there is no mention of the persons whom they are meant to affect.
('2', 113, 9, 13, 281360) 3 With the greatest deference, your Petitioners venture to submit that such a mode of procedure is un British and, therefore, it should not receive countenance in a Colony which is supposed to be the most British in South Africa.
('2', 113, 9, 14, 281590) If it is proved to the satisfaction of this Honourable House that the presence of the Indian in the Colony is an evil and there is an alarming influx of Indians into the Colony, your Petitioners submit that it will be better in the interests of all parties concerned that a Bill directly aiming at the evil be passed.
('2', 113, 10, 15, 281908) 1 The Natal Mercury, 29 3 1897, published the text of the petition with a few introductory lines and some minor verbal alterations.
('2', 113, 10, 16, 282040) 2 For provisions of these enactments, vide “Petition to the Secretary of State for the Colonies”, 2 7 1897, Appendix A D. 3 Indians were not specifically mentioned in three of the four measures despite the fact that they were implicitly meant to affect the Indians; only the Uncovenanted Indians Protection Bill referred to the Indians by name.
('2', 114, 0, 1, 282385) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 115
('2', 114, 1, 2, 282427) But your Petitioners respectfully submit that it can be easily shown that the presence of the Indian in the Colony, instead of being an evil, is of benefit to it and that there is no alarming influx of Indians into the Colony.
('2', 114, 1, 3, 282654) In is an admitted fact that the Indians, whom the Bills are calculated to keep away from the Colony, are”sober and industrious”.
('2', 114, 1, 4, 282783) Such is the opinion pronounced by the highest authorities in the land as well as by those who are their bitterest opponents.
('2', 114, 1, 5, 282908) And your Petitioners submit that such a class of people cannot but be an economical benefit wherever they may go, more especially in newly opened up countries like Natal.
('2', 114, 1, 6, 283079) Your Petitioners further urge that the returns published by the Acting Protector of Immigrants 1 show that while 1,964 Indians arrived in the Colony between August and January last, 1,298 left it during the same period.
('2', 114, 1, 7, 283299) Your Petitioners feel sure that this Honourable House would not consider this increase to be such as to justify the introduction of the Bills under discussion.
('2', 114, 1, 8, 283459) Nor will this Honourable House, your Petitioners trust, ignore the fact that most, if not all, of the 666 Indians must have proceeded to the Transvaal.
('2', 114, 1, 9, 283611) Your Petitioners, however, do not wish to say that the statements made above should be accepted without verification.
('2', 114, 1, 10, 283729) But your Petitioners submit that the statements furnish a prima facie case for enquiry.
('2', 114, 2, 11, 283817) Your Petitioners fear that the Bills are a present to the popular prejudice.
('2', 114, 2, 12, 283894) It is, therefore, respectfully submitted that before considering the Bills this Honourable House should ascertain beyond doubt whether the evil does or does not exist.
('2', 114, 3, 13, 284062) Your Petitioners humbly suggest that a census of the free Indian population, and a searching enquiry in the question of the presence of the Indian being an evil, are absolutely essential to enable this Honourable House to arrive at a right conclusion with regard to the Bills.
('2', 114, 3, 14, 284339) Nor is this a matter that would take so long a time as to render any legislation after the enquiry ineffectual.
('2', 114, 3, 15, 284451) An examination of the Bills without reference to their veiled object and premature character, your Petitioners submit, shows that they are unjust and arbitrary measures.
('2', 114, 4, 16, 284621) 1 Vide “Memorial to Secretary of State for the Colonies”, 15 3 1897.
('2', 115, 0, 1, 284690) 116 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 115, 1, 2, 284732) As to the Quarantine Bill, your Petitioners assure this Honourable House that in criticizing it they have no wish to oppose anything, no matter how hard it may be, that may be necessary in the interestsof the health of the community.
('2', 115, 1, 3, 284966) Your Petitioners would welcome and, so far as it may be in their power, cooperate with the authorities in carrying out, any measures of quarantine adopted to guard the Colony against the introduction of infectious disease into it.
('2', 115, 1, 4, 285197) Your Petitioners, however, venture to submit that the present Bill is simply a part of the anti Indian policy, and against it as such your Petitioners feel it their duty to enter their respectful protest.
('2', 115, 1, 5, 285402) Your Petitioners venture to think that such a measure in a British Colony would give an opportunity to those Powers, which are jealous of the British power and trade, to justify the vexatious quarantine rules that they are adopting.
('2', 115, 1, 6, 285635) As to the Trading Licences Bill, your Petitioners welcome it so far as it is meant to teach the communities residing in the Colony to keep their premises in a good sanitary condition and to provide proper accommodation for their clerks and servants.
('2', 115, 1, 7, 285885) But your Petitioners most earnestly though respectfully protest against the discretion being given to the Licensing Officer to refuse or grant a licence “at his own will” and, more especially, against the clause which gives the final power to the Colonial Secretary or the Town Councils or Town Boards, as the case may be.
('2', 115, 1, 8, 286208) These clauses, your Petitioners are afraid, show most clearly that the Bill is to operate against the Indian community alone.
('2', 115, 1, 9, 286334) To deny a subject the right to appeal to the highest tribunal of justice against the decisions of persons or bodies who are not unoften guided and carried away by popular feelings or prejudice would be deemed to be an arbitrary measure in any part of the civilized world; in the British Dominions, an insult to the British name and its Constitution which is rightly termed the purest in the world.
('2', 115, 1, 10, 286732) Nothing, your Petitioners submit, can be more disastrous to the stability of British Rule and the feeling of security that the meanest of Her Majesty’s subjects enjoy, than anything that takes away the right of the subject to ventilate his grievance, supposed or real, before the highest tribunals of justice in the British Dominions, which have, under the severest trials, vindicated their fame for absolute impartiality.
('2', 115, 1, 11, 287155) Your Petitioners, therefore, humbly submit that, no matter what this Honourable House decides with regard to the Bills, it will unanimously reject the clause under consideration.
('2', 116, 0, 1, 287334) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 117
('2', 116, 1, 2, 287376) The clause 1 in the Immigration Restriction Bill, with regard to the form to be filled in European characters makes it a class Bill and the requirement is, in your Petitioners’ humble opinion, unjust to the Indian community.
('2', 116, 1, 3, 287601) In the interests of the present Indian population, your Petitioners submit that the clause requires amending.
('2', 116, 1, 4, 287711) For most of the well to do Indians draw upon India for domestic servants who retire at the end of a certain number of years and are replaced by others.
('2', 116, 1, 5, 287863) That process does not add to the number of Indians in the Colony and yet is beneficial to the Indians.
('2', 116, 1, 6, 287966) Such servants could not possibly know English or any other European language.
('2', 116, 1, 7, 288044) They do not come into competition with the Europeans in any way whatever.
('2', 116, 1, 8, 288118) Your Petitioners, therefore, submit that for this, if for no other reason, the clause should be altered so as not to affect the Indians of that class.
('2', 116, 1, 9, 288269) The £25 clause is also objectionable on the same principle.
('2', 116, 1, 10, 288329) 2 Your Petitioners submit that the interests of the present Indian population of the Colony should, in such matters at any rate, be sympathetically considered.
('2', 116, 2, 11, 288489) As to the Bill for the protection of Uncovenanted Indians, 3 your Petitioners are deeply thankful to the Government for their good intentions, especially because the bill owes its origin to a certain correspondence between the Government and certain members of the Indian community with reference to the matter.
('2', 116, 2, 12, 288801) But the effect of the favour done by the Government will be absolutely neutralized by the 5th clause 4 which exempts those who may arrest free Indians, not having the pass mentioned in the 2nd clause, from liability to action for damages for wrongful arrest.
('2', 116, 2, 13, 289060) It was only when an officer showed

('2', 119, 8, 15, 295683) It has to be carried on the person, a thing that is not always easy to do.
('2', 119, 8, 16, 295758) Instances are on record when Indians not far from their homes have been arrested for being without a pass and put to a great deal of annoyance.
('2', 119, 8, 17, 295902) Such cases, if the fifth clause of the Bill is to remain, are

('2', 120, 3, 8, 297048) 17. CIRCULAR LETTER 1
('2', 120, 4, 9, 297070) WEST STREET, DURBAN (NATAL), March 27, 1897 2
('2', 120, 6, 10, 297116) We the undersigned, representing the Indian community in Natal, hereby request the favour of your giving attention to the memorial herewith enclosed, addressed to the Right Honourable Mr. Joseph Chamberlain, which deals with the now all absorbing Indian question in Natal.
('2', 120, 6, 11, 297389) It is our sincere hope that the importance of the subject will fully compensate for its length and that, therefore, it will not deter you from perusing the memorial.
('2', 120, 6, 12, 297555) The Indian question in this Colony has reached the critical point.
('2', 120, 6, 13, 297622) It affects not only Her Majesty’s Indian subjects residing in the Colony, but the whole population of India.
('2', 120, 6, 14, 297731) It is preeminently Imperial in its aspect.
('2', 120, 6, 15, 297774) “May they or may they not,” as The Times puts it, “go freely from one British possession to another, and claim the rights of British subjects in allied States?” European Natal says they shall not, so far as she is concerned.
('2', 120, 6, 16, 297999) The memorial discloses a sad tale of oppression because of this attitude of Natal.
('2', 120, 7, 17, 298082) 1 Printed copies of this, under the title "The Position of Indians in Natal" were evidently sent to a number of public men in England along with a copy of the Memorial to the Secretary of State for the Colonies on March 15. 2 The letter was actually despatched after the Memorial it forwarded had been submitted to the Natal Governor on April 6.
('2', 121, 0, 1, 298428) 122 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 121, 1, 2, 298470) There is shortly to be a Conference of Premiers of the British Colonies, in London, where the question how far, if at all, the Colonies will be allowed to legislate to the prejudice of the Indians without such legislation applying to the Europeans, is to be discussed by Mr. Chamberlain with the Premiers.
('2', 121, 1, 3, 298776) It, therefore, becomes necessary for us to lay before you briefly our position in Natal.
('2', 121, 1, 4, 298865) The following are some of the legal disabilities the Indians at present labour under in the Colony:
('2', 121, 2, 5, 298965) 1. The Indians, unlike Europeans, cannot be out after 9 p.m., unless, practically, they can produce a pass.
('2', 121, 3, 6, 299073) 2. Any Indian is liable to arrest at any time of the day unless he can show a pass to the effect that he is a free Indian.
('2', 121, 3, 7, 299196) (The complaint herein is particularly against the manner in which the law is applied.)
('2', 121, 4, 8, 299283) 3. Indians, unlike Europeans, when driving cattle must be provided with certain passes.
('2', 121, 5, 9, 299371) 4. A bye law in Durban provides for the registration of native servants and Indian servants who are described as “others belonging to the uncivilized races of Asia”.
('2', 121, 6, 10, 299537) 5. An indentured Indian, when he becomes free, must either return to India, his passage being paid for him, or pay an annual poll tax of £3 as the price of permission to live as a somewhat free man in the Colony.
('2', 121, 6, 11, 299750) (The London Times describes this condition as one “perilously near to slavery”.)
('2', 121, 7, 12, 299831) 6. Indians, unlike Europeans, in order to be entitled to the Franchise must prove that they belong to a country “possessing elective representative institutions founded on the Parliamentary Franchise,” 1 or, must receive an order of exemption from the Governor in Council.
('2', 121, 7, 13, 300104) (This law was passed last year after the Indians had been in possession of the Franchise right under the General Franchise law of the Colony till then, and that law requires that the candidate voter being an adult male, and not being a native of South Africa, must possess immovable property worth £50, or must be paying an annual rental of £10.)
('2', 121, 8, 14, 300451) 1 Vide ”Memorial to Natal Legislative Assembly”, 27 4 1896 and Memorial to J. Chamberlain”, 22 5 1896.
('2', 122, 0, 1, 300554) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 123
('2', 122, 1, 2, 300596) 7. The Government High Schools are closed against Indian students, no matter what their abilities, character and standing.
('2', 122, 2, 3, 300719) The following is the statement of legislation to be passed during the present session of the local Parliament:
('2', 122, 3, 4, 300830) 1. The Governor is to receive the power to refuse to allow any person coming from an infected port to land at all in the Colony, even though such person may have trans shipped at some other port.
('2', 122, 3, 5, 301026) 1 (The Premier, in moving the second reading of this Bill, said that it would enable the Natal Government to arrest the immigration of free Indians to the Colony.)
('2', 122, 4, 6, 301190) 2. The Town Councils and the Town Boards are to be empowered to refuse or grant trading licences at their discretion, 2 their decisions not being subject to review by the highest tribunal of justice in the land.
('2', 122, 4, 7, 301402) (The Premier, in moving the second reading of this Bill, said that such power was to be given so that the trading licences may be withheld from the Indians.)
('2', 122, 5, 8, 301560) 3. Immigrants are to be required to fulfil certain conditions, e.g., to have property worth £25, 3 to be able to fill in a form in some European language, the unwritten understanding, according to the Premier, being that these conditions are not to be enforced against the Europeans.
('2', 122, 5, 9, 301844) (The Government have stated that these measures would be temporary and that, after the Conference hereinbefore referred to, they may be able to bring in such Bills as would apply to Indians or Asiatics exclusively and thus admit of more drastic restrictions and dispense with mental reservations and partial operation.)
('2', 122, 6, 10, 302164) 4. A pass system is to be established in order to protect free Indians from the unpleasantness of an arrest, and officers arresting Indians without passes are to be exempt from liability
('2', 122, 7, 11, 302351) 1 Quarantine Law; vide "Memorial to Secretary of State for the Colonies", 15 3 1897. 2 Vide “Petition to the Secretary of State for the Colonies”, 2 7 1897, Appendix D. 3 The provision regarding the property qualification was later replaced by a clause, Section 3(b), which disqualified "paupers"; vide “Petition to the Secretary of State for the Colonies”, 2 7 1897, Appendix B.
('2', 123, 0, 1, 302731) 124 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 123, 1, 2, 302773) to answer any claim for wrongful arrest.
('2', 123, 1, 3, 302814) 1 The following proposals for further anti Indian legislation have been laid before the Natal Government:
('2', 123, 2, 4, 302920) 1. The Indians should not own landed property.
('2', 123, 2, 5, 302967) 2. Town Councils should be empowered to compel Indians to reside in prescribed locations.
('2', 123, 3, 6, 303057) According to the present Premier, Indians in Natal must for ever be and remain “hewers of wood and drawers of water” and that “they must not form part of the South African nation which is going to be built up”.
('2', 123, 3, 7, 303268) We may state that the prosperity of Natal is admitted to depend mainly upon indentured labour from India, and yet it is Natal which denies freedom to the Indian settler.
('2', 123, 3, 8, 303438) Such is, moreover, the position of the Indians, more or less, throughout South Africa.
('2', 123, 3, 9, 303525) If the Indians are to be denied freedom of intercourse with the British Dominions and allied States, there will be an end to Indian enterprise.
('2', 123, 3, 10, 303669) Just when, as The Times says, Indians, setting aside their long cherished prejudices, are beginning to show an inclination to emigrate for purposes of trade, etc., the Colonies are endeavouring to shut them out.
('2', 123, 3, 11, 303881) If this is allowed by the Home Government, and, therefore, by the Imperial Parliament, it will, in our humble opinion, be a grave infringement of the gracious Proclamation of 1858, and would deal a death blow to Imperial federation, unless the Indian Empire is outside its pale.
('2', 123, 3, 12, 304160) We venture to think that the above facts by themselves are sufficient to induce you to extend your unreserved support to our cause.
('2', 123, 4, 13, 304292) We remain,
('2', 123, 6, 14, 304303) Your obedient servants, ABDUL CARIM HAJEE ADAM (DADA ABDOOLLA & CO.) AND FORTY OTHERS

('2', 129, 0, 1, 311119) 130 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 129, 1, 2, 311161) 25. LETTER TO “THE NATAL MERCURY” 1
('2', 129, 2, 3, 311197) DURBAN, April 13, 1897
('2', 129, 3, 4, 311220) THE EDITOR, The Natal Mercury
('2', 129, 5, 5, 311250) As this will be my first contribution after my return from India, on the Indian question, and a great deal has been said about me, much as I would like to avoid it, it seems to be necessary that I should say a few words on the matter.
('2', 129, 5, 6, 311485) The following charges have been laid against me: (1) That I blackened the character of the Colonists in India, and made many mis statements; 2 (2) that there is an organization under me to swamp the Colony with Indians; 3 (3) that I incited the passengers on board the Courland and Naderi to bring an action against the Government for damages for illegal detention; 4 (4) that I have political ambition, and the work I am doing is done in order to fill my pocket.
('2', 129, 5, 7, 311949) As for the first charge, I believe I need not say anything since you have absolved me from it.
('2', 129, 5, 8, 312044) 5 I venture, however, to deny formally that I ever did anything to merit it.
('2', 129, 5, 9, 312121) As to the second, I repeat what I have said elsewhere: that I have no connection with any organization, nor, so far as I know, is there any organization to swamp the Colony with Indians.
('2', 129, 5, 10, 312308) As to the third, I have denied and again deny most emphatically that I incited a single passenger to bring an action for damages against the Government.
('2', 129, 5, 11, 312461) As to the fourth, I may state that I have no political ambition whatever.
('2', 129, 5, 12, 312535) Those who know me personally know well in what direction my ambition lies.
('2', 129, 5, 13, 312610) I do not aspire to any Parliamentary honours whatever, and, though three opportunities passed by, I deliberately refrained from getting myself placed on the Voters’ List.
('2', 129, 5, 14, 312781) I receive no remuneration for the public work that I am doing.
('2', 129, 5, 15, 312844) If the European Colonists can believe me, I beg to assure them
('2', 129, 6, 16, 312907) 1 This appeared under the title "The Indian Question".
('2', 129, 6, 17, 312962) 2 The reference is to alleged mis statements in the Green Pamphlet.
('2', 129, 6, 18, 313030) 3 Vide “Letter to The Natal Mercury”, 13 11 1897. 4 Vide “Interview to The Natal Advertiser”, 13 1 1897, and “Memorial to Secretary of State for the Colonies”, 15 3 1897. 5 Vide “Memorial to Secretary of State for the Colonies”, 15 3 1897, Appendix Y.
('2', 130, 0, 1, 313282) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 131
('2', 130, 1, 2, 313324) that I am here not to sow dissensions between the two communities, but to endeavour to bring about an honourable reconciliation between them.
('2', 130, 1, 3, 313466) In my humble opinion, much of the ill feeling that exists between the two communities is due to misunderstanding of each other’s feelings and actions.
('2', 130, 1, 4, 313617) My office, therefore, is that of an humble interpreter between them.
('2', 130, 1, 5, 313686) I have been taught to believe that Britain and India can remain together for any length of time only if there is a common fellow feeling between the two peoples.
('2', 130, 1, 6, 313848) The greatest minds in the British Isles and India are striving to meet that ideal.
('2', 130, 1, 7, 313931) I am but humbly following in their footsteps, and feel that the present action of the Europeans in Natal is calculated to retard, if not altogether to frustrate, its realization.
('2', 130, 1, 8, 314110) I feel, further, that such action is not based on good grounds, but rests on popular prejudice and preconceived notions.
('2', 130, 1, 9, 314231) Such being the case, I venture to trust that, however much the European Colonists may differ from the above opinion, they would be gracious enough to show a spirit of toleration thereof.
('2', 130, 2, 10, 314418) There are several Bills 1 before the Natal Parliament prejudicially affecting the interests of the Indians.
('2', 130, 2, 11, 314526) They are not supposed to represent final legislation with regard to the Indians, but the Honourable the Prime Minister has stated that more stringent measures may be adopted after the forthcoming Conference of the Colonial Premiers has taken place.
('2', 130, 2, 12, 314775) This is a gloomy outlook for the Indians, and if, in order to avert it, they put forth all the legitimate resources at their disposal, I venture to think that they should not be blamed.
('2', 130, 2, 13, 314961) It seems that everything is being hurried on as if there was any danger of thousands of Indians of all sorts and conditions pouring into Natal.
('2', 130, 2, 14, 315105) 2 I submit that there is no such danger and the late quarantine would serve as an effective check, if there was any.
('2', 130, 2, 15, 315222) The suggestion that there should be an inquiry as to whether the Indian is an evil or a benefit to the Colony has been pooh poohed and an opinion expressed that he who has eyes can see how the Indians are ousting the Europeans in every direction.
('2', 130, 2, 16, 315469) With deference, I beg to differ.
('2', 130, 2, 17, 315502) The thousands of free Indians, apart from the indentured, who have developed the large estates in Natal and given them a value, and turned them from jungles into productive soil, I am sure you will not
('2', 130, 3, 18, 315704) 1 The Quarantine, Dealers' Licences, Immigration Restriction and Protection of Uncovenanted Indians Bills 2 Speaking in Parliament on March 27, the Natal Premier had referred to a systematic plan to overrun the country with free Indian immigrants.
('2', 131, 0, 1, 315952) 132 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 131, 1, 2, 315994) call an evil to the Colony.
('2', 131, 1, 3, 316022) They have not ousted any Europeans; on the contrary, they have brought them prosperity and considerably increased the general wealth of the Colony.
('2', 131, 1, 4, 316170) Will the Europeans—can they?
('2', 131, 1, 5, 316199) —perform the work done by those Indians?
('2', 131, 1, 6, 316240) Have not the Indians very much helped to make this the Garden Colony of South Africa?
('2', 131, 1, 7, 316326) When there were no free Indians, a cauliflower sold at half a crown; now, even the poorest can buy it.
('2', 131, 1, 8, 316429) Is this a curse?
('2', 131, 1, 9, 316446) Has the working man been injured in any way thereby?
('2', 131, 1, 10, 316499) The Indian traders are said to “have eaten into the very vitals of the Colony”.
('2', 131, 1, 11, 316579) Is it so?
('2', 131, 1, 12, 316589) They have made it possible for the European firms to extend their business in the way they have done.
('2', 131, 1, 13, 316691) And these firms, because of this extension, can find employment for hundreds of European clerks and book keepers.
('2', 131, 1, 14, 316805) The Indian traders act as middlemen.
('2', 131, 1, 15, 316842) They begin where the Europeans leave.
('2', 131, 1, 16, 316880) It is not to be denied that they can live cheaper than Europeans; but that is a benefit to the Colony.
('2', 131, 1, 17, 316983) They buy wholesale from European stores, and can sell with a trifling addition to the wholesale prices, and are thus a benefit to the poor Europeans.
('2', 131, 1, 18, 317133) It might be said in answer to this that the work now done by the Indian storekeepers could be done by Europeans.
('2', 131, 1, 19, 317246) This is a fallacy.
('2', 131, 1, 20, 317265) The very Europeans who are now wholesale dealers would be retail dealers but for the presence of the Indian storekeepers, except in isolated instances.
('2', 131, 1, 21, 317417) The Indian storekeepers have, therefore, raised the Europeans a stage higher.
('2', 131, 1, 22, 317495) It has, further, been said that, in time to come, Indians may usurp the wholesale trade also from the Europeans.
('2', 131, 1, 23, 317608) This supposition is not borne out by facts, because the wholesale prices in Indian and European stores are, if not exactly, almost the same, thus showing the competition in the wholesale lines cannot by any means be said to be unfair.
('2', 131, 1, 24, 317843) The cheaper living of the Indian is not an important factor in determining the wholesale price, because the cheaper living of the one is counterbalanced by the more methodical business habits and the mercantile “home connections” of the other.
('2', 131, 1, 25, 318087) It is objected, on the one hand, that the Indians buy landed property in Natal and, on the other, that their money does not circulate in the Colony but goes to India, because “they wear no boots, no European made clothing, and send their earnings to India”, thus constituting a terrible drain on the Colony.
('2', 131, 1, 26, 318395) These two objections completely answer each other.
('2', 131, 1, 27, 318446) Assuming that the Indians wear no boots and European made clothing, they do not send the money thus saved to India, but invest it in buying landed property.
('2', 131, 1, 28, 318603) What, therefore, they earn with one hand in the Colony they spend with the
('2', 132, 0, 1, 318678) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 133
('2', 132, 1, 2, 318720) All, then, that the Indians send to India can only be a portion of the interest in the shape of rents received from such property.
('2', 132, 1, 3, 318851) The purchase of landed property by the Indians is a double benefit.
('2', 132, 1, 4, 318919) It increase the value of land, and gives work to the European builders, carpenters, and other artisans.
('2', 132, 1, 5, 319023) It is a mere chimera to say that European workmen have anything whatever to fear from the Indian community.
('2', 132, 1, 6, 319131) There is absolutely no competition between the European artisans and the Indian, of whom there are very few, and the few are indifferent workmen.
('2', 132, 1, 7, 319277) A project to import Indian artisans to construct an Indian building in Durban failed.
('2', 132, 1, 8, 319363) No good Indian artisans would come to the Colony.
('2', 132, 1, 9, 319413) I do not know of many Indian buildings which have been constructed by Indian artisans.
('2', 132, 1, 10, 319500) There is a natural division of work in the Colony, without any community encroaching upon the work of the other.
('2', 132, 2, 11, 319613) If there is any reason whatever in the views put forward above, I beg to submit that legislative interference is unjustifiable.
('2', 132, 2, 12, 319741) The law of supply and demand will naturally regulate the supply of free Indians.
('2', 132, 2, 13, 319822) After all, if the Indian is really a canker, the more dignified course, since it has been admitted that the Indians can thrive because of the European support, will be that such support should be withdrawn.
('2', 132, 2, 14, 320029) The Indians, then, may fret awhile, but cannot legitimately complain.
('2', 132, 2, 15, 320099) But it should appear unfair to anybody that legislation should interfere with the supported on the complaint of the supporters.
('2', 132, 2, 16, 320227) All, however, I venture to claim on the strength of the above argument is that there is sufficient in it to justify the inquiry hereinbefore suggested.
('2', 132, 2, 17, 320379) No doubt there would be the other side of the question.
('2', 132, 2, 18, 320435) If there was an inquiry, both sides could thoroughly be thrashed out and an unbiased judgment obtained.
('2', 132, 2, 19, 320539) Then there would be some good material for our legislators to go on with and for Mr. Chamberlain to guide him.
('2', 132, 2, 20, 320650) The opinion pronounced 10 years ago by a Commission of Inquiry, consisting of Sir Walter Wragg and other Commissioners, is that the free Indian is a benefit to the Colony.
('2', 132, 2, 21, 320822) 1 That is the only reliable material at present before the legislators, unless it is proved that the conditions during the last 10 years have so far changed as to prevent them from accepting that opinion.
('2', 132, 2, 22, 321027) These, however, are local considerations.
('2', 132, 2, 23, 321069) Why should not Imperial considerations also guide the
('2', 132, 3, 24, 321123) 1 For the findings of the Indian Immigrants Commission, vide “Memorial to Secretary of State for the Colonies”, 15 3 1897, also “The Indian Franchise”, 16 12 1895, Part VI.
('2', 133, 0, 1, 321296) 134 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 133, 1, 2, 321338) Colonist?
('2', 133, 1, 3, 321348) And if they should, then, in the eye of the law, the Indian is to have the same rights as all other British subjects.
('2', 133, 1, 4, 321466) India benefits hundreds of thousands of Europeans; India makes the British Empire; India gives an unrivalled prestige to England; India has often fought for England.
('2', 133, 1, 5, 321632) Is it fair that European subjects of that Empire in this Colony, who themselves derive a considerable benefit from Indian labour, should object to the free Indians earning an honest livelihood in it?
('2', 133, 1, 6, 321832) You have said that the Indians want social equality with the Europeans; I confess I do not quite understand the phrase; but I know that the Indians have never asked Mr. Chamberlain to regulate the social relations between the two communities; and so long as the manners, customs, habits, and religions of the two communities differ, there will, naturally, be a social distinction.
('2', 133, 1, 7, 322213) What the Indians fail to understand is, why that difference should come in the way of the two living cordially and harmoniously in any part of the world without the Indians having to accept a degradation of their status in the eye of the law.
('2', 133, 1, 8, 322456) If the sanitary habits of the Indian are not quite what they ought to be, the Sanitary Department can, by strict vigilance, effect the needed improvement.
('2', 133, 1, 9, 322611) If Indians have not got decent looking stores, licensing authorities can soon turn them into decent looking ones.
('2', 133, 1, 10, 322725) These things can only be done when European Colonist, as Christians, look upon the Indians as brethren, or, as British subjects, look upon them as fellow subjects.
('2', 133, 1, 11, 322889) Then, instead of cursing and swearing at the Indians as now, they would help them to remove any defects that there may be in them, and thus raise them and themselves also in the estimation of the world.
('2', 133, 2, 12, 323092) I appeal to the Demonstration Committee 1 , who are supposed more particularly to represent the working men.
('2', 133, 2, 13, 323201) They now know that the Courland and Naderi did not bring 800 passengers for Natal, and that, in what they did bring, [there] was not a single Indian artisan.
('2', 133, 3, 14, 323359) there is no attempt on the part of the Indians “to put the Europeans in the kitchen, and to become masters themselves’.
('2', 133, 3, 15, 323479) 3 The European working man can have no complaint against the Indian.
('2', 133, 3, 16, 323548) Under the circumstances, in my humble opinion, it behoves them to reconsider their position and direct the energy at their disposal in such channels that all sections of Her Majesty’s subjects in the Colony may live in
('2', 133, 4, 17, 323767) 1 Vide “Interview to The Natal Advertiser”, 13 1 1897. 2 ibid 3 Vide “Memorial to Secretary of State for the Colonies”, 15 3 1897.
('2', 134, 0, 1, 323898) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 135
('2', 134, 1, 2, 323940) harmony and peace, instead of under a state of excitement and friction.
('2', 134, 1, 3, 324012) Information has appeared in the papers that a gentleman is shortly to proceed to England on behalf of the Indians and the evidence against the Colony is being collected.
('2', 134, 1, 4, 324182) In order that there may be no misunderstanding about the matter, I may state that, in view of the approaching Conference, a gentleman is going to London on behalf of the Indian community in South Africa, to place the Indian side of the question before their sympathizers and the general public, as also, if necessary, Mr. Chamberlain.
('2', 134, 1, 5, 324517) 1 He is to receive no remuneration for his services but passage and expenses.
('2', 134, 1, 6, 324595) The statement that evidence is being collected against the Colony is very ugly and, unless it were true, could only be made by a person writing under an assumed name.
('2', 134, 1, 7, 324762) The gentleman in question will certainly be put in possession of all the information about the Indian question in South Africa, but that appears in the papers already published.
('2', 134, 1, 8, 324940) The Indians never have wished, and do not now wish, to make out a charge of brutality or general bodily ill treatment by the Europeans towards them.
('2', 134, 1, 9, 325089) Nor do they wish to make out that the treatment of the indentured Indians in Natal is worse than elsewhere.
('2', 134, 1, 10, 325197) Therefore, if collecting evidence against the Colony is meant to convey some such impression, it is a groundless statement.
('2', 134, 1, 11, 325321) Your, etc., M. K. GANDHI

('2', 138, 1, 2, 331082) 29. ADDRESS TO QUEEN VICTORIA 1
('2', 138, 2, 3, 331114) [Before May 21, 1897] 2
('2', 138, 3, 4, 331138) In token of our joy at the approaching completion of the 60th year of your glorious and beneficent reign, we are proud to think that we are your subjects, the more so as we know that the peace we enjoy in India, and the confidence of security of life and prosperity which enables us to venture abroad, are due to that position.
('2', 138, 3, 5, 331466) We can but re echo the sentiments of loyalty and devotion which are finding expression among all your subjects and in all parts of your vast dominions on which the sun never sets.
('2', 138, 3, 6, 331646) That the God Almighty may spare you in health and vigour for a long time to come to reign over us, is our devout wish and prayer.

('2', 138, 5, 8, 331804) 30. LETTER TO ADAMJI MIYAKHAN
('2', 138, 6, 9, 331834) TRANSVAAL HOTEL, PRETORIA, May 21, 1897
('2', 138, 7, 10, 331874) DEAR MR. ADAMJI MIYAKHAN 3 ,
('2', 138, 8, 11, 331903) I hope you have made the necessary arrangements for the address to Her Majesty the Queen.
('2', 138, 8, 12, 331993) 4 If it has not been already printed or engraved, please put in the following superscription.

('2', 142, 1, 2, 336952) 35. PETITION TO SECRETARY OF STATE FOR
('2', 142, 2, 3, 336991) THE COLONIES
('2', 142, 3, 4, 337004) DURBAN, July 2, 1897
('2', 142, 4, 5, 337025) TO THE RIGHT HONOURABLE JOSEPH CHAMBERLAIN HER MAJESTY’S PRINCIPAL SECRETARY OF STATE FOR THE COLONIES
('2', 142, 6, 6, 337128) THE PETITION OF THE UNDERSIGNED BRITISH INDIANS REPRESENTING THE INDIAN COMMUNITY IN NATAL
('2', 142, 7, 7, 337219) HUMBLY SHEWETH:
('2', 142, 8, 8, 337235) That your Petitioners hereby respectfully venture to approach you with reference to four Indian Bills passed by the Honourable the Legislative Assembly and the Honourable the Legislative Council of the Colony of Natal and which, having received the Governor’s assent, have been gazetted as Acts.
('2', 142, 8, 9, 337531) These Bills were, in the order in which they were passed respectively: the Quarantine Bill, the Immigration Restriction Bill, the Trade Licences Bill, and the Bill to protect the Uncovenanted Indians from liability to arrest.
('2', 142, 8, 10, 337757) Your Petitioners alluded to the first three Bills 1 in their last memorial and said therein that, if these Bills passed the Natal Legislatures, they might have to approach you again with special reference thereto.
('2', 142, 8, 11, 337971) It has now become your Petitioners’ unfortunate duty so to do, and they confidently trust they would be excused for the trouble they have to give you, seeing that the question underlying these Bills touches the very existence of the Indian community in Natal.
('2', 142, 8, 12, 338231) As soon as the last two of these Bills were gazetted as Acts, your petitioners wrote to the Honourable the Colonial Secretary 2 praying that the despatch of the Bills to Her Majesty’s Government should be postponed till the receipt hereof; a reply from the Honourable the Colonial Secretary was received to the effect that the Bills had already
('2', 142, 9, 13, 338576) 1 Of March 15; vide “Memorial to Secretary of State for the Colonies”, 15 3 1897. 2 Vide “Letter to Natal Colonial Secretary”, 2 6 1897.
('2', 143, 0, 1, 338713) 144 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 143, 1, 2, 338755) been forwarded.
('2', 143, 1, 3, 338771) Thereupon, the following humble telegram 1 was sent to you:
('2', 143, 2, 4, 338831) Indian Bills mentioned last memorial Gazetted Acts.
('2', 143, 2, 5, 338883) We humbly request deferring consideration.
('2', 143, 2, 6, 338926) Memorial preparing.
('2', 143, 2, 7, 338946) Copies of the four Bills mentioned are appended hereto, and marked A, B, C and D respectively.
('2', 143, 2, 8, 339041) Your petitioners ventured to approach both the Houses of the local Parliament with reference to these Bills, 2 without avail.
('2', 143, 2, 9, 339167) Copy of the petition to the Honourable the Legislative Assembly is annexed herewith and marked E 3. It endeavours to show that restrictive legislation for Indians is not warranted by the circumstances and, therefore, that before embarking upon such legislation a census should be ordered to be taken of the total Indian population of the Colony and inquiry instituted as to whether the presence of the Indian in the Colony is a benefit or an evil to the Colony.
('2', 143, 2, 10, 339629) The Quarantine Bill gives the power to the Governor not only to return any ship coming from infected ports without allowing her to land her passengers and cargo, but also prevent any person coming, in the first instance, from an infected port from landing in Natal, even though such person may have transshipped into some other boat on his way to Natal.
('2', 143, 2, 11, 339983) Your petitioners can have no objection against any Quarantine Law, no matter how severe, so long as it is meant as a protection against the introduction of infectious diseases.
('2', 143, 2, 12, 340160) But the present Bill is merely a part of the anti Indian policy of the Natal Government.
('2', 143, 2, 13, 340249) As has been pointed out in the anti Indian Demonstration Memorial, the Natal Government made a promise to the Demonstration Committee that a Bill to extend the Governor’s powers of imposing quarantine was under consideration.
('2', 143, 2, 14, 340475) 4 The present Bill has been looked upon as one of the Indian Bills of the session; thus, says The Natal Mercury, 24th February 1897, with reference to the Quarantine and other Indian Bills:
('2', 143, 3, 15, 340665) The first three Bills published in the Gazette this week are in fulfilment of the promise of the Government that measures to deal with the question of Indian immigration would be introduced during the forthcoming session of
('2', 143, 4, 16, 340889) 1 Vide “Cable to Chamberlain, Hunter and Others”, 9 6 1897. 2 ibid.
('2', 143, 4, 17, 340957) 3 This is not reproduced as an appendix to the petition; for the text of the petition to the Natal Legislative Assembly, vide “Petition to Natal Legislative Assembly”, 26 3 1897. 4 Vide “Memorial to Secretary of State for the Colonies”, 15 3 1897.
('2', 144, 0, 1, 341205) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 145
('2', 144, 1, 2, 341247) Parliament.
('2', 144, 1, 3, 341259) None of the Bills specifically relates to Asiatics and, therefore, [they] do not come under the suspensory conditions attached to such measures.
('2', 144, 1, 4, 341404) They have been drafted to apply to all and sundry and certainly no fault can be found with their comprehensive character.
('2', 144, 1, 5, 341526) It may be frankly admitted that the Bills are more or less of an objectionable character, but desperate diseases require desperate remedies.
('2', 144, 1, 6, 341667) It is to be regretted that such measures are necessary, but that they are necessary is beyond dispute, and however disagreeable it may be to pass such legislation, it has been an imperative duty and must be undertaken.
('2', 144, 1, 7, 341886) The Bill to amend the laws relating to quarantine may be fairly termed an extraordinary measure of precaution taken in the face of plague stricken countries.
('2', 144, 1, 8, 342044) Something more than the ordinary measures are necessary if we are to secure immunity from dread diseases.
('2', 144, 1, 9, 342150) The same paper, in answering the objections to the Immigration Restriction Bill, says again in a leading article dated 30th March, 1897:
('2', 144, 2, 10, 342287) It has been urged by those people who consider the Bill (i.e., the Immigration Restriction Bill) objectionable because it is not straightforward, that a Bill should be passed against Asiatics in particular, that we should enter upon the “long constitutional fight”, and, in the mean time, we should protect ourselves with the Quarantine Act; the inconsistency of such a course is very apparent.
('2', 144, 2, 11, 342682) It would imply that we were much too high minded to be dishonest with regard to the Immigration Bill, but we had not the slightest objection to take a mean advantage of the provisions of the Quarantine Bill.
('2', 144, 2, 12, 342890) To prevent the landing of Indian immigrants in Natal, on the ground that they came from a country infected with dangerous infectious disease within a thousand miles of the district they come from, is just as disingenuous as the operations under the Immigration Restriction Bill.
('2', 144, 2, 13, 343169) It is, then, because the Quarantine Bill is intended indirectly to prevent Indian immigration to Natal that your Petitioners deem it necessary to enter their respectful protest against it.
('2', 144, 2, 14, 343358) For, why should an Indian, trans shipping into a German liner at Zanzibar bound for Natal, be prevented from landing there while other passengers may do so without difficulty?
('2', 144, 2, 15, 343534) If an Indian is likely to bring an infectious disease into the Colony, so are the other passengers who have come into contact with him.
('2', 144, 2, 16, 343670) The Immigration Restriction Bill provides, among other things, that any person who is a pauper and is likely to become a public charge, and cannot write out an application to the Colonial Secretary according to the form given as a schedule to the Bill, shall be treated as a prohibited immigrant.
('2', 144, 2, 17, 343967) Thus, an Indian, who is learned in any of
('2', 145, 0, 1, 344009) 146 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 145, 1, 2, 344051) the Indian languages, but does not know any European language, cannot land in Natal even though it be temporarily.
('2', 145, 1, 3, 344166) Such an Indian may go to the Transvaal, a foreign territory, but may not set his foot on the Natal soil, Even in the Orange Free State, any Indian may remain for two months without having to undergo any ceremony, but he may not do so in the British Colony of Natal.
('2', 145, 1, 4, 344432) This is, therefore, going further than either of the above independent States.
('2', 145, 1, 5, 344511) If an Indian Prince wanted to travel round the world and came upon Natal, he would not be allowed to land there unless special permission was accorded to him.
('2', 145, 1, 6, 344670) Ships on their way to Mauritius, having Indian passengers, have been calling here after the Immigration Law came into operation, and the Indian passengers are not even allowed to land and have exercise or fresh air while the ships are at anchor.
('2', 145, 1, 7, 344916) By order of the Immigration Department they are kept under strict supervision, and their luggage is stored away in the hold lest they should evade the supervision and land.
('2', 145, 1, 8, 345089) In other words, British subjects, because they happen to be Indians, are practically treated as prisoners on the British soil.
('2', 145, 1, 9, 345216) It has been authoritatively stated that no Government would dream of applying the Law to the Europeans in the same manner as the Indians.
('2', 145, 1, 10, 345354) In dealing with the clause 3, sub clause (b) now modified, the Honourable the Prime Minister said as follows, on the second reading of the Bill:
('2', 145, 2, 11, 345499) As to immigrants being in possession of twenty five pounds, when those words were introduced it never occurred to him that it would be applied to the Europeans.
('2', 145, 2, 12, 345660) It could be so applied if the Government were foolish enough.
('2', 145, 2, 13, 345722) The object, however, was to deal with the Asiatics.
('2', 145, 2, 14, 345774) Some people said they liked an honest straightforward course.
('2', 145, 2, 15, 345836) When a ship was heading against a wind, she had to tack, and by and by she accomplished her goal.
('2', 145, 2, 16, 345934) When a man met difficulties, he fought against them, and, if he could not knock them over, he went round them instead of breaking his head against a brick wall.
('2', 145, 2, 17, 346095) The want of straightforwardness about the Bill has appealed to almost everyone in the Colony.
('2', 145, 2, 18, 346189) The Farmers’ Conference at Maritzburg, the capital of the Colony, a meeting held in the Durban Town Hall for the purpose of giving the members of the Borough an opportunity to express their opinion on the Bills, and other meetings protested against it on the ground that it was un British; several members of the Parliament also expressed themselves strongly against it.
('2', 145, 2, 19, 346560) Mr. Binns, the leader of the unformed opposition in the House of Assembly, said:
('2', 146, 0, 1, 346641) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 147
('2', 146, 1, 2, 346683) They ought to guard against taking a purely local view of so serious a question.
('2', 146, 1, 3, 346764) The Bill was not straight.
('2', 146, 1, 4, 346791) It did not go straight to the point, and nothing could be more appropriate than the remark that was made in the petition read that afternoon, that it was un British.
('2', 146, 1, 5, 346957) Nobody liked the Bill.
('2', 146, 1, 6, 346980) There was not a man in all Natal that liked the Bill, and the Premier certainly did not like it.
('2', 146, 1, 7, 347077) He might think that there was a necessity for it, and that the Bill should assume the form it has done.

('2', 146, 2, 9, 347267) Mr. Maydon, another member of the Assembly,
('2', 146, 3, 10, 347311) ventured to strongly express the opinion, and he believed the majority of the Colonists of Natal agreed with him, that rather than accept this measure, they would continue to wallow in the mire of the Asiatic immersion.

('2', 146, 5, 14, 347772) The Bill was a monstrous Bill.

('2', 146, 5, 16, 347896) They did not talk of tacking in these days of steamship, but went straight ahead.
('2', 146, 6, 17, 347978) Thus, seeing that there is no unanimity of opinion about the Bill, your Petitioners submit that their modest prayer that a census should be taken of the Indian population, and an enquiry made as to the allegation that the presence of Indians is an evil to the Colony, might have been complied with before passing such a drastic measure.
('2', 146, 6, 18, 348315) Your Petitioners submit that there was absolutely no justification for the measure.
('2', 146, 6, 19, 348399) It has not been proved that the number of the Indians is more rapidly increasing than the number of Europeans.
('2', 146, 6, 20, 348510) On the other hand, the last report shows that, while there might have been an increase of 666 Indians during the last six months ending January, 1
('2', 146, 7, 21, 348657) the increase in the number of the Europeans was close upon 2,000. Further, the class of the Indians whom the Bill is intended to prevent from coming number about 5,000 in the Colony as against 50,000 Europeans.
('2', 146, 7, 22, 348868) Also, the deliberate opinion of the Commission that sat ten years ago in Natal under the Chairmanship of Sir Walter Wragg, the first Puisne Judge, stands on record, namely:
('2', 146, 8, 23, 349041) 1 Vide “Memorial to Secretary of State for the Colonies”, 15 3 1897.
('2', 147, 0, 1, 349110) 148 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 147, 1, 2, 349152) We are content to place on record our strong opinion based on much observation that the presence of these traders has been beneficial to the whole Colony and it would be unwise if not unjust to legislate to their prejudice.
('2', 147, 1, 3, 349376) This is the only authoritative opinion that the local legislatures could be guided by.
('2', 147, 1, 4, 349463) In the teeth of these facts, your petitioners yet venture to trust that Her Majesty’s Government would order that the inquiry of the nature above indicated be instituted before arriving at a decision as to the necessity of legislation restrictive of the freedom of the British Indians in Natal; that is, if Her Majesty’s Government decide that, in spite of the Proclamation of 1858, a British Colony can legislate to the prejudice of British Indians, and if Her Majesty’s Government come to the conclusion that the Proclamation does not confer any such privileges as are contended for herein, and, if they are satisfied that the number of Indians in Natal is increasing at an alarming rate, and that the presence of the Indians is an evil to the Colony, it would be far more satisfactory that a Bill specially applicable to the Indians should be introduced.
('2', 147, 1, 5, 350321) With the greatest deference, it does seem strange that, while the Transvaal Government have been compelled to withdraw their Aliens Law 1 , the Natal Government have passed an Immigration Act which is far more severe than the Transvaal one.
('2', 147, 1, 6, 350562) Your Petitioners would now crave leave to give extracts from the Press, showing how the Immigration Restriction Act is viewed by the Press:
('2', 147, 2, 7, 350702) Section 4 defines the penalties to which any prohibited immigrant, making his way into the Colony in disregard of the Act, is liable, viz., deportation and (or) six months’ imprisonment.
('2', 147, 2, 8, 350889) Now, we think most people will agree with us that, however necessary it may be for the Colony, for its own benefit, to impose restrictions on immigration, it is not a crime for any person to endeavour to come into the country.
('2', 147, 2, 9, 351116) It is morally certain, too, that the class of persons to whom the Bill applies will, as a rule, be totally ignorant of the fact that, by entering the Colony, they are breaking any of its laws.
('2', 147, 2, 10, 351309) Such a law is in a different position from the ordinary laws of the country, since it applies to people who have no opportunity of making themselves acquainted with its laws.
('2', 147, 2, 11, 351484) It is, moreover, the duty of the officials appointed, therefore, to see that no prohibited immigrants are landed, and under these circumstances we think deportation is sufficient, and penal laws should be eliminated.
('2', 147, 2, 12, 351701) A similar criticism applies to Section 5, which provides
('2', 147, 3, 13, 351758) 1 Vide “Letter to Dadabhai Naoroji and Others”, Before 18 9 1897.
('2', 148, 0, 1, 351824) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 149
('2', 148, 1, 2, 351866) for a deposit of £100 as a sort of guarantee, to be forfeited should the immigrants eventually prove to come under the category of “prohibited immigrants”.
('2', 148, 1, 3, 352022) We see no justice whatever in annexing this deposit.
('2', 148, 1, 4, 352075) If he is treated as a prohibited immigrant and compelled to leave the Colony, his money should be returned.
('2', 148, 1, 5, 352183) The clause imposing heavy penalties on shipmasters is only sure to provoke criticism.
('2', 148, 1, 6, 352269) It virtually imposes upon the captains of vessels the duty, before leaving the port of departure, of a minute examination into the circumstances and position of every one of their passengers.
('2', 148, 1, 7, 352461) This may be necessary for the effectual operation of the law, but it nevertheless inflicts a great hardship upon the masters.
('2', 148, 2, 8, 352587) The Bill, it will be observed, applies to persons entering the Colony by land and sea.
('2', 148, 2, 9, 352674) We are of opinion that it would be much less obnoxious and more easily enforced if it applied to immigrants by sea only.
('2', 148, 2, 10, 352795) There is very little reason to fear any considerable influx of Asiatics by land, and the only other persons are travellers from one South African State to another, who should be as free from restriction as possible, and natives, the greater part of whom would be excluded by the educational tests, possibly to the detriment of our labour supply.—The Natal Advertiser, 24 2 ’97.
('2', 148, 3, 11, 353173) Would it not be a reasonable position to take up to say “If you won’t have the one class, you shan’t have the other?” That this attitude is not an unlikely one is apparent from the tone of the Indian Press.
('2', 148, 3, 12, 353380) We published, a few days ago, an article from The Times of India which practically calls upon Natal to choose between unrestricted immigration or none at all.
('2', 148, 3, 13, 353539) That may be only a local view, but we think we are not far wrong in saying that it is just the sort of answer we should give if the cases were reversed.
('2', 148, 3, 14, 353692) It is not an unfair argument to say that if the Colony finds it necessary for its own benefit to exclude a certain class of Indian immigrants it cannot complain if the Indian Government refuses to allow it to import, also for its own benefit, another class of Indian immigrants.
('2', 148, 3, 15, 353971) —The Natal Advertiser, 5 4 ’97.
('2', 148, 4, 16, 354003) We question whether any Act so drastic in its tendency, and so wide in its scope, has been adopted by any British Colony, and it is no honour to a Colony, which professes such devotion to progress and freedom as ours, to be the first to inscribe such a measure on its statute book.—The Natal Advertiser, 26 2 ’97.
('2', 148, 5, 17, 354317) It may be fairly argued that, having regard to its purpose, it is dishonest and hypocritical in principle, because its real object is not its ostensible object.
('2', 148, 5, 18, 354478) It professes to be a measure to restrict immigration generally, when everybody knows that in reality it is intended to stop Asiatic immigration.— The Natal Advertiser, 26 2’97.
('2', 149, 0, 1, 354655) 150 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 149, 1, 2, 354697) Let us try to get what we want by an honest, fair, and aboveboard measure, which does not seek to hide the real issues under a cloud of vague, unworkable and un English restrictions.
('2', 149, 1, 3, 354880) Until we can do this, there is ample scope for the energies of Government, and the Colonial municipalities in carrying out local regulations which will do a good deal towards minimizing the evil complained of.—The Natal Advertiser, 12 3 ’97.
('2', 149, 2, 4, 355122) The Natal Immigration Law represents one of the most contemptible tricks to which a Government and legislature could be party.—The Star, 20 5 ’97.
('2', 149, 3, 5, 355269) The session of 1897 will be known hereafter as having given birth to that most objectionable law, which in some respects is even worse than the enactment 1 passed by the Transvaal Volksraad last year with a similar object.
('2', 149, 3, 6, 355492) It is within the knowledge of everyone that Mr. Chamberlain protested against the law, and that it was promptly repealed by the Volksraad.
('2', 149, 3, 7, 355631) But it is certain that, if the law is good for Natal, it can scarcely be bad for the Transvaal.—The Transvaal Advertiser, 22 5 ’97.
('2', 149, 4, 8, 355763) The new Natal law is more than a violation of this general principle.
('2', 149, 4, 9, 355833) It is, in addition, a dishonest law, if the contention produced in favour of passing it is to be recognized.
('2', 149, 4, 10, 355942) While its terms are of universal applicability, the Government openly admitted in the Legislature that it would only be applied to certain classes.
('2', 149, 4, 11, 356090) Such a mode of securing class legislation is pernicious in the extreme.
('2', 149, 4, 12, 356162) Class legislation is generally wrong or undesirable; but when a class law is passed in a shape that does not show it is meant for only one section of the community, its inherent faults become greatly intensified.
('2', 149, 4, 13, 356375) It is further an act of cowardice on the part of any Parliament to shirk the consequences that may ensue from the candid adoption of a class measure by resorting to the pretence that a law is not meant to be a class one at all.
('2', 149, 4, 14, 356603) The avowed object of this Natal Immigration Restriction law is to deal with the influx of free Indians; not, be it well marked, with all Indians.
('2', 149, 4, 15, 356749) Indentured ‘coolies’ are to be included in the same category of persons exempt from the operations of this law as, say, the Prince of Wales.
('2', 149, 4, 16, 356890) Yet, as a matter of fact, the indentured coolies brought to Natal largely consist of the very lowest class of natives to be picked out of the gutters of Calcutta and Bombay.
('2', 149, 4, 17, 357064) Man for man, the free Indian coming to Natal at his own expense is likely to be of a better stamp than the destitute coolie shipped across at other people’s expense.
('2', 149, 4, 18, 357230) But this indentured fellow countryman of the lowest caste is to be admitted because he is a bondsman.
('2', 149, 4, 19, 357332) Yet, in five years’ time, the semi slave
('2', 149, 5, 20, 357373) 1 The Transvaal Aliens Act

('2', 150, 1, 2, 357442) thus allowed in can, if he chooses, demand his freedom and settle in Natal as a free Indian.—The Star, 10 5 ’97.
('2', 150, 2, 3, 357555) The Natal Law cannot with any sense of fairness and justice be countenanced by Mr. Chamberlain after the attitude he has taken up towards a much less offensive enactment passed in his State, which is very much less within his ‘sphere of influence’ than Natal.—The Star, 7 5 ’97
('2', 150, 3, 4, 357833) The Dealers’ Licences Bill 1 is, if possible, the worst of all.
('2', 150, 3, 5, 357897) It not only requires that traders should keep their books in English, but gives absolute power to the licensing authorities to refuse to issue or renew licence without the right to the aggrieved party to appeal to the highest tribunal of justice.
('2', 150, 3, 6, 358144) It is thus subversive of one of the most cherished principles of the British Constitution.
('2', 150, 3, 7, 358235) Your Petitioners cannot better express their objections to the Bill than in the words of Mr. Tatham, a member of the Legislative Assembly:
('2', 150, 4, 8, 358374) He had no hesitation in saying that this Bill would establish a
('2', 150, 5, 9, 358438) monopoly in favour of existing traders.
('2', 150, 5, 10, 358478) Members who had discussed the Bill
('2', 150, 6, 11, 358513) discussed from the point of view of the trader apart from the point of view of
('2', 150, 7, 12, 358592) the consumer.
('2', 150, 7, 13, 358606) One of the most disastrous courses which legislation could take
('2', 150, 8, 14, 358670) was a course which had for its object the restraint of trade, and so far was this
('2', 150, 9, 15, 358752) principle recognized that, by the common law of England, a private contract
('2', 150, 10, 16, 358828) entered into between two persons was invalid if that contract could be shown
('2', 150, 11, 17, 358905) to be prejudicial to the community by placing restraint on trade.
('2', 150, 12, 18, 358971) recognized as a principle of trade all the world over that there was nothing like
('2', 150, 13, 19, 359053) competition, not only for those engaged in the competition but also for
('2', 150, 14, 20, 359125) consumers.
('2', 150, 14, 21, 359136) The effect of a Bill of this sort would simply enhance the profits of
('2', 150, 15, 22, 359206) traders at the expense of the consumers.
('2', 150, 15, 23, 359247) He dealt with this Bill not from the
('2', 150, 16, 24, 359284) point of view of its effect as an Asiatic repression Bill, but from the point of
('2', 150, 17, 25, 359365) view upon which it was presented to the House.
('2', 150, 17, 26, 359412) The Bill included all sections
('2', 150, 18, 27, 359443) of the community, whether Europeans or Asiatics, and it contained provisions
('2', 150, 19, 28, 359520) of an alarming character.
('2', 150, 19, 29, 359546) It was provided that licences would be issued by one
('2', 150, 20, 30, 359599) individual, and licences already in existence were liable to be taken away by
('2', 150, 21, 31, 359677) that individual.
('2', 150, 21, 32, 359694) That applied to country districts.
('2', 150, 21, 33, 359729) How did it apply in towns
('2', 150, 22, 34, 359755) and municipalities?
('2', 150, 22, 35, 359775) Let him take Durban as an example.
('2', 150, 22, 36, 359810) The Town Council
('2', 150, 23, 37, 359827) might consist of a majority of persons who studied their own interests before

('2', 151, 1, 2, 360057) the interests of the community, and might refuse licences to trade in that
('2', 151, 2, 3, 360132) borough.
('2', 151, 2, 4, 360141) The Premier would say that these people were subject to the control
('2', 151, 3, 5, 360209) of the popular vote, but how was the popular vote to be brought into operation
('2', 151, 4, 6, 360288) when it was a case of one individual against the whole body.
('2', 151, 4, 7, 360349) Even the Honourable the Prime Minister found it very difficult to justify the Bill, and was not eager that it should pass.
('2', 151, 4, 8, 360472) He said:
('2', 151, 5, 9, 360481) They asked that powers be given to each municipality, in excess of its present powers, to control the issuing of licences, and there need be no hesitation in saying what their object was.
('2', 151, 5, 10, 360669) It was to prevent persons who competed with Europeans from getting licences to trade, as Europeans were required to do.
('2', 151, 5, 11, 360789) This was the intention of the Bill, and, if that intention were accepted, then, of course, the second reading would pass, and then they would have to deal with details.
('2', 151, 5, 12, 360958) It would not be possible to pass this Bill without appearing to take away a part of the liberty of the subject, because the subject now had a right to a licence as a matter of course, and if this Bill were passed into law, the subject would no longer have the right.
('2', 151, 5, 13, 361225) He would only have that right if the licensing authority thought fit to grant it.
('2', 151, 5, 14, 361307) This Bill interferes with the course of law, because the Bill would be defeated in its objects if the courts had jurisdiction.
('2', 151, 5, 15, 361434) The Town Councils would be responsible to their constituents, and there would be no appeal from their decisions, as regards the granting of licences, to a court of law.
('2', 151, 5, 16, 361603) The objection had been taken to this Bill that it would not allow the law to have its natural course.
('2', 151, 5, 17, 361705) The answer was if they should be granted, then they would not pass this Bill; but under this measure the licensing authorities only would have this discretion.
('2', 151, 5, 18, 361865) (Hear, hear.) He thought it right to emphasize the fact that the courts of law would have no jurisdiction over trade licences under this Bill.
('2', 151, 5, 19, 362008) This jurisdiction would be exercised by the licensing authorities.
('2', 151, 5, 20, 362075) If the Assembly thought that the Bill should go through the second reading then there would be a discussion on details in Committee.
('2', 151, 5, 21, 362208) He submitted the Bill to the Assembly, and wished to point out that the main object of it was to affect those persons dealt with under the Immigration Bill.
('2', 151, 5, 22, 362365) Ships would not bring these people if they knew they could not be landed, and the people would not come here to trade if they knew they could not get licences.
('2', 151, 5, 23, 362525) Mr. Symons “opposed this Bill.

('2', 151, 5, 25, 362777) As a matter of fact, they do not keep any books at all.
('2', 151, 5, 26, 362833) The objection to the aggrieved party going to the highest
('2', 152, 0, 1, 362891) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 153
('2', 152, 1, 2, 362933) tribunal of justice in the land seems to be based on the ground that the Licensing Officer will not be able to justify the use of his discretionary power in a court of law.
('2', 152, 1, 3, 363106) The question also arises as to what would be done with reference to renewals of licences.
('2', 152, 1, 4, 363196) Are the merchants, with hundreds and thousands of pounds worth of goods, to be called upon to shut up their businesses if the Licensing Officer thought it fit to order so?
('2', 152, 1, 5, 363368) It suggested itself to Mr. Smythe, a member of the Assembly, who moved that an year’s time should be given to persons in possession of licences, and drew the House’s attention to the fact that even the Free State gave the traders reasonable time before compelling them to close their businesses.
('2', 152, 1, 6, 363664) But, unfortunately, the motion was lost.
('2', 152, 1, 7, 363705) The Natal Advertiser, 5 4 ’97. thus expresses itself on the Bill:
('2', 152, 2, 8, 363771) It is a matter for regret that so many members, who boldly protested against the violation of British traditions embodied in the Immigration Bill, should have swallowed, without a grimace, the much more serious infringement of the liberty of the subject involved in the Licences Bill.
('2', 152, 2, 9, 364056) With the object of the Bill we are in thorough accord; and we do not either attach very much weight to the fears of some of the members as to the large powers granted to corporations.
('2', 152, 2, 10, 364240) A very much graver danger is the negation of appeal to the courts of justice.
('2', 152, 2, 11, 364318) It is only this, in fact, which could make the powers granted under the Bill dangerous.
('2', 152, 2, 12, 364406) It would have been easy to frame a measure which would safeguard the interests to be protected quite as effectively as this one, without resorting to the crude and unstatesmanlike expedient of depriving persons of their right to appeal to a court of law.
('2', 152, 2, 13, 364661) No urgency could justify such a provision.
('2', 152, 2, 14, 364704) The Premier’s argument that “there would be no discretion if the discretion was to be in the Supreme Court or any other court; they could not give discretion to a licensing authority and allow the discretion to be exercised by somebody else,” is unworthy of himself and his audience.
('2', 152, 2, 15, 364988) Licensing authorities under the existing law have discretion, but that does not exclude the ultimate jurisdiction of the Supreme Court.
('2', 152, 2, 16, 365124) Moreover the argument is destroyed by the provision in the Bill itself which allows appeal to the Colonial Secretary.
('2', 152, 2, 17, 365242) So that it actually does give discretion to a licensing authority, and then allow the discretion to be exercised by some body else.
('2', 152, 2, 18, 365374) Your Petitioners have not attempted to discuss the details of the above Bills at length, since, in their humble opinion, the principle of the Bills is so utterly opposed to the spirit of the British Constitution, as also of the Proclamation of 1858, that it seems useless to discuss the details.
('2', 152, 2, 19, 365670) This is clear, however, that if the Bills are not disallowed, Natal would have gone much further than the Transvaal in oppressing the
('2', 153, 0, 1, 365804) 154 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 153, 1, 2, 365846) Indians.
('2', 153, 1, 3, 365855) The Indians in virtue of the Immigration Law cannot enter Natal, except a few who are able to read and write English, though they may go to the Transvaal without any hindrance.
('2', 153, 1, 4, 366032) The hawkers may not get licences to hawk in Natal, though they can get them as of right in the Transvaal.
('2', 153, 1, 5, 366138) Under such circumstances, your Petitioners venture to trust that, if nothing else is done, Indian immigration to Natal would be stopped, and a great anomaly, i.e., the fact that Natal gets all the advantage of the presence of the Indian in the Colony while she would give none, removed.
('2', 153, 1, 6, 366425) The Bill to protect Uncovenanted Indians from liability to arrest 1
('2', 153, 2, 7, 366493) is not in answer to the anti Indian clamour in the Colony, but has its origin in a certain correspondence that passed between the Government and some Indians.
('2', 153, 2, 8, 366652) Indians that are not under indenture are sometimes arrested under the indentured Indians Immigration Law, as being deserters from their estates.
('2', 153, 2, 9, 366797) To avoid this inconvenience, some Indians approached the Government with a view to get it minimized.
('2', 153, 2, 10, 366898) The Government were good enough to issue a Proclamation authorizing the Protector of Immigrants to issue certificates to free Indians, certifying that the bearers were not indentured Indians.
('2', 153, 2, 11, 367090) It was, however, meant to be a temporary measure, and the present Bill is intended to replace it.
('2', 153, 2, 12, 367188) Your Petitioners recognize the good intentions of the Government in introducing the Bill; but your Petitioners are afraid that, owing to the clause 3 2, rendering the Police, arresting any Indians for being without a pass, free from liability for wrongful arrest, takes away all the good that the Bill is no doubt intended to do, and makes it an engine of oppression.
('2', 153, 2, 13, 367556) The taking out of passes is not compulsory, and it is admitted that only the poorer Indians would take advantage of the pass clause.
('2', 153, 2, 14, 367689) Before; too, much trouble only arose through the overzeal of officers in making arrests.
('2', 153, 2, 15, 367778) Now, the 3rd clause gives almost a license to arrest with impunity any Indian they choose.
('2', 153, 2, 16, 367869) Your Petitioners further draw your attention to the argument against the Bill as set forth in the memorial to the Honourable the Legislative Assembly herein before referred to (Appendix E), and venture to hope that the Bill will be disallowed.
