('2', 325, 0, 1, 754543) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 326
('2', 325, 1, 2, 754585) 107. INDIAN TRADERS IN NATAL 1
('2', 325, 2, 3, 754616) DURBAN, November 18, [1899]
('2', 325, 3, 4, 754644) Nothing of what I have so far written on the position of the British Indians in South Africa deserves that consideration which the matter I am about to deal with in this letter ought to do.
('2', 325, 3, 5, 754834) One of the four Acts the Natal Legislature passed in 1897, in indecent hurry and at a time when the fury of the Durban mob had hardly subsided, was that known as the Dealers’ Licenses Act.
('2', 325, 3, 6, 755023) The Act gives absolute discretion to the Licensing Officers appointed under it to issue or refuse a wholesale or a retail license, whether to trade as a shopkeeper or as a hawker, his decision being subject to review by the Town Council or the Town Board, which have the power to appoint him.
('2', 325, 3, 7, 755316) There is no right of appeal against a decision of these bodies, sitting as a Court of Appeal in such license cases.
('2', 325, 3, 8, 755432) The penalty for carrying on a trade without a license is £20, in default of which the magistrates have the power to send the defaulter to gaol— not under the Act itself, but under the powers reserved to the magistrates under another law for cases where imprisonment is not specifically mentioned.
('2', 325, 3, 9, 755729) It was hoped that the depriving the Supreme Court of the Colony of jurisdiction over all bodies exercising judicial functions would be found by the Privy Council to be illegal; but, as the reader may remember, that body has decided otherwise.
('2', 325, 3, 10, 755972) The Supreme Court has also decided that licenses issued under the Act are personal only, and, therefore, although they may be held, say by a company, the sale of its goodwill would not carry with it the right to trade under the Company’s license during the remainder of the license period.
('2', 325, 3, 11, 756262) Thus, there is no loophole left under the Act, and the judicial interpretation has narrowed down the rights of the parties affected thereby to the smallest compass.
('2', 325, 3, 12, 756427) The poor Indians have sent petitions—two to the Colonial Secretary and one to Lord Curzon, on whom they have built very large hopes.
('2', 325, 3, 13, 756560) No reply has as yet been received from the Viceroy, and none from the Colonial Secretary to the last petition, except an intimation by the Natal Government to the effect that the Colonial Office was in correspondence with them in the matter.
('2', 325, 3, 14, 756802) It would be safe to say that there are over 300 Indian store or shopkeeper’s licenses and about 500 Indian hawker’s licenses in the
('2', 325, 4, 15, 756934) 1 Vide Footnote in “The Plague Panic in South Africa”, 20 3 1899, supra.
('2', 326, 0, 1, 757007) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 327
('2', 326, 1, 2, 757049) Colony of Natal.
('2', 326, 1, 3, 757066) The holders of these form the respectable portion of the Indian community, and represent the 4,000 free Indians in the Colony, as distinguished from about 50,000 Indians who were brought into Natal under indenture as labourers, and their descendants.
('2', 326, 1, 4, 757317) In its operation the Act has ruined many Indian storekeepers, and unsettled the minds of all of them.
('2', 326, 1, 5, 757419) In certain cases the Incensing Officers have taken the greatest liberties with the Act, and it would not at all be an exaggeration to say that they have used their power in an arbitrary and tyrannical manner, and that the Licensing Boards have connived at and, at times, encouraged and even dictated, their actions.
('2', 326, 1, 6, 757735) Not only have new licenses been refused, transfers of old licenses prohibited and renewals of old licenses not allowed, but insult in some cases has been added to injury, while the injured parties have felt absolutely powerless.
('2', 326, 1, 7, 757964) An old Indian settler, who had risen from the status of a labourer to that of a respectable trader, removed from an up country district where he had been trading for several years, to Durban, bought a piece of property, and thought he would take out a license in Durban in the Indian portion of the town, where he was to cater principally for Indian customers.
('2', 326, 1, 8, 758325) He applied for a license, showed he had engaged a European book keeper to keep his books, and produced certificates as to respectability and honesty from three well known European merchants who had dealt with him; but the Licensing Officer declined to grant the license.
('2', 326, 1, 9, 758596) The matter was taken in appeal before the Durban Town Council, and the Licensing Officer was asked by the applicant’s attorney to give reasons for his refusal.
('2', 326, 1, 10, 758756) He declined to do so.
('2', 326, 1, 11, 758778) The Town Council upheld the decision of the Licensing Officer, and would not even make him his reasons.
('2', 326, 1, 12, 758882) While the case was being conducted, the Court (i.e., the Town Council), the Licensing Officer (who was the respondent) and the Town Solicitor retired to a private room for consultation, and on return, forgetting that the counsel s address was still to be heard, the Council announced their decision upholding their Officer’s action.
('2', 326, 1, 13, 759215) The applicant’s counsel drew their attention to the irregularity, and the farce of addressing a Court that had made up its mind was allowed to be gone through— with no better result.
('2', 326, 1, 14, 759398) The persevering applicant took the case before the Supreme Court which, while it declined to interfere with the decision of the Town Council —having no power to do so under the Act—quashed the whole proceedings, and sent the case back for rehearing, with the
('2', 327, 0, 1, 759657) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 328
('2', 327, 1, 2, 759699) direction that the appellant was entitled to reasons for refusal.
('2', 327, 1, 3, 759765) To the Acting Chief Justice: It seemed .
('2', 327, 1, 4, 759806) that the action of the Town Council in this case had been oppressive....
('2', 327, 1, 5, 759879) It seemed to him that the refusal of both requests [for a copy of the record and reasons] was unjudicial and an improper proceeding.
('2', 327, 1, 6, 760012) Justice Mason, the first Puisne Judge, considered the proceedings under appeal were a disgrace to the Town Council, and he did not hesitate to use this strong language.
('2', 327, 1, 7, 760181) He considered under the circumstance that it was an abuse of words to say there had been an appeal to the Town Council.
('2', 327, 1, 8, 760301) So the Town Council reheard the appeal, and made the Licensing Officer give his reasons, which were that “the applicant had no claim whatever upon Durban, as the class of trade he was engaged in was sufficiently provided for in the town.” The decision was the same as on the previous occasion, and the unfortunate man has to remain without his license.
('2', 327, 1, 9, 760654) I understand that now he is a poor man, having been obliged to live on his capital.
('2', 327, 1, 10, 760738) The reason was, in plain words, absolutely false, many licenses to Europeans having since been granted, and the application having been in respect of a place that was vacated by an Indian storekeeper who had left Durban.
('2', 327, 1, 11, 760959) Another Indian who, it was proved, was a Colonist of fifteen years’ standing, lived in a decent style, had large businesses in several parts of the Colony, and had good credit with a number of European firms, also applied for a license —with the same unsuccessful result.
('2', 327, 1, 12, 761231) The real reason was forced out for the first time during the hearing of his appeal.
('2', 327, 1, 13, 761315) The Licensing Officer said:
('2', 327, 2, 14, 761343) The Act 18 of 1897 as I understand was passed with a view of placing some check on the issue of trading licenses to certain classes of people generally regarded as undesirables, and as I believe I am right in assuming that the applicant in question is one that would be included in that class, and, moreover, as he has never before had a license in Durban, I have felt it my duty to refuse his license.
('2', 327, 2, 15, 761746) One of the councillors, in approving of the decision of the Licensing Officer, said:
('2', 327, 3, 16, 761831) The reason was not because the applicant or the premises were unsuitable, but because the applicant was an Indian.
('2', 327, 3, 17, 761946) Personally he considered the refusal of the license a grievance to the applicant, who was a most suitable person to appear before the Council to ask for a license.
('2', 327, 3, 18, 762110) Another councillor would not take part in the proceedings because he disagreed with the dirty work they (councillors) were called upon to do.
('2', 327, 3, 19, 762252) If the burgesses wished all such licenses stopped, there was a clean way of going about the
('2', 328, 0, 1, 762344) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 329
('2', 328, 1, 2, 762386) matter: viz., getting the Legislative Assembly to enact a measure against the granting of licenses to the Indian community.
('2', 328, 1, 3, 762510) But sitting as a Court of Appeal, unless there were good grounds to the contrary, the license should be granted.
('2', 328, 2, 4, 762623) But, of course, it was not, as the anti Indian element was too strong in the Council.
('2', 328, 2, 5, 762709) The Newcastle Town Council took away at one stroke almost all the Indian licenses in 1898. It was then that the matter was taken to the Supreme Court, and thence to the Privy Council, which decided that there was no appeal from the Town Council’s decisions under the Act.
('2', 328, 2, 6, 762981) This year it has granted most of the Indian licenses, and it must also be said to its credit that, while the question was pending before the Privy Council, it allowed the Indians concerned to carry on their trade.
('2', 328, 2, 7, 763195) The Chairman of the Dundee Local Board, in dealing with a similar appeal, said he would not give the applicant even “the chance of a dog”.
('2', 328, 2, 8, 763334) The same Board, moreover, passed a resolution last year instructing the Licensing Officer to cancel as many Indian licenses as possible.
('2', 328, 2, 9, 763471) This was too much for even the public press of Natal, and a hint was given that the Board was going too far.
('2', 328, 2, 10, 763580) The result was in a measure satisfactory, and licenses have been granted this year, though with the proviso that they would not be renewed next year in respect of the same building.
('2', 328, 2, 11, 763762) In another respect, two Indian merchants sold their business to Indians and asked for a transfer of license, which was refused—the decision being upheld in appeal by the Local Board.
('2', 328, 2, 12, 763945) In some parts of the Colony, licenses granted last year have been withheld this year.
('2', 328, 2, 13, 764031) Such, in a brief outline, is the effect of the Act in question.
('2', 328, 2, 14, 764095) As a result of the correspondence between the Colonial Office and the Natal Government, the latter have told the different local bodies that, unless they exercised their powers with better discretion so as not to affect vested interests, the right of appeal to the Supreme Court would be given to the aggrieved parties.
('2', 328, 2, 15, 764415) This letter officially admits the grievance and also approves of the remedy suggested by the Indians.
('2', 328, 2, 16, 764517) But the three Municipalities of Natal take the letter for what it is worth, and hardly listen to such a threat of the Natal Government.
('2', 328, 2, 17, 764653) Neither the Licensing Officers nor the Town Councils are much to blame in the matter.
('2', 328, 2, 18, 764739) They are merely victims.
('2', 328, 2, 19, 764764) Any body of persons placed under similar circumstances would act in the same manner as the Natal Licensing Officers and Boards.
('2', 328, 2, 20, 764892) The Officers are either Town Clerks or Town Treasurers and, therefore, as the Chief Justice remarked in the case referred to above, hardly independent of those bodies, the members of which, in their turn, depend for their offices on the
('2', 329, 0, 1, 765129) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 330
('2', 329, 1, 2, 765171) goodwill of the people that are directly opposed to the Indians.
('2', 329, 1, 3, 765236) And to these bodies the Natal Legislative Assembly has said:
('2', 329, 2, 4, 765297) We leave the Indian entirely at your mercy.
('2', 329, 2, 5, 765341) You may, without your action being called in question by any body, either let them earn an honest living in your midst or deprive them of it without any compensation whatever.
('2', 329, 3, 6, 765517) So long, therefore, as the Act, which is admitted by all, including even the Natal politicians, to be opposed to free trade and the cherished principles of the British Constitution, is allowed to blot the Statute book of the Colony, so long will the grievances remain, the Government letters, like the one mentioned above, addressed to the Corporations notwithstanding.
('2', 329, 3, 7, 765887) The Indians very reasonably say: “Impose what sanitary restrictions you like on us; let our books be kept in English, if you will; introduce, if so minded, other tests which we may reasonably be expected to fulfil; but, after we have complied with all the requirements, allow us to continue to earn our living and, if there be interference on the part of the Officers administering the law, give us the right of appeal to the highest judicial tribunal in the land.” It is difficult, indeed, to find fault with such a position, and more so to understand the distrust of the Natal Legislature in the Supreme Court of the Colony.
('2', 329, 3, 8, 766514) This licensing question is a festering sore which needs must be healed.
('2', 329, 3, 9, 766586) It affects the present Indian population, and fairly promises to ruin it unless there is timely intervention.
('2', 329, 3, 10, 766696) The petty Indian traders are surely, if slowly, being weeded out unnoticed.
('2', 329, 3, 11, 766772) This tells very materially upon their feeders— the large Indian firms and their dependants.
('2', 329, 3, 12, 766864) Indian landlords have an anxious time of it, as their premises, however well constructed they may be, cannot be let, as no one would have them when the licenses cannot be got.
('2', 329, 3, 13, 767040) The current year is fast approaching its end, and the Indians are all anxiously waiting to know how they will fare next year as to the renewal of their licenses, The war is depopulating Natal, and no one knows when business may be resumed and people may be able to return to their homes.
('2', 329, 3, 14, 767328) Still, it might be as well for the Indian public to remain on the alert, and by well sustained efforts to see that this evil, at any rate, is removed before it is too late, and before the Indians in Natal, through sheer suppression, are unable even to let their voice be heard in India.
('2', 329, 4, 15, 767615) The Times of India (Weekly edition), 6 1 1900
('2', 330, 0, 1, 767661) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 331
('2', 330, 1, 2, 767703) 108. LETTER TO W. PALMER
('2', 330, 2, 3, 767728) 14, MERCURY LANE, DURBAN, November 24 1899
('2', 330, 3, 4, 767771) TO WILLIAM PALMER, EST.
('2', 330, 3, 5, 767795) TREASURER DURBAN WOMEN’S PATRIOTS LEAGUE DURBAN
('2', 330, 4, 6, 767843) DEAR SIR,
('2', 330, 5, 7, 767853) We have been requested by the Indian subscribers to the Durban Women’s Patriotic League Fund to forward to you the enclosed cheques which represent a special contribution to the fund by the Indian merchants and storekeepers of Durban.
('2', 330, 5, 8, 768088) We feel that we have not subscribed enough, but the subscription for the support of the families of the Indian volunteers in the event of their services being required, the heavy strain put upon our resources for feeding and housing thousands of Indian refugees, not only from the Transvaal, but also from our up country Districts at present occupied by the enemy, and the enormous losses sustained owing to the virtual suspension of business, have crippled our pecuniary strength.
('2', 330, 5, 9, 768570) We know, however, that the Volunteers who have dedicated their lives to the Colony and the Empire, as also those they have left behind, have performed an act of self sacrifice before which anything we have done dwindles into insignificance.
('2', 330, 5, 10, 768811) What little therefore, we are able to send herewith is merely as token of our heartfelt sympathy and admiration of our brave men who are fighting for us all.
('2', 330, 6, 11, 768969) Yours etc.

('2', 331, 10, 20, 770705) He says also that he will not accompany the Corps for the present but may do so if there is a real need for him.
('2', 331, 10, 21, 770818) In my humble opinion, Dr. Booth is indispensable for the Corps.
('2', 331, 10, 22, 770882) His knowledge of medicine was of the greatest value to us, and if Dr. Booth did not accompany us, we, a Corps of nearly 1000 men,
('2', 332, 0, 1, 771012) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 333
('2', 332, 1, 2, 771054) would be without a medical adviser.

('2', 332, 1, 4, 771211) In the treatment of the wounded that might be entrusted to the care of the leaders, Dr. Booth’s services, Your Lordship will agree, will be inestimable.
('2', 332, 1, 5, 771364) His place can be filled here, in the ambulance camp there would be a gap without him.

('2', 333, 0, 1, 772272) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 334
('2', 333, 1, 2, 772314) 114. INDIAN AMBULANCE CORPS
('2', 333, 2, 3, 772342) The Hon.
('2', 333, 2, 4, 772351) Mr. Harry Escombe, Premier of Natal in 1897, invited at his residence in Johannesburg the leaders of the Indian Ambulance Corps proceeding that day to the front.
('2', 333, 2, 5, 772513) The following is a brief press report of the speech Gandhiji made at Mr. Escombe’s request.
('2', 333, 2, 6, 772605) [JOHANNESBURG,] December 13, 1899
('2', 333, 3, 7, 772639) When the ultimatum was presented by the Transvaal, some of them thought it was a time when they should sink all differences, and, as they insisted upon rights and privileges as subjects of the Queen, do something to prove their loyalty.
('2', 333, 3, 8, 772876) Very few of them could handle arms, although, if the Ghoorkas or the Sikhs had been there, they would have shown what they could do in the way of fighting.
('2', 333, 3, 9, 773032) They— that is the English speaking Indians—came to the conclusion that they would offer their services to the Colonial or Imperial Government, unconditionally and absolutely without payment, in any capacity in which they could be useful, in order to show the Colonists that they were worthy subjects of the Queen.
('2', 333, 3, 10, 773346) They called a meeting, and at that time there was so much enthusiasm shown that almost everyone present put their names on the list as willing to serve, and from that list they had chosen suitable men.
('2', 333, 3, 11, 773548) He asked Dr. Prince to examine them to know how many were fit to serve on the battlefield.
('2', 333, 3, 12, 773639) Dr. Prince passed 25, and they sent the list of names to the Government, but got the reply that at that time their services could not be accepted.
('2', 333, 3, 13, 773786) Shortly after this, ambulance classes were started by Dr. Booth and they had been attending his lectures almost every night.
('2', 333, 3, 14, 773911) The Government had intimated that they required 50 to 60 Indians to go to the front, and on the Protector coming to him, he said that they were ready at a moment’s notice to do whatever was needed of them, and that, without remuneration of any kind.
('2', 333, 3, 15, 774161) The Colonial Secretary, however, did not think the work suitable for them, and on hearing this, Dr. Booth wrote to the Colonial Secretary and gave him an idea of the work they could do; Dr. Booth was then kind enough to go with him to Maritzburg, where they saw Bishop Baynes and, also, Colonel Johnston.
('2', 333, 3, 16, 774466) The latter thought they would do admirably to act as leaders for the Indians engaged as bearers.
('2', 333, 3, 17, 774563) Their dream had been realised, and although, unfortunately, they were not to be engaged in the fighting line, he hoped they would be able to discharge their duties well.
('2', 333, 3, 18, 774733) To Dr. Booth they were very grateful for what he had done, and he also had offered
('2', 334, 0, 1, 774816) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 335
('2', 334, 1, 2, 774858) his services gratis to the Government, and was going with them that night.
('2', 334, 1, 3, 774933) The Natal Mercury, 14 12 1899

('2', 338, 2, 3, 780407) [DURBAN,] January 30, 1900
('2', 338, 3, 4, 780434) DEAR SIR, I received your letter asking [me] to contribute notes or the doings of the Indian Ambulance Corps at Spearman’s Hill when we were all in the thickest of the work.
('2', 338, 3, 5, 780608) Some of us had, besides taking charge of stretchers, to look after the provisioning, etc., of the Corps, getting hardly time to sleep or eat.
('2', 338, 3, 6, 780750) Hence my inability to acknowledge your note which, I trust, you would excuse understandingly.
('2', 338, 3, 7, 780844) But even if time had permitted, I would have refrained from writing the notes on the strength of the advice of a valued English friend who, soon after he saw my notes 2 in the Advertiser on the doings of the Corpsin the Colenso tight, thought that there should be very little said by the Indians themselves of their work done in connection with the war and that their part was merely to do without speaking.
('2', 338, 3, 8, 781252) Since then I have so far resisted all temptations to write anything about the work for publication.
('2', 338, 3, 9, 781352) I remain,
('2', 338, 4, 10, 781362) yours truly,

('2', 340, 7, 11, 784341) 124. CONGRATULATION TO BRITISH GENERALS
('2', 340, 8, 12, 784381) At a large and representative meeting of Indians and Europeans held in response to the invitations issued by Gandhiji on March 10, a resolution congratulating the British Generals was adopted.
('2', 340, 8, 13, 784574) Supporting the resolution, Gandhiji made a brief speech of which the following is a press report.
('2', 340, 8, 14, 784672) DURBAN,: March 14, 1900
('2', 340, 9, 15, 784696) Mr. M. K. Gandhi, Secretary of the Indian Congress, in supporting the resolution 2 said that they were deeply grateful for the splendid response which had been made to the invitations issued to the European community in Durban.
('2', 340, 9, 16, 784924) They had response also from Indians in Umzinto, Verulam and other centres.
('2', 340, 9, 17, 784999) There was some talk of a special meeting being held by the Indians.
('2', 340, 9, 18, 785067) He thought that the
('2', 340, 10, 19, 785087) 1 The letters of invitation bore the heading “Long Live Kaiser i Hind” and pictures of Queen Victoria and three prominent British Generals who had taken part in the Boer War.
('2', 340, 10, 20, 785262) 2 Vide Resolution No.
('2', 340, 10, 21, 785284) 1 on “Congratulations to British Generals”, Prior to 26 3 1900, infra.
('2', 340, 10, 22, 785355) It was moved by Abdool Kadir, President of the Natal Indian Congress, and seconded by Louis Paul.
('2', 341, 0, 1, 785453) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 342
('2', 341, 1, 2, 785495) Indians could not be too joyful in connection with the British victories in South Africa, provided they did not become conceited.
('2', 341, 1, 3, 785625) The Indians had a special interest in this affair.
('2', 341, 1, 4, 785676) Lord Roberts, the hero of Kandahar, 1 who was at the head of the forces, and Sir George White, who had conducted the siege of Ladysmith with much gallantry, had been for some long time Commandersin Chief in India.
('2', 341, 1, 5, 785890) The Indians would have failed in their duty to themselves if they had not given expression to their feelings at the successes which had attended the feats of the two Generals.
('2', 341, 1, 6, 786066) He hoped that they would believe him when he said that the want of the knowledge of English language did not prevent Indians from following the course of events with accuracy and interest.
('2', 341, 1, 7, 786255) It was the Indians’ proudest boast that they were British subjects.
('2', 341, 1, 8, 786323) If they were not, they would not have had a footing in South Africa.
('2', 341, 1, 9, 786392) The Natal Mercury, 15 3 1900 The Natal A Advertiser, 15 3 1900
('2', 341, 2, 10, 786455) 125. INDIAN AMBULANCE CORPS IN NATAL 2
('2', 341, 3, 11, 786494) [DURBAN, post March 14, 1900] General Sir William Olpherts is reported to have said: While fully sharing the enthusiasm for the bravery of our troops fighting in South Africa, I think that sufficient attention has not been called to the devotion of the Indian dhoolie bearers who do.
('2', 341, 3, 12, 786778) their work of mercy on the battlefields.
('2', 341, 3, 13, 786819) Under the heaviest fire they seek the wounded, fearing nothing, although without means of defence.
('2', 341, 3, 14, 786918) These Indian fellow subjects of ours are doing in Natal a work which requires even more courage than that of the soldier.
('2', 341, 3, 15, 787040) Since sending my last contribution, 3 I have been twice to the front; and though what General Olpherts said of the dhoolie bearers could not be said of all the Indian Ambulance Corps, I have no doubt that the Corps has done a work that was absolutely necessary, and that would do credit to any Ambulance Corps in the world.
('2', 341, 3, 16, 787364) I referred in my letter, dated October 27th, to the unconditional offer, without pay,
('2', 341, 4, 17, 787450) 1 In 1880 Lord Roberts made a historic march from Kabul to Kandahar, then capital of ,Afghanistan.
('2', 341, 4, 18, 787549) 2 Vide footnote in “The Plague Panic in South Africa”, 20 3 1899, supra.
('2', 341, 4, 19, 787622) 3 Vide “Indian Traders in Natal”, November 18, 1899.
('2', 342, 0, 1, 787675) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 343
('2', 342, 1, 2, 787717) of the English speaking Indians of Durban to do service on the battlefield.
('2', 342, 1, 3, 787793) Since then, events have happened which resulted in its acceptance.
('2', 342, 1, 4, 787860) It was anticipated that the battle of Colenso would claim not a few lives, and that the safe carrying of the seriously wounded would be a grave problem, as the limited number of European ambulance bearers would not be equal to the required strain.
('2', 342, 1, 5, 788108) General Buller, therefore, wrote to the Natal Government, asking them to raise an Indian Ambulance Corps, which would not be required to work within the range of fire.
('2', 342, 1, 6, 788276) The managers of the various plantations (which control much Indian labour), as well as the leaders of the Indian community, were approached by the Government, and the response was prompt.
('2', 342, 1, 7, 788464) A Corps of over 1,000 Indian stretcher bearers was formed in less than three days, the bearers receiving 20s.
('2', 342, 1, 8, 788574) per week as against 35s.
('2', 342, 1, 9, 788599) per week received by the European bearers.
('2', 342, 1, 10, 788642) It is worthy of mention that the sturdy band of leaders began their work under exceptionally happy auspices.
('2', 342, 1, 11, 788751) the late Mr. Escombe, who was sometime Prime Minister of Natal and represented the Clolony at the Conference of Colonial Premiers at the time of the Diamond Jubilee, gave a reception in his house to the volunteers, where the Mayor of Durban, Mr. Pakeman of the Johannesburg Leader, and other ladies and gentlemen were invited, and in his address—which was his last public utterance— .
('2', 342, 1, 12, 789136) spoke words of encouragement to them, and generously observed that Natal could not forget the loyal services that the Indian community in its own way was rendering to the Colony and to the Empire.
('2', 342, 1, 13, 789333) The Mayor also spoke to the effect.
('2', 342, 1, 14, 789369) Later, in the same evening, Mr. Rustomjee of Durban gave a dinner party in honour of the leaders going to the front, when all the prominentIndians representing different divisions sat at the same table.
('2', 342, 1, 15, 789572) The Corps reached Chieveley at about 3.30 p.
('2', 342, 1, 16, 789617) on December 15, and as soon as they were detrained, the bearers were given their redcross badges and ordered to march to the field hospital—a distance of over 6 miles.
('2', 342, 1, 17, 789785) The conditions under which this Corps worked were possibly somewhat more arduous than is usual.
('2', 342, 1, 18, 789881) Wherever they went, they carried rations for a month or a fortnight, as; the case might be, including firewood, and, at first, without wagons or a water cart.
('2', 342, 1, 19, 790040) The Chieveley district is extremely dry, and there is hardly any water to be found within easy distances.
('2', 342, 1, 20, 790146) The roads all over Natal are rugged and more or less hilly.
('2', 342, 1, 21, 790206) On reaching the field hospital, we heard of the battle at Colenso.
('2', 342, 1, 22, 790273) We saw the wounded being brought by the ambulance wagons and the European bearers from the base of
('2', 343, 0, 1, 790372) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 344
('2', 343, 1, 2, 790414) operations to the field hospital, and the men as well as the leaders fully realised the situation.
('2', 343, 1, 3, 790513) Before the tents could be pitched (I mean the tents for the leaders and not for the bearers—the latter had to sleep as they could, in the open, in some cases even without blankets), or the men could have anything to eat or drink, the Medical Officer wanted over 50 wounded men carried to Chieveley station.
('2', 343, 1, 4, 790820) By 11 o’clock at night, all the wounded the Medical Officer could get ready were taken as directed, and it was only after that time that the Corps could get a meal.
('2', 343, 1, 5, 790985) After this, the Superintendent of the Corps went to the Medical Officer and offered to carry more stretchers, but he was thanked and told to keep the men in readiness at 6 o’clock next morning.
('2', 343, 1, 6, 791179) Between that time and noon, over 100 stretcher cases were disposed of by the men.
('2', 343, 1, 7, 791261) While they were returning from their work, orders were received to strike camp and march to Chieveley immediately to entrain there for Estcourt.
('2', 343, 1, 8, 791406) This was, of course, a retreat.
('2', 343, 1, 9, 791438) It was wonderful to see how, with clockwork regularity, over 15,000 men with heavy artillery and transports broke camp and marched off, leaving behind nothing but empty tins and broken cases.
('2', 343, 1, 10, 791630) It was an extremely hot day for marching—this portion of Natal is treeless as well as waterless.
('2', 343, 1, 11, 791727) The Corps commenced its march at noon under these trying conditions.
('2', 343, 1, 12, 791796) On reaching the railway station at about 3 o’clock, the station master informed the Superintendent that he could not say definitely when he could place the carriages—I mean open trucks in which the men were to be packed like sardines—at his disposal.
('2', 343, 1, 13, 792047) The European Ambulance men and the Indians had to remain about the station yard till 8 p.m.
('2', 343, 1, 14, 792139) The former were then entrained for Estcourt, and the latter were told to shift for the night as best they could on the veldt.
('2', 343, 1, 15, 792265) Tired, hungry, and thirsty (there was no water available at the station except for the hospital patients and the station staff), the men had to find means of satisfying both hunger and thirst, and of obtaining some rest.
('2', 343, 1, 16, 792486) They brought dirty water from a pool about half a mile from the station, cooked rice and by midnight, after partaking of what was, under the circumstances, regarded as an excellent repast, wanted to sleep.
('2', 343, 1, 17, 792692) Practically the whole of General Buller’s Cavalry passed by during thenight, and the men had very little rest.
('2', 343, 1, 18, 792803) Next day the men were closely packed in the trucks, and, after five hours’ waiting, the train proceeded to Estcourt where, in a violent storm, exposed to the sun and wind, without shelter, the Corps had to remain for two days, after which orders were received to temporarily disband it.
('2', 343, 1, 19, 793090) General Wolf Murray had officially recognised the services rendered by the
('2', 344, 0, 1, 793165) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 345
('2', 344, 1, 2, 793207) On January 7th, the Corps was reformed and proceeded to Estcourt, this time under somewhat better auspices, in that the nine hundred and odd bearers also were provided with tents.
('2', 344, 1, 3, 793387) Fully a fortnight elapsed, however, before actual work was commenced.
('2', 344, 1, 4, 793457) The interval was passed in drilling the men and their leaders under the indefatigable Dr. Booth, who volunteered on the same terms as the leaders (i.e., without any remuneration) to accompany the Corps in the capacity of medical officer.
('2', 344, 1, 5, 793695) The drill consisted in teaching the bearers how to lift the wounded, and to place and carry them on stretchers.
('2', 344, 1, 6, 793807) They were taken long distances over extremely rugged ground.
('2', 344, 1, 7, 793868) All this training was found to be of inestimable value, and none too strict.
('2', 344, 1, 8, 793945) Thus, fitted as the Corps was more or less for military discipline, it did not find it difficult, when the orders were received at 2 a.m., to entrain for Frere at 6 o’clock in the morning, to break camp, load the two wagons and march to the station within three hours.
('2', 344, 1, 9, 794214) From Frere a distance of 25 miles had to be covered on foot before the headquarters at Spearman’s Camp could be reached.
('2', 344, 1, 10, 794335) I shall let the special correspondent of The Natal Witness speak of the experiences and trials of this journey.
('2', 344, 2, 11, 794447) Early in the afternoon, heavy clouds began to bank upon the horizon, and at half past three, a storm seemed imminent.
('2', 344, 2, 12, 794565) Meanwhile the wagons had arrived and been loaded up.
('2', 344, 2, 13, 794618) The start was not auspicious.
('2', 344, 2, 14, 794648) At the first dip between the station and our camping ground, the leading wagon stuck fast and half an hour elapsed before it could be extricated.
('2', 344, 2, 15, 794794) By that time, a terrific wind had arisen, which appeared to be blowing the threatening thunderstorm away from us to the southward....
('2', 344, 2, 16, 794928) In less than three quarters of an hour, the wind suddenly veered, bringing the storm back with tremendous force) and hail along with it....The hail certainly ceased after a while, but the rain continued in a steady downpour....
('2', 344, 2, 17, 795156) At length, it was decided to halt and wait for the wagons, and the rain having now stopped, although the clouds gave evidence of more to follow, ovens were made out of antheaps, at which we endeavoured (for the most part, unsuccessfully) to dry our sopping garments....At 8 o’clock, just as we were becoming partially dry and recovering our spirits under the influence of the fires, down came the rain again in tropical torrents.
('2', 344, 2, 18, 795586) All the time, a bitter wind blew, and for discomfort our situation could scarcely have been excelled.
('2', 344, 2, 19, 795688) The leading wagon had got stuck in a drift from which, owing to the awful state of the road and weather, the combined spans of oxen (32) had been quite unable to remove it....
('2', 344, 2, 20, 795864) The next morning, fifty stretchers went out to the temporary hospital.
('2', 344, 2, 21, 795935) Here Major Bapty, Secretary of the Principal Medical Officer, sent word to the leaders that it was optional for
('2', 345, 0, 1, 796047) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 346
('2', 345, 1, 2, 796089) them to take the stretchers or not to the base at Spion Kop, about two miles on the other side of the river, as it was within range of the Boer guns, and he could nor be sure that they would not drop a shell or two on the pontoon bridge.
('2', 345, 1, 3, 796327) This preliminary was due to the fact that the men were told, as I have said before, that they would have to work without the line of fire.
('2', 345, 1, 4, 796466) But the leaders and the men were quite ready not to mind the risk and go to the base and undertake the work.
('2', 345, 1, 5, 796575) By evening almost all the wounded were brought to the stationary hospital, the bearers often having to make three or four journeys from the temporary hospital to the base.
('2', 345, 1, 6, 796747) Full three weeks were thus passed in almost continuous work, emptying one hospital after another, chiefly the stationary hospital.
('2', 345, 1, 7, 796878) During the time five journeys were made to Frere, the men three times carrying the wounded the whole distance of 25 miles in a single day, and twice taking them up at or near the little Tugela bridge at Springfield from the European bearers.
('2', 345, 1, 8, 797120) The Corps had the honour of carrying some officers of note— Major General Woodgate being among them.
('2', 345, 1, 9, 797221) It was freely remarked each time the “light footed, elastic stepped” bearers covered the whole distance of 25 miles with their charge, under a trying sun and over a difficult road, that they alone could perform the feat.
('2', 345, 1, 10, 797442) Says the special correspondent of The Natal Witness:
('2', 345, 2, 11, 797495) One hundred miles in five days may be accounted fairly good walking for a man unburdened with any weight but that of his own carcass and clothes.
('2', 345, 2, 12, 797641) When the wounded have to be carried on stretchers for nearly half that distance, and the greater portion of the remainder is traversed by men Iaden with heavy kit, such marching, I think, will be acknowledged as very creditable work.
('2', 345, 2, 13, 797875) Such is the feat lately performed by the Indian Ambulance Corps, and one that any body of men may be proud of.
('2', 345, 3, 14, 797986) Thus honoured and thus satisfied with the thought of having done its duty, the Corps was again temporarily disbanded—but recent events go to show that its services may not be needed again.
('2', 345, 3, 15, 798175) The Indian merchants had supplied the leaders with large quantities of cigarettes, cigars, pipes, and tobacco for the wounded, and these were freely distributed among them.
('2', 345, 3, 16, 798348) Of course, they were very much appreciated, especially as no cigarettes, etc., could be had in or near the camp.
('2', 345, 3, 17, 798461) The leaders and the bearers were by no means satisfied with having carried their charge safely and well to their destination; but, at each stopping place during the long marches, even neglecting their own comforts, they left no stone unturned to attend to the wants of the wounded, e.g., helping them to tea and fruit—often doing so with their own money, or from their own rations.
('2', 345, 3, 18, 798843) Nor is this the only part the Indian community has taken in the war.
('2', 345, 3, 19, 798912) All the
('2', 346, 0, 1, 798920) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 347
('2', 346, 1, 2, 798962) leaders who went without pay were not capable of maintaining their dependents during their absence.
('2', 346, 1, 3, 799062) The Indian merchants, therefore, started a fund which contributed to the support of the families of such leaders as needed it, and at no inconsiderable cost fully equipped the volunteers.
('2', 346, 1, 4, 799250) In order to still more effectively identify themselves with the patriotic wave, and to show that they are capable of sinking their differences in the face of a common danger, they have subscribed a respectable sum of £65 to the Durban Women’s Patriotic League, a local organisation formed for the purpose of providing medical comforts for the wounded soldiers and volunteers, some of which latter are violent anti Indian Colonists.
('2', 346, 1, 5, 799682) the Indian ladies have come forward to prepare pillowcases and handkerchiefs for the same purpose, out of cloth furnished by the Indian merchants.
('2', 346, 1, 6, 799829) Thus speaks The Natal Mercury anent the subscription:
('2', 346, 2, 7, 799883) This gift of money for the Women’s Patriotic Fund, specially for the purpose of assisting in the care of the sick and wounded volunteers at the front, is a very acceptable and eloquent expression of the feeling of the Indian people.
('2', 346, 2, 8, 800116) It is not enough, in their minds, to succour the large mass of Indian refugees, as they are doing in an open handed manner, but they must bestow this added contribution, we believe, as a token of their devotion to the Queen Empress and to the country in which they have come to reside.
('2', 346, 2, 9, 800402) Nothing can better show the real feeling that animates this portion of our population, who too often have very little said on their behalf, than such a display of loyalty.
('2', 346, 3, 10, 800574) The Indians have entirely taken on their shoulders the maintenance of thousands of Indian refugees not only from the Transvaal but also from the upper districts of Natal which are temporarily in the hands of the enemy.
('2', 346, 3, 11, 800793) This fact has so much impressed the Colonial mind that the Mayor of Durban made the following public acknowledgement:
('2', 346, 4, 12, 800911) They knew full well that many of the Indian nationality had been
('2', 346, 5, 13, 800976) compelled to leave their posts and come down here as refugees.
('2', 346, 5, 14, 801039) They had had a
('2', 346, 6, 15, 801054) large number arrived, and the Indians had borne the expense themselves.
('2', 346, 7, 16, 801126) that he sincerely thanked them.
('2', 346, 8, 17, 801158) It derives, at the present moment, a peculiar importance.
('2', 346, 8, 18, 801216) The Central Committee in London have cabled withdrawing their support from the able bodied European refugees, confining it solely to women and invalids, and the matter is now taxing to the’ utmost the resources of the Refugee Relief Committee in Durban.
('2', 346, 8, 19, 801470) It may not be amiss to mention also a few instances of individual sympathy for the
('2', 347, 0, 1, 801553) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 348
('2', 347, 1, 2, 801595) soldiers.

('2', 347, 1, 4, 801835) We are not told where the noble hearted woman found her food for the day.

('2', 351, 5, 10, 808896) 129. AN APPEAL FOR FUNDS 1
('2', 351, 6, 11, 808923) 14, MERCURY LANE, DURBAN, April 11, 1900
('2', 351, 7, 12, 808964) SIR, You all know that a hospital for Indians was opened in Durban about a year and a half ago.
('2', 351, 7, 13, 809060) Dr. Booth and another doctor work in it in an honorary capacity.
('2', 351, 7, 14, 809125) Prior to the opening of the hospital, a meeting was held in Durban at which it was decided that Indians should contribute £85 per annum as rental charges.
('2', 351, 7, 15, 809280) This arrangement was to hold good for a period of two years.
('2', 351, 7, 16, 809341) A fund was immediately raised and a sum of £6l collected.
('2', 351, 7, 17, 809399) The balance of, £24 is still to be collected.
('2', 351, 7, 18, 809445) But this amount will not suffice to meet the expenses.
('2', 351, 7, 19, 809500) Over nine months’ rent is in arrears.
('2', 351, 7, 20, 809538) As Durban has contributed to many funds, it is not proper to put the responsibility for the remaining amount on it alone.
('2', 351, 7, 21, 809660) Hence this letter.
('2', 351, 8, 22, 809679) 1 A circular letter.
('2', 352, 0, 1, 809700) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 353
('2', 352, 1, 2, 809742) A report of the working of the hospital for the first six months is enclosed from which you will see the usefulness of the institute.
('2', 352, 1, 3, 809876) Madrasi women entering it in a very serious condition have come out cured.
('2', 352, 1, 4, 809951) The Gujaratis also have benefited from it.
('2', 352, 1, 5, 809994) No community has been left out.
('2', 352, 1, 6, 810026) Free medicine is supplied to hundreds of patients who deposit some amount, according to their capacity, in the charity box kept for the purpose; even those who cannot contribute anything receive medicine.
('2', 352, 1, 7, 810231) Medicines are bought out of the box collections and the deficit, if any, is met by the missionaries.
('2', 352, 1, 8, 810332) If we are not able to help, the hospital will have to be closed down.
('2', 352, 1, 9, 810402) As the two doctors serve honorarily, it is being run at a small cost and many poor people benefit from it.
('2', 352, 1, 10, 810509) A blind, old, infirm Gujarati gentleman received free treatment in the hospital for many days.
('2', 352, 1, 11, 810604) You ought to spare whatever you can for such a cause and also collect contributions from others and forward them.

('2', 352, 3, 16, 810885) 130. INDIAN AMBULANCE CORPS 1
('2', 352, 4, 17, 810915) DURBAN, April 18 [1900] Perhaps, in reading the accounts published from day to day of the Boer War, you have Showed the movements of the Indian community in connexion with it in so far as they have been chronicled by the newspapers But, I am also aware that the Press has not been able to give anything like a full account of the doings of the Indians in South Africa.
('2', 352, 4, 18, 811284) I need hardly say that, as soon as war was declared, irrespective of their opinions as to the justness or otherwise of the war, the Indians to a man made up their minds to give their humble support to the British Government during the crisis; and, as the immediate result of this sentiment, an extremely will attended meeting of the English speaking Indians of Durban was held, and as
('2', 352, 5, 19, 811669) 1 This letter of Gandhiji; appeared in India as from its “Indian Correspondent”, He had already sent a fuller account to The Times of india (Weekly edition), vide ‘Indian Ambulance Crops,” post 14 3 1900
('2', 353, 0, 1, 811873) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 354
('2', 353, 1, 2, 811915) many as could signed, there and then, a declaration offering their services to the military authorities, unconditionally and without pay to do any work that they may be Considered fitted for especially mentioning the field hospital and commissariat departments, and recording the fact that they did not know the use of arms.
('2', 353, 1, 3, 812240) The offer was ultimately accepted in connexion with the Indian Ambulance Corps which, at the instance of the military authorities, was formed in Natal.
('2', 353, 1, 4, 812392) The bearers for the Corps consisted mostly of indentured Indians supplied by the Estates in Natal, through the Protector’s Department, and through the above mentioned volunteers who were to act as leaders of the parties of stretcher bearers, the Indians being perfectly free either to go to the battlefield or not.
('2', 353, 1, 5, 812707) Thus about 1,000 Indian bearers, and thirty leaders (no more of the latter being really necessary), carried the wounded after the battle of Colenso, and by their arduous work commanded the admiration of all concerned and more than satisfied the patients themselves.
('2', 353, 1, 6, 812973) It was freely acknowledged by the European Superintendent of the Corps and other Europeans who came with it that, without the leaders, the carrying could not be done with saticfaction.
('2', 353, 1, 7, 813158) The Corps, having been formed only for the advance to Ladysmith through Colenso, was disbanded after the reverse, and Was reformed when General Buller tried to force passage through Spion Kop.
('2', 353, 1, 8, 813351) The nature of the work this time was, if possible, more exacting undoubtedly, more risky.
('2', 353, 1, 9, 813441) The Indians, contrary to the announcement that they were to work without the range of fire, had to fetch the Wounded from within the range, at times shells falling within hardly 100 yards of them, all this, of course, being unavoidably due to the unexpected reverseat Spion Kop and retirement from Vaalkranz.
('2', 353, 1, 10, 813750) The bearers and the leaders had to march with their charge to a distance of twenty five miles, from Spearman’s Camp to Frere, over the Natal roads which, as you are aware, are very rough and hilly, at one time doing a distance of over 125 miles in a week.
('2', 353, 1, 11, 814006) Moreover, our Indian merchants supplied cigarettes, etc., for the wounded, which was quite a feature of the Indian Corps.
('2', 353, 1, 12, 814128) Many Europeans who ought to know have told me that no European Ambulance Corps could cover the distance of twenty five miles, carrying the wounded under such difficult circumstances, in a single day, which our Indian bearers and their leaders did in the face of serious difficulties about food and shelter.
('2', 354, 0, 1, 814435) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 355
('2', 354, 1, 2, 814477) Not being satisfied with this work, and in order that our merchants may be still more effectively identified with the patriotic feeling, and in order to show that we were quite capable of sinking our local differences at a time of common danger, a substantial fund to the amount of £65 was collected by them and handed over to the Durban Women’s Patriotic League, which is a local organisation for supplying medical comforts to the wounded soldiers and volunteers, some of the latter being violently anti Indian Colonists.
('2', 354, 1, 3, 815000) Our Indian ladies prepared handkerchiefs and pillow cases out of cloth supplied by our merchants for the wounded.
('2', 354, 1, 4, 815114) All the Indian refugees, counting thousands, have been entirely supported by the Indian community—a fact that has elicited from the Mayor of Durban a public acknowledgement of gratefulness, and this fact becomes the more important in view of what is going on at present.
('2', 354, 1, 5, 815385) The Refugee Relief Committee find it very difficult to adequately maintain even the European refugees.
('2', 354, 1, 6, 815488) The Central Committee in London has cabled withdrawing the support hitherto given as well to the able bodied men as to the women and infirm men.
('2', 354, 1, 7, 815633) When the welcome news of the relief of Kimberley and Ladysmith was received, the Indians, side by side with the Europeans, marked their sense of joy by closing their shops, decorating their stores, etc.
('2', 354, 1, 8, 815836) They also held a public meeting.
('2', 354, 1, 9, 815869) Sir John Robinson, who was the first Prime Minister of Natal under responsible government, was invited to preside for the occasion, which invitation the Honourable gentleman very kindly accepted.
('2', 354, 1, 10, 816065) The meeting was a brilliant success and was attended by about 1,000 Indians representing all parts of the Colony, and over sixty leading Europeans.
('2', 354, 1, 11, 816213) India, 18 5 1900
('2', 354, 2, 12, 816230) 131. LETTER TO LEADERS OF AMBULANCE CORPS

('2', 357, 11, 10, 820120) 135. FAREWELL ADDRESS TO DR.
('2', 357, 11, 11, 820149) LANCELOT PARKER BOOTH 2
('2', 357, 12, 12, 820173) DURBAN, June 29, 1900
('2', 357, 13, 13, 820195) We the undersigned Indian subscribers place on record on the eve of your withdrawal from Indian work in this Colony, the sense of gratitude the Indian community owes you for your many acts of charity and kindness.
('2', 357, 13, 14, 820409) To the poor among us you have been a friend and benefactor, irrespective of creed or caste.
('2', 357, 13, 15, 820501) Many of us know from personal experience how we could rely upon your free medical assistance at all times.
('2', 357, 13, 16, 820608) Your gentleness and kind sympathy have often succeeded where medicine alone would fail.
('2', 357, 13, 17, 820696) The Indian Hospital,
('2', 357, 14, 18, 820717) 1 Vide “Letter to Colonial Secretary”, March 17, 1900. 2 This was drafted by Gandhiji on behalf of the Indian Community on the eve of Rev.
('2', 357, 14, 19, 820856) Booth’s departure from Cape Colony to take up an appointment in Umtata.
('2', 358, 0, 1, 820928) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 359
('2', 358, 1, 2, 820970) which was the direct result of your 17 years’ labour in alleviating human suffering, is a standing testimony to your work in that direction.
('2', 358, 1, 3, 821111) Your services in connection with the Indian Ambulance Corps, the training you were good enough to give the ambulance class, also much sacrifice of time, the willingness with which you offered to accompany the corps in spite of pressing duties in Durban, your medical aid to bearers at the front and your counsel to the leaders, can hardly be overvalued by the Indian community.
('2', 358, 1, 4, 821489) We may say without exaggeration that you have presented to us a pattern of an upright Englishman and good, gentle Christian who knows no distinction between Jew and Gentile.
('2', 358, 1, 5, 821663) The fact that half the number of Indian schools owe their existence to your energy is an indication of your efforts on behalf of the masses.
('2', 358, 1, 6, 821804) It is hard for us to tender you, unmixed with sorrow, our congratulations on your preferment.
('2', 358, 1, 7, 821898) Umtata’s gain is our loss.
('2', 358, 1, 8, 821925) You leave behind you a gap; it will be difficult to fill.
('2', 358, 1, 9, 821983) The congregation of your church may find an equally eloquent preacher and as safe a guide, but where shall your congregation find so faithful, sympathetic and tried a friend whom they have learnt to know and love for close upon two decades?
('2', 358, 1, 10, 822224) As a slight token of our esteem for you, we beg of you to accept this address and the accompanying purse for the benefit of your Indian Hospital.
('2', 358, 1, 11, 822370) We wish you and Mrs. Booth a happy time in your new sphere and pray that the Almighty may long spare you and your wife to continue your work of love.

('2', 359, 9, 10, 823511) 138. THE INDIAN FAMINE
('2', 359, 10, 11, 823534) DURBAN, July 30, 1900
('2', 359, 11, 12, 823556) TO THE EDITOR The Natal Advertiser
('2', 359, 13, 13, 823591) The Natal Emigration Agent at Calcutta has forwarded to the Protector of Indian Immigrants leaflets for distribution among the indentured Indians and those that have become free and settled in the Colony, appealing for funds in aid of the relief of the terrible famine now raging in India.
('2', 359, 13, 14, 823881) This appeal, in my opinion, has an awful meaning.
('2', 359, 13, 15, 823931) It shows the intensity of the calamity; it shows also that, in spite of the resources of a great Empire, it has been found necessary to ask even poor Indians to contribute their quota.
('2', 359, 13, 16, 824116) It will be recollected that in 1896, when India was visited by a widespread famine, a direct appeal was made to the Mayor in South Africa, to which a prompt response was made from all parts of the
('2', 359, 14, 17, 824313) 1 The circular bears several signatures in support of the proposal.
('2', 360, 0, 1, 824381) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 361
('2', 360, 1, 2, 824423) continent.
('2', 360, 1, 3, 824434) 1 This time, evidently, there has been no such direct appeal made, owing to the distress which we are undergoing ourselves.
('2', 360, 1, 4, 824558) The same cause has prevented the Indian community in Natal, which has narrowly kept itself in touch with the situation in India and which has so far contented itself with having forwarded subscriptions to the branch office in India, from placing it before the Colonists generally.
('2', 360, 1, 5, 824839) But the Viceroy of India has sent a fresh, pathetic appeal to the Lord Mayor of London, which urges every part of the great Empire to come to the rescue.
('2', 360, 1, 6, 824993) The receipt of copies of the appeal and the simultaneous arrival of the leaflets from Calcutta change the aspect very materially, and, in my humble opinion, makes it incumbent upon the Indian community here, not only to make a fresh effort itself, but also to bring the matter, at any rate, to the notice of the Colonists, so as to enable them to exercise the privilege (shall I call it) of helping millions of their starving fellow beings, who are, moreover, subjects of the same Queen as themselves.
('2', 360, 1, 7, 825495) It will be, at the same time, exceedingly improper to ignore the fact that the Colony has suffered, and will yet have to suffer, a great deal owing to the war.
('2', 360, 1, 8, 825655) But I may be pardoned for saying that our State is very prosperous compared to the miserable conditions of the millions in India, who have to be engaged in a war in which there is no victory to be gained, in which, probably, the only reward is a painful and lingering death.
('2', 360, 1, 9, 825930) One penny would just feed a man for a day in the disaster area in India.
('2', 360, 1, 10, 826003) Is there a man in theColony Who cannot, without any inconvenience, spare a shilling, and thus be the means of feeding 12 hungry mouths for a day?
('2', 360, 1, 11, 826149) Though, therefore, it is quite true that many individual members cannot give very large sums, hundreds, even thousands, can give at least a few shillings each.
('2', 360, 2, 12, 826309) The Lord Bishop of Natal has dwelt on the good that the War, bad as it is, has done, in that it has brought closer together the various parts of the mighty Empire to Which it is our pride to belong.
('2', 360, 2, 13, 826508) It may be that the threefold scourge in India—viz., famine, plague and cholera—black as it is, will be the means of forging another link in the chain that ties all together.
('2', 360, 3, 14, 826682) 1 Vide “Memorial to Secretary of State for the Colonies”, 15 3 1897. 2 In response to an appeal for funds by Sir John and others, over £2000 were subscribed by the Natal Europeans alone.
('2', 360, 3, 15, 826869) Vide “Notes,” post 3 9 1900, infra.
('2', 360, 3, 16, 826905) Later, in a letter to the Press, however, (Vide “The Famine Fund”, February 16, 1901, infra,) Gandhiji mentions that “about £3000 were contributed by the Europeans, £1700 by Indians, and £300 by the natives”.
('2', 361, 0, 1, 827114) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 362
('2', 361, 1, 2, 827156) Close on 6,000,000 of the famine stricken in India have to be daily supported through the State, not to mention the flow of private charity, which saves tens of thousands of lives.
('2', 361, 1, 3, 827337) Mr. Adamji Peerbhoy alone supported, according to The Times of India, during the month of May last, 16,300 men per day.
('2', 361, 1, 4, 827457) The number of those seeking relief, according to Dr. Klopsch, increases by 10,000 per day.
('2', 361, 1, 5, 827548) The welcome rains that have watered the greater part of the afflicted area, will, for the present, increase the numbers to be relieved and put a heavier strain on the resources of the State, both in men and money.
('2', 361, 1, 6, 827762) The plague has been doing its work of destruction unremittingly for the last four years, and the cholera fiend, the right hand of famine, has completed the havoc, Besides the various British Colonies and Settlements, America has raised a fund and sent a special representative, Dr. Klopsch, to administer it.
('2', 361, 1, 7, 828071) Germany has also come to the rescue.
('2', 361, 1, 8, 828108) India’s misery is such as all friends and strangers alike may assist in alleviating.
('2', 361, 1, 9, 828193) Why not Natal?
('2', 361, 1, 10, 828208) In conclusion, it is my pleasant duty to announce that His Excellency the Governor of Natal, the Honourable the Attorney General, and the Honourable Sir John Robinson have showed great sympathy for the starving millions of India, and promised to patronise any fund that may be raised on their behalf.
('2', 361, 2, 11, 828509) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI

('2', 366, 6, 6, 833897) 146. LETTER TO COLONIAL SECRETARY
('2', 366, 7, 7, 833931) 14, MERCURY LANE, DURBAN, August 18, 1900
('2', 366, 8, 8, 833973) TO THE HONOURABLE THE COLONIAL SECRETARY PIETERMARITZBURG
('2', 366, 9, 9, 834031) SIR, I have the honour to acknowledge your letter of the 14th instant regarding the application for a certificate of domicile for one Dosa Desa.
('2', 366, 9, 10, 834176) I regret to trouble you in the matter again.
('2', 366, 9, 11, 834221) I tried to obtain from the Immigration Restrictions Officer information as to the causes that led to the introduction of the rule in question, but failed.
('2', 366, 9, 12, 834376) It is quite possible that some people have abused the previous practice and if the abuse, assuming that it exists, was brought to the notice of the Indians generally, in my humble opinion, it could be mitigated, if not altogether stopped.
('2', 366, 9, 13, 834615) If affidavits have been made falsely, the culprits could be legally punished.
('2', 366, 9, 14, 834693) But the rule in question, though it may not be a hard and fast one, will, it is submitted, be a great hardship, especially to the poorer.
('2', 366, 9, 15, 834831) As it is, they are put to considerable expense in getting the certificates, but the new rule would put unnecessary obstacles in their way.
('2', 366, 9, 16, 834970) In practice, it is hardly possible to expect men to apply from India for certificates.
('2', 366, 9, 17, 835057) It takes as a rule 30 days and often longer for a letter to reach India and, if there was any flaw in an affidavit, it is difficult to say how long it would not take before a certificate could be issued.
('2', 366, 9, 18, 835261) Moreover, it is hardly to be expected that the limited number of Indians who may be known to the Immigration Officer as respectable could know the persons for whom
('2', 367, 0, 1, 835425) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 368
('2', 367, 1, 2, 835467) certificates of domicile may be required.
('2', 367, 1, 3, 835509) Under the circumstances, I submit that the rule should be withdrawn altogether and the ordinary procedure may be adopted to meet the abuse, if any, of the Immigration Restriction Act, 1 under the old practice of issuing certificates.
('2', 367, 1, 4, 835743) I may mention that my client, the applicant for the certificate, Dosa Desa, is much inconvenienced owing to the delay in obtaining the certificate.
('2', 367, 2, 5, 835891) I have the honour to be,
('2', 367, 4, 6, 835916) your obedient servant, M. K. GANDHI

('2', 367, 9, 15, 836771) I venture to think that the innovation is causing an amount of inconvenience the measure of which the Government do not realize.
