('2', 369, 0, 1, 838172) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 370
('2', 369, 1, 2, 838214) 149. NOTES
('2', 369, 2, 3, 838225) NOTES ON THE PRESENT POSITION OF THE BRITISH INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA 1
('2', 369, 3, 4, 838296) [Post September 3, 1900] 2
('2', 369, 4, 5, 838323) A suggestion has been made that the friends in England of the Indian settlers in South Africa should be put in possession of the latest facts regarding their grievances, so as to enable them to place the matter for consideration before the proper authorities, in view of the pending settlement of South African affairs.
('2', 369, 4, 6, 838643) It has also been suggested that a memorial to the Colonial Secretary, backed up by public meetings, should be promoted in order that it may strengthen the hands of the workers in England.
('2', 369, 4, 7, 838831) After mature consideration, the latter plan has been dropped.
('2', 369, 4, 8, 838893) There are sound reasons for the belief that, if adopted, it will be misunderstood here, where the feeling is that until the war is over, and the troubles attendant thereon have entirely disappeared, no questions not arising from the war should be discussed or considered.
('2', 369, 4, 9, 839165) Moreover, it is likely that a memorial at the present time would disturb the happy relations which, for the time being, appear to subsist between the European and the Indian communities.
('2', 369, 4, 10, 839352) It is most difficult to say what the future would bring, and whether the old soreness would not be revived as soon as peace is restored.
('2', 369, 4, 11, 839489) Indeed, there are grounds for the fear that there will be no change in the former attitude.
('2', 369, 4, 12, 839581) The Natal Witness only a few days ago, in the course of a leading article, said that the services rendered by the local Indians, as ambulance men and otherwise, should not be allowed to blind the Colonists to the necessity of keeping an ever vigilant eye en the Indian question, and seeing that the temporary military occupation under Lord Roberts who, owing to his Indian connexion, might entertain pro Indian views, is not permitted to encroach upon the position Natal has hitherto maintained successfully in restricting Indian immigration and enterprise, and that the services referred to above were rather an acknowledgement by the Indians of the justice of Natal’s position than that they were rendered in spite of their
('2', 369, 5, 13, 840307) 1 This was published in India, 12 10 1900, as from “a Natal Correspondent” 2 This date has been arrived at on the basis of references in the “Notes” to the immigration Restriction Act (vide “Notes”, 3 9 1900, infra), a specific case under which was dealt with in the letters to the Colonial Secretary dated July 31, August 18 and 30, and September 3, 1900.
('2', 370, 0, 1, 840664) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 371
('2', 370, 1, 2, 840706) legitimate grievances.
('2', 370, 1, 3, 840729) The Indians formed a Volunteer Stretcher bearer Corps of over 1,000, each bearer drawing £1 per week, i.e., a little over half the pay drawn by the European stretcher bearers, assisted by over 30 leaders who served without any remuneration whatsoever, and included the most respectable portion of the community, and who left their business or employment to serve their Empress.
('2', 370, 1, 4, 841107) When they did so, it was clearly stated that it was done in spite of the grievances, because they felt it their duty, at a time like that, to sink the domestic differences.
('2', 370, 1, 5, 841280) The Indian merchants, if they could not join the Corps, equipped the leaders and maintained the families of such of them as stood in need of help.
('2', 370, 1, 6, 841427) The Corps served at the fateful battles of Colenso, Spion Kop and Vaalkranz.
('2', 370, 1, 7, 841504) High praise has been bestowed on the work done by it.
('2', 370, 1, 8, 841558) Sir John Robinson the first Prime Minister of Natal—has thus spoken of its services: With reference to the part played by the Indian community during the crisis, I can only say that it redounds to the credit and patriotism of you all.
('2', 370, 1, 9, 841793) Reasons which you can well understand forbade the employment of any but British troops in the battle field.
('2', 370, 1, 10, 841901) But whatever use could be made of your loyal ardour —what opportunity could be afforded to your eager desire to co operate in the Empire’s cause—was gladly agreed to by the authorities.
('2', 370, 1, 11, 842087) Though you were debarred from actual service in the field, you were able to do excellent work in succouring the wounded.
('2', 370, 1, 12, 842208) I cannot too warmly thank your able countryman, Mr. Gandhi, upon his timely, unselfish and most useful action in voluntarily organising a corps of bearers for ambulance work at the front at a moment when their labours were sorely needed in discharging arduous duties which experience showed to be by no means devoid of peril.
('2', 370, 1, 13, 842534) All engaged in that service deserve the grateful recognition of the community.
('2', 370, 1, 14, 842613) The Indians contributed what has been called a handsome sum (over £57) to the funds of the Women’s Patriotic League, of which The Natal Marcury says: This gift of money for the Women’s Patriotic Fund, especially for the purpose of assisting in the care of sick and wounded volunteers at the front, is a very acceptable and eloquent expression of the feeling of the Indian people.
('2', 370, 1, 15, 842993) It is not enough, in their minds, to succour the large mass of Indian refugees, as they are doing in an open handed manner, but they must bestow this added contribution, we believe, as a token of their devotion to the Queen Empress and to the country in which they have come to reside.
('2', 370, 1, 16, 843279) Nothing can better show the real feeling that animates this portion of our population, who too often have very little said on their behalf, than such a display of loyalty.
('2', 370, 1, 17, 843451) The Indian ladies gave their work in the shape of making
('2', 371, 0, 1, 843508) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 372
('2', 371, 1, 2, 843550) pillowcases, handkerchiefs, etc., for the wounded out of cloth supplied by the Indian merchants over and above the above contribution.
('2', 371, 1, 3, 843685) The Indians throughout the trying times also maintained thousands of their fellow countrymen, refugees from the Transvaal and the parts of the Colony in Boer occupation, practically without encroaching upon the funds sent from London and raised locally, and administered by the Refugee Relief Committee.
('2', 371, 1, 4, 843989) The Mayor of Durban has acknowledged that service in the following words (spoken in March last): The Mayor took the opportunity of thanking the Indian community for their loyalty during the last four months or so.
('2', 371, 1, 5, 844203) Many of their people had been compelled to leave their abodes in the upper parts of the Colony, and had come down here for refuge.
('2', 371, 1, 6, 844334) These they had taken amongst themselves; and borne the burden of maintenance at their own expense.
('2', 371, 1, 7, 844433) For that he thanked them sincerely.
('2', 371, 2, 8, 844469) It may be stated, without any affectation, that these services have been rendered without any intention to secure any reward.
('2', 371, 2, 9, 844595) If we claimed privileges as British subjects we could not very well shirk the duties of such subjects, which the very humble services undoubtedly were, and, therefore, could carry no reward.
('2', 371, 2, 10, 844786) It might be worthy of note that the local Indians were not behind hand in materially assisting the Indian Camp Followers’ Fund, initiated by Captain Leumann, I.M.S. They subscribed over £50, and the Colonial born Indians gave an amateur performance, handing to it the net proceeds thereof to the extent of over £20. As an illustration of the happy relations may be mentioned the great meeting held by the Indians to congratulate the British Generals on the relief of Ladysmith and Kimberley, which was presided over by Sir John Robinson, and attended by over fifty leading European citizens; also, the extremely generous response made by the Europeans in Natal to an appeal for the famine stricken masses of India, over £2,000 being subscribed by them alone.
('2', 371, 2, 11, 845545) The Governor is the Patron of the Fund, the Mayor of Durban is the Chairman, the Protector of Indian Immigrants the honorary treasurer, an Indian gentleman the honorary secretary, and leading European planters and merchants on the Committee—a combination that might have been impossible a year ago.
('2', 371, 2, 12, 845844) The above remarks on the feeling regarding the British Indiansin Natal clears the ground for a statement of grievances.
('2', 371, 2, 13, 845964) It may be as well to read the following summary side by side with the circular
('2', 372, 0, 1, 846043) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 373
('2', 372, 1, 2, 846085) letter dated 27th March, 1897. 1
('2', 372, 2, 3, 846118) As to the Transvaal and the Orange River Colony, nothing need be said at present, except that it may be confidently expected that none of the grievances which, owing to the past status of the two States, the Colonial Office declared itself powerless to redress however much it sympathised with the Indians, will be allowed to exist in the slightest degree under the new regime where there would not have to be considered even the sentiments of a self governing Colony as in the case of Natal.
('2', 372, 2, 4, 846611) Zululand, now being part and parcel of Natal, does not require separate mention, though it may be stated that the regulations prohibiting Indian bids at land sales when it was directly under the Crown were withdrawn before it was incorporated with this Colony.
('2', 372, 2, 5, 846872) In Natal, the position remains unchanged.
('2', 372, 2, 6, 846914) The Immigration Restriction Act is still being enforced as vigorously as it could be under the circumstances.
('2', 372, 2, 7, 847024) A short statement of its working may not be out of place.
('2', 372, 2, 8, 847082) Under it, no person who is unable to write out, in any of the European languages, an application in the form attached to the Act, can enter the Colony unless he has been previously domiciled.
('2', 372, 2, 9, 847274) Notices, for which there is no sanction in the Act itself, have been issued to the shipping companies warning them against taking Indian passengers for Natal unless they are armed with certificates of domicile, which were at first issued free of charge on a verbal application either by the person himself or by his friends.
('2', 372, 2, 10, 847599) A charge of 2s.
('2', 372, 2, 11, 847615) was then introduced for its issue.
('2', 372, 2, 12, 847650) Later on, an affidavit of proof of domicile was required.
('2', 372, 2, 13, 847708) Then two affidavits were insisted upon, and proof that the applicant for the certificate had been resident in the Colony at least two years; and the latest innovation is that either the person wishing to enter the Colony must himself apply for a certificate of domicile, or persons of known respectability should tender, under oath, proof of domicile.
('2', 372, 2, 14, 848060) Thus, it will be seen that the cordon of restriction has grown tighter with the lapse of time.
('2', 372, 2, 15, 848155) The practical effect of the working of all this is that all but the well to do are shut out of the Colony.
('2', 372, 2, 16, 848262) As to this, it is contended for the Government that it would be no hardship for the persons requiring certificates of domicile to make the application under their own
('2', 372, 3, 17, 848429) 1 Vide “Letter to The Natal Mercury”, 15 11 1897.
('2', 373, 0, 1, 848479) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 374
('2', 373, 1, 2, 848521) signatures, as they could always take them out before leaving the Colony.
('2', 373, 1, 3, 848595) Such an argument would be perfectly sound if the innovation were to affect only those that may hereafter leave the Colony.
('2', 373, 1, 4, 848718) But it is positively harmful for those that are outside the Colony.
('2', 373, 1, 5, 848786) A person in India requiring such a certificate may have to wait one year before he could get it.
('2', 373, 1, 6, 848883) The postal service between India and South Africa is as irregular as it could be; and there is no guarantee that the receipt, by the Immigration Officer, of an application invariably insures the issue of the domicile paper.
('2', 373, 1, 7, 849107) For, as has often happened before, it is not at all unlikely that it may have to be returned several times to India for some flaw therein—imaginary or real.
('2', 373, 1, 8, 849264) Theoretically, the shipping companies: may defy the notices which have no legal force; and the Indians claiming admission may not take out domicile certificates which are not required by law.
('2', 373, 1, 9, 849456) In practice, the shipping companies resolutely decline to issue passages except on production of certificates above referred to; so much so, that it is very difficult for those who write out the English application to obtain a passage, because they cannot produce a domicile certificate, and the shipping companies would not look at the provision exempting such persons from the operation of the Act.
('2', 373, 1, 10, 849857) The reason given for introducing such elaborate restrictions is that they are necessary to prevent evasions of the law; and it may be admitted that some evasions have occurred.
('2', 373, 1, 11, 850034) It is, however, submitted that they ought not to be used as a handle for making unduly harsh a law which is, in its very nature, severe, and committing what is a breach of the fundamental principles of the British Constitution.
('2', 373, 1, 12, 850262) The evasions should be publicly denounced and, if necessary, punished, for which there is ample provision made in the Act itself.
('2', 373, 1, 13, 850392) Unfortunately, the latter course has not been adopted, with the result that the innocent have to suffer for the lapse of the few guilty persons.
('2', 373, 1, 14, 850537) Everything that could be done locally to induce the authorities to relax the severity has been and is being done; and it would be unfair to omit to mention that the authorities have endeavoured in a measure to meet the wishes of the Indian community.
('2', 373, 1, 15, 850788) Much more can, however, be done, if not now, at any rate after the war is over, by pressure of the Colonial Office to which the Government has been found to be amenable in the past.
('2', 373, 1, 16, 850970) Another effect of the Act is that it imposes vexatious restrictions on those who intend to pass through, or sojourn temporarily in the Colony, neither of which acts is prohibited by law.
('2', 373, 1, 17, 851157) The Government, however, in order to prevent surreptitious settlement of Indians in the
('2', 374, 0, 1, 851245) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 375
('2', 374, 1, 2, 851287) Colony have, perhaps rightly, introduced what are called Visiting and Embarkation passes.
('2', 374, 1, 3, 851377) The objection, therefore, is not so much to the introduction of the passes as to the conditions under which they are issued.
('2', 374, 1, 4, 851502) Formerly, a deposit of £25 for Embarkation passes was required, and a fee of £1 for either a Visiting or Embarkation pass.
('2', 374, 1, 5, 851625) The Government, however, in answer to Indian representations, were pleased to reduce the £25 to £10, and withdrew the £1 fee.
('2', 374, 1, 6, 851751) The £10 deposit, however, still stands, much to the inconvenience of intending visitors, not all of whom could afford to deposit the sum, small as it may appear in the estimation of the Government.
('2', 374, 1, 7, 851949) It was this Act that was instrumental in sending away a shipload of Indian refugees from the Transvaal from Delagoa Bay, who would fain have come to Natal, and thus saved not only the passage money from India to Delagoa Bay for their return after the war, but not have been also a burden to the already overpressed famine stricken India.
('2', 374, 1, 8, 852287) The other Act, not by any means the next in importance, but rather the worst of all, is the Dealers’ Licenses Act, only at the present time its effect is not much felt.
('2', 374, 1, 9, 852456) The country beyond the Tugela is yet under semi military government.
('2', 374, 1, 10, 852525) The Newcastle, Ladysmith and Dundee Corporations which gained, in 1898, unenviable notoriety for the harsh and oppressive way in which they enforced the Act, have not been able to shake themselves free from the misery caused by the Boer occupation.
('2', 374, 1, 11, 852774) In Durban and Maritzburg, the Licensing Officers have not given much trouble.
('2', 374, 1, 12, 852852) What will happen in January next, at the time of the renewal of licenses, it is difficult to foresee.
('2', 374, 1, 13, 852954) The poor traders, however,: are already trembling in their shoes because of the great uncertainty in which the Act leaves them from year’s end to year’s end.
('2', 374, 1, 14, 853112) The friends in London may recollect that Mr. Chamberlain has approached the Natal Government, suggesting that they should introduce legislation repealing the clause depriving the Supreme Court of the ordinary appellate jurisdiction over the decisions of the Licensing Officers or the Corporation, as the case may be; and that the Natal Government have written to the various municipalities.
('2', 374, 1, 15, 853503) informing them that, unless they judiciously exercised their powers under the Act, they might have to introduce legislation of the nature above indicated.
('2', 374, 1, 16, 853658) This may be good so far as it goes, but it is sincerely hoped that it has not satisfied the Colonial Office.
('2', 374, 1, 17, 853767) The least that is necessary is the removal of the terrible uncertainty that hangs, like the sword of Damocles, over every Indian licensee; and this can only be done by restoring the authority of the Supreme Court.
('2', 375, 0, 1, 853981) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 376
('2', 375, 1, 2, 854023) was (and very rightly) a howl of indignation when Mr. Kruger usurped the function of the High Court at Pretoria; but perhaps the very rottenness of the Transvaal Constitution was somewhat a safeguard from any real danger from such usurpation.
('2', 375, 1, 3, 854266) But in Natal, where there are all the safeguards of a well ordered Constitution, the deprivation of the jurisdiction of the highest Court of Justice in the land makes the danger terribly real and tangible, because it receives the solemn sanction of the legislature.
('2', 375, 1, 4, 854532) The truth of these remarks will be fully borne out by recalling to the mind what has been possible in the Transvaal in spite of the vagaries of its laws and what the Town Councils, free from the healthy restrictions Of their Courts which, as British bodies, they are bound to fear and respect, have been able and attempted to do.
('2', 375, 1, 5, 854862) War has prevented an approach to the Colonial Office in this matter.
('2', 375, 1, 6, 854931) While correspondence on the subject with the local Government was going on, war broke out; and it was considered prudent to stay further action till the cloud melted away.
('2', 375, 1, 7, 855103) The 9 o’clock rule, and numerous other troubles referred to in the circular letter, need not be recapitulated here.
('2', 375, 1, 8, 855219) They but serve to show what the Indians have to suffer in the Colony.
('2', 375, 1, 9, 855289) We would give much to find ourselves in reality at one with the Colonists as we are on paper, being British.
('2', 375, 1, 10, 855398) subjects; and it will be time enough to trouble our friends in London with the comparatively smaller troubles when the Immigration Restriction and the Dealers’ Licenses Acts have ceased to worry us.
('2', 375, 1, 11, 855597) One thing is day by day causing much soreness of feeling, and that is the education of the Indian youths.
('2', 375, 1, 12, 855703) The Government, which is ruled by the majority, perhaps not unnaturally finds itself powerless to assist the Indians.
('2', 375, 1, 13, 855821) The result is, the Indian children are entirely shut out of the ordinary primary schools as well as the high schools.
('2', 375, 1, 14, 855939) The Head Master of the Durban High School is said to have written, some time ago, to the Minister of Education, to the effect that parents would withdraw their children if an Indian was admitted.
('2', 375, 1, 15, 856135) It is, however, submitted that the Colonial Office should make it clear to the local Government that the Indians have an equal right with the Europeans in the Colony to receive education in the Government schools which are supported by taxes paid as well by the Indians as by the Europeans.
('2', 375, 1, 16, 856426) For the logical consequence of the threat (it is nothing less) held out by the Head Master would be that the Indians might
('2', 376, 0, 1, 856549) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 377
('2', 376, 1, 2, 856591) have absolutely no status if it were carried out in every department of life in the Colony.
('2', 376, 1, 3, 856683) What would prevent a ring of European merchants, under the threat of clearing out from a particular street in a commercial centre in the Colony, from asking the Government to drive out an Indian merchant or two from their neighbourhood?

('2', 376, 6, 10, 857562) SI R, As soon as the intention of the Council to introduce a bye law making it an offence for a riksha hauler to take up a coloured passenger in a riksha labelled for “Europeans only” was known, many Indians asked me to draw up a protest, but I felt at the time that it would not be proper to do so.
('2', 376, 6, 11, 857862) I thought it would be inconsistent with the self respect of the Indian community to wish to insist on having the right to use the same riksha used by the Europeans if the latter objected to share it with the Indians, so long as the same kind of vehicle was available to the Indians also.
('2', 376, 6, 12, 858150) But I have now begun to feel
('2', 376, 7, 13, 858179) 1 The two memorials, the general letter (“Petition to Natal Governor”) and the special articles referred to have been given in this Volume in their chronological sequence.
('2', 377, 0, 1, 858351) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 378
('2', 377, 1, 2, 858393) that I committed a grave error in proffering the above advice.
('2', 377, 1, 3, 858456) The practical working of the bye law has created and is creating an irritation among the Indians of all classes which it would be folly on my part not to bring to the notice of the Council.
('2', 377, 1, 4, 858646) I freely confess that the problem is not easy of solution.
('2', 377, 1, 5, 858705) Yet it may not be altogether insoluble.
('2', 377, 1, 6, 858745) In this communication it is not my intention to raise the legal question though I humbly believe that the bye law is illegal.
('2', 377, 1, 7, 858871) I wish, if possible, to obtain partial relief by appealing to the good sense of the Council.
('2', 377, 1, 8, 858964) I trust that what is objected to is not so much the colour of a fare as his dirty clothes or appearance.
('2', 377, 1, 9, 859069) If so, might it not be possible to give instructions to the haulers not to take such fares?
('2', 377, 1, 10, 859161) I am told that the haulers are shrewd enough to understand and carry out such instructions.
('2', 377, 1, 11, 859253) The suggestion is obviously difficult, and will by no means be free from hard ships and injustice but it is likely to allay the present acute soreness.
('2', 377, 1, 12, 859405) The very rigorous working of the bye law may defeat its own object, and in my humble opinion, it can only be worked without friction if its application is very largely tempered with discretion.
('2', 377, 1, 13, 859599) It is, I submit, no small thing that hundreds of coloured people who have hitherto freely used the rikshas as a mode of conveyance, suddenly find themselves de barred from its use; for I understand that there are very few rikshas without the label above referred to.
('2', 377, 1, 14, 859866) May I ask you to place this before His Worship the Mayor and the Council Committee at the earliest possible opportunity and hope that it will receive the consideration that its subject matter deserves?
('2', 377, 1, 15, 860068) I trustI also that it will be considered in the spirit in which it is written.

('2', 382, 6, 14, 868869) 156. SPEECH AT INDIAN SCHOOL
('2', 382, 7, 15, 868898) The following is a brief press report of the mid summer breaking up function of the Higher Grade Indian School, Durban.
('2', 382, 7, 16, 869018) December 21, 1900 Mr. Gandhi, in speaking of the headmaster’s work, said that the best of institutions would suffer if there were not men to give life to them.
('2', 382, 7, 17, 869178) This was well illustrated in the case of the Higher Grade Indian School.
('2', 382, 7, 18, 869251) The Indian parents had to thank the Government for presenting the school with Mr. Connolly, who had made the school his own.
('2', 382, 7, 19, 869376) Even Mrs. Connolly assisted him id his great work, and his
('2', 382, 8, 20, 869435) 1 Hamid Gool, a leading Indian of Cape Town.
('2', 383, 0, 1, 869480) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 384
('2', 383, 1, 2, 869522) brother, who had lately arrived from England, was kind enough to place his voice at the disposal of the school.
('2', 383, 1, 3, 869634) The Indians had to thank Mr. Connolly and his staff very much for their zeal and devotion.
('2', 383, 1, 4, 869725) With reference to the gymnasium, he ventured to suggest that a movable and portable set of single and double bars and sets of dumb bells could, for very little expense, be procured, and would in a measure compensate for the want of a suitable ground.
('2', 383, 1, 5, 869976) Credit could not be withheld from Mr. Paul for inducing the parents to avail themselves of the school for their children.

('2', 383, 3, 7, 870131) 157. PETITION TO NATAL GOVERNOR
('2', 383, 4, 8, 870163) DURBAN, prior to December 24, 1900
('2', 383, 5, 9, 870198) TO HIS EXCELLENCY THE HONOURABLE SIR WALTER FRANCIS HELY HUTCHINSON, KNIGHT GRAND CROSS OF THE MOST DISTINGUISHED ORDER OF SAINT MICHAEL AND SAINT GEORGE, GOVERNOR AND COMMANDER IN CHIEF IN AND OVER THE COLONY OF NATAL, VICE ADMIRAL OF THE SAME, AND SUPREME CHIEF OVER THE NATIVE POPULATION
('2', 383, 6, 10, 870489) THE HUMBLE PETITION OF THE UNDERSIGNED, REPRESENTING
('2', 383, 7, 11, 870542) THE BRITISH INDIANS RESIDENT IN DURBAN
('2', 383, 8, 12, 870581) HUMBLY SHEWETH,
('2', 383, 9, 13, 870597) That your petitioners beg to draw Your Excellency’s attention to the enclosed Bye law passed recently by the Durban Town Council and approved by Your Excellency.
('2', 383, 9, 14, 870759) At the time the said Bye law was proposed to be published, the Indians who generally use the rickshas were alarmed, but it was then hoped that the Bye law would not be so enforced as to apply to all non Europeans without distinction.
('2', 383, 9, 15, 870993) Your Petitioners thought that, if the European community did not wish the Indians to make use of the same rickshas as they, the latter consistently with their self respect could not take exception to such attitude so long as there remained a sufficient number of rickshas not set apart for the exclusive use of any particular
('2', 384, 0, 1, 871319) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 385
('2', 384, 1, 2, 871361) community.
('2', 384, 1, 3, 871372) In practice, however, it has been found, during the short time the Bye law has been in operation, that it is extremely difficult to find a ricksha without the label “For Europeans Only”.
('2', 384, 1, 4, 871559) For a time, and only for a time, no particular hardship was felt as there were a number of rickshas without the above label and the police did not unduly interfere with the ricksha “boys” carrying people cleanly dressed.
('2', 384, 1, 5, 871780) The thing, however, was soon changed as the Town Council gave definite instructions to the police to rigorously enforce the said Bye law, with the result that a very large number of, your Petitioners venture to call, cleanly dressed Indians suddenly found themselves deprived of the use of the above vehicles to their great inconvenience and annoyance.
('2', 384, 1, 6, 872133) The Town Council was approached with a view, not to obtain a cancellation of the Bye law, but such enforcement thereof as not to deprive the Indians altogether of use of the rickshas.
('2', 384, 2, 7, 872317) The Town Council has, however, declined to accede to the request.
('2', 384, 2, 8, 872383) Your Petitioners venture to submit that the said Bye law is illegal in terms of Section 75 of Law No.
('2', 384, 2, 9, 872485) 19 of 1872, as it is opposed to the general spirit of the British Constitution and the Laws of the Colony.
('2', 384, 2, 10, 872592) By reason of the premises, your Petitioners pray that the said Bye law may be cancelled or amended so as not to cause the inconvenience complained of.
('2', 384, 2, 11, 872743) And for this act of justice and mercy, your Petitioners shall for ever pray &c.
('2', 384, 3, 12, 872823) M. C. CAMROODEEN & CO.,
('2', 384, 4, 13, 872847) AND TWENTY FIVE OTHERS
('2', 384, 5, 14, 872870) Durban Town Council Records, 1901.
('2', 384, 6, 15, 872905) 1 Vide “Letter to Town Clerk”, September 24, 1900

('2', 388, 6, 11, 877531) 166. THE FAMINE FUND 1
('2', 388, 7, 12, 877554) 14, MERCURY LANE, DURBAN, February 16, 1901
('2', 388, 8, 13, 877598) DEAR SIR,
('2', 388, 9, 14, 877608) Now that the Famine Fund raised in the Colony is closed, it may be as well to give you its genesis.
('2', 388, 9, 15, 877708) While the Indian community was agitating itself whether it would be possible, as in 1897, in spite of thepresent distressing circumstances in South Africa, to make an effort, the Viceroy’s letter to the Lord Mayor of London for further help was published in the local papers, and, almost simultaneously with this, came a request to the Protector of Indian Immigrants from the Natal Agent at Calcutta to collect subscriptions from the indentured Indians.
('2', 388, 9, 16, 878162) We thereupon bestirred ourselves, and, on behalf of the Indian community, H. E. the Governor was approached with a view to secure his patronage.
('2', 388, 9, 17, 878307) He most graciously consented to become the Patron of any such fund that might be raised in that behalf and promised to head the list with £20. The Hon.
('2', 388, 9, 18, 878459) Sir John Robinson, ex Premier of Natal, and the Hon.
('2', 388, 9, 19, 878512) Henry Bale, the Attorney General of Natal, very actively espoused the movement.
('2', 388, 9, 20, 878592) A strong Central Committee was formed with the Mayor of Durban as Chairman and
('2', 388, 10, 21, 878671) 1 This letter, which appeared in India, 15 3 1901, and in Gujarati in Mumbai Samachar 16 3 1901, was addressed to the Press in general.
('2', 389, 0, 1, 878807) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 390
('2', 389, 1, 2, 878849) the Protector of Immigrants as Honorary Treasurer, and an appeal for funds was made in the papers which, too, rendered great help.
('2', 389, 1, 3, 878980) A local artist drew up a realistic cartoon which The Natal Mercury consented to issue as a special.
('2', 389, 1, 4, 879080) The excellent pictorial representations of The Times of India were pressed into service.
('2', 389, 1, 5, 879169) The result was that nearly £5,000 were collected, of which about £3,000 were contributed by the Europeans, £1,700 by the Indians and £300 by the natives.
('2', 389, 1, 6, 879323) The magistrates in the various divisions, chairmen of Local Boards, the clergy and a band of Indian workers, besides the Committee members, vied with one another in making collections.
('2', 389, 1, 7, 879508) Lady Robinson, supported by her friends, also rendered valuable help.
('2', 389, 1, 8, 879578) Colour prejudice was for the time being forgotten, and the best traits of the character of the community were, in this instance, brought into play.
('2', 389, 1, 9, 879726) In 1897, the European contribution to the famine fund was over £200 and the Indian was about £1,200—there was no organization formed then for collections among the Europeans.
('2', 389, 1, 10, 879901) The Viceroy has acknowledged the generosity of Natal in very suitable terms.
('2', 389, 3, 11, 879978) yours truly, M. K. GANDHI
('2', 389, 4, 12, 880004) From the photostat of the office copy: S. N. 3777.

('2', 390, 6, 7, 880953) 169. TO HEADS OF INDIAN SCHOOLS
('2', 390, 7, 8, 880985) (A Circular Letter) DURBAN, March 19, 1901
('2', 390, 8, 9, 881028) DEAR SIR, As you know, Mr. Russell delivered an address to the Indian children in the Town Hall on the reign of our late beloved Kaiser i Hind, and a memorial souvenir 1 was presented on behalf of the Indian community to the children.
('2', 390, 8, 10, 881263) The Committee consider that the other Indian children, too, who could not possibly attend the function, should receive the souvenir.
('2', 390, 8, 11, 881396) It is worth preserving, and I would suggest that one copy should be framed and hung in the schoolroom, and each pupil should be induced either to frame it, if he can afford it, or neatly paste it on a nice piece of thick cardboard and hang it in his room.
('2', 390, 8, 12, 881652) Will you kindly let me know how many pupils you have in your school so that I may post the number of copies?
('2', 390, 8, 13, 881761) If you can induce local storekeepers to decently frame and exhibit it in their show window, a few more copies could be sent.
('2', 390, 8, 14, 881886) At the same time, as we have only a limited supply, I would ask you to be good enough to restrict yourself to the exact number required.
('2', 390, 9, 15, 882023) 1 This souvenir consisted of: a photograph of Queen Victoria, with an extract from her Proclamation of 1858 to the people of India, at the top; and six dates in her lifes in relation to India, at the bottom; a map of India in 1901 showing it, in its entirety, as a British possession, and her remark “I will be good”, then she was informed at the age of 12, that she was the future Queen of England.
('2', 391, 0, 1, 882423) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 392
('2', 391, 1, 2, 882465) May I also suggest that you should carefully study Mr. Russell’s address and discourse upon it to your pupils, so that they may have a fairly good idea of the ever memorable reign.
('2', 391, 2, 3, 882646) Yours faithfully, M. K. GANDHI
('2', 391, 3, 4, 882677) From the photostat of the office copy: S. N. 3789.

('2', 393, 2, 3, 885525) 14, MERCURY LANE, DURBAN, March 30, 1901
('2', 393, 3, 4, 885566) TO THE COLONIAL SECRETARY PIETERMARITZBURG
('2', 393, 5, 5, 885609) A kind friend has sent me a copy [of an] extract from General Buller’s dispatch wherein among the officers mentioned is included my name, described as “Mr. Gandhi, Asst.
('2', 393, 5, 6, 885779) Indian Ambulance Corps.” If the extract is complete, according to my correspondent, no more officers of that Corps are thus mentioned.
('2', 393, 5, 7, 885914) If that be so, and if the credit given is to the Assistant Superintendent as such, it belongs to Mr. Shire, who was the only Gentleman in the Corps recognised as such.
('2', 393, 5, 8, 886082) And if the description of the office is of no consequence and if I am entitled to any credit for having done my duty, it is due in a greater measure to Dr. Booth, now Dean of St. John’s, and to Mr. Shire, who spared no pains in making the Corps the success it proved to be.
('2', 393, 5, 9, 886356) If I may venture to estimate their work, it is due to them to state that Dr. Booth’s services as Medical Officer in particular and adviser and guide in general were simply inestimable, and Mr. Shire’s were equally so in connection especially with the internal administration and discipline.
('2', 393, 5, 10, 886647) May I ask you to bring the contents of this communication to the notice of the Military Authorities.
('2', 393, 6, 11, 886748) I have the honour to be,
('2', 393, 8, 12, 886773) your obedient servant, M. K. GANDHI
('2', 393, 9, 13, 886809) Pietermaritzburg Archives: C. S. O. 1901/2888.
('2', 393, 10, 14, 886856) 1 The Commanding Officer Natal, in a letter to the Principal Under Secretary, commented on this as follows: “I think this was meant as a compliment to Mr. Gandhi’s nationality, of which the Bearer Corps was formed.
('2', 393, 10, 15, 887071) No doubt the work of the other gentlemen was equally of great value, but it is difficult to include all names.” The Colonial Secretary’s reply of April 16, acknowledged by Gandhiji in his letter of April 18, (vide the next page) is not available.

('2', 395, 0, 1, 888392) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 396
('2', 395, 1, 2, 888434) 176. A CIRCULAR LETTER 1
('2', 395, 2, 3, 888459) DURBAN, April 20, 1901
('2', 395, 4, 4, 888482) The position of the British Indians in the Transvaal and the Orange River Colony is sufficiently serious to call for a statement from us to enable you to move in the matter.
('2', 395, 4, 5, 888656) It will be recollected that Mr. Chamberlain has lately announced that the legislation of the late South African Republic and the Orange Free State would, “so far as possible”, be adopted by the Imperial Government.
('2', 395, 4, 6, 888871) The question at once arose in our minds whether the legislation of the old governments was included in the qualifying clause “so far as possible”.
('2', 395, 4, 7, 889018) If present regime is any test of the future, then, indeed, the question has been solved for us to the horror of every Indian in South Africa.
('2', 395, 4, 8, 889160) The whole of the anti Indian legislation in the Transvaal is being enforced with a rigour unknown before.
('2', 395, 4, 9, 889266) The laxity of the late Government was totally in our favour.
('2', 395, 4, 10, 889327) Though the Location Law was there, and the cab regulations, footpath and numerous other bye laws existed in the Statute book, they were more or less a dead letter.
('2', 395, 4, 11, 889491) The enforcement of the Location Law, although often threatened, was never carried out as against the respectable Indians, the storekeepers and others, and only a few—very few—actually suffered the indignity of the footpath and other bye laws.
('2', 395, 4, 12, 889734) All is now changed.
('2', 395, 4, 13, 889754) Every anti Indian ordinance of the late Government is being unearthed, and, with strict British regularity, applied to the victims.
('2', 395, 4, 14, 889886) The handful of poor Indians that were unable to leave the Transvaal before the war broke out, and who are therefore now there, have protested against the enforcement, but so far in vain.
('2', 395, 4, 15, 890073) The following telegram was forwarded to His Excellency the High Commissioner on the 25th March last: To Private Secretary, His Excellency High Commissioner: Some British Indians, who are at present in Pretoria and Johannesburg, write to Indian Refugee Committee saying they have received notice to remove to Locations, they are not allowed walk on footpaths, and that generally anti Indian laws of the late Republic are being strictly enforced.
('2', 395, 4, 16, 890518) I am requested respectfully to draw His Excellency’s attention to the admission of His Majesty’s Government that
('2', 395, 5, 17, 890631) 1 This was addressed to select friends of India in England.
('2', 395, 5, 18, 890691) A copy was also sent to the Secretary of State for the Colonies.
('2', 395, 5, 19, 890756) It was published in India, 24 5 1901, with minor changes, as “from a Correspondent”.
('2', 396, 0, 1, 890841) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 397
('2', 396, 1, 2, 890883) such laws are objectionable and the statement that they would endeavour to have them repealed.
('2', 396, 1, 3, 890978) The laws, it appears, were never it appears, were never under the old regime enforced asstrictly as they now are and, pending general settlement, Committee prays for relief.
('2', 396, 1, 4, 891152) We are anxiously awaiting reply; but the non receipt of any reply till now forebodes, we are afraid, disappointment.
('2', 396, 1, 5, 891269) It should be recollected that the protests against such legislation made by the then British Agent, as well as the Secretary of State for the Colonies, had much \ to do with the laxity of the Republican officials above alluded to.
('2', 396, 1, 6, 891500) Mr. Chamberlain’s reply, from which the following extracts are taken, to the Indian Memorialists as to the Location Law was very sympathetic, and shows clearly that he strongly disapproved of it, and stopped only when he felt helpless: I regret extremely that I cannot return a more encouraging answer to the memorial before me, for the petitioners have my sympathy.
('2', 396, 1, 7, 891867) I believe them to be a peaceable, law abiding, and meritorious body of persons, and I can only hope that, even as matters stand, their undoubted industry and intelligence, and their indomitable perseverance, will suffice to overcome any obstacles which may now face them in the pursuit of their avocations.
('2', 396, 1, 8, 892174) In conclusion, I would say that, whilst desirous loyally to abide by the award and to allow it to close the legal and international questions in dispute between the two Governments, I reserve to myself the liberty, later on, to make friendly representations to the South African Republic as to these traders, and possibly to invite that Government to consider whether, when once its legal position has been made good, it would not be wise to review the situation from a new point of view, and decide whether it would not be better in the interests of its own burghers to treat the Indians more generously, and to free itself from even the appearance of countenancing a trade jealousy, which I have some reasons to believe does not emanate from the governing class in the Republic.
('2', 396, 1, 9, 892955) Are we, then, when everything is in his power, to groan under all the disabilities which so roused his indignation?
('2', 396, 1, 10, 893071) Even a few weeks before the war broke out, the British Agent assured the deputation that waited on him at Pretoria, that everything short of a declaration of war was done by him, that negotiations were still going on, and that if, unfortunately, the threatened war broke out, we need not bother thereabout.
('2', 396, 1, 11, 893378) Lord Lansdowne has declared publicly that the an legislation which was clearly in breach of the Pretoria Convention was one of the principal causes of the war.
('2', 396, 1, 12, 893538) Is, then, the very evil to remove which, among others, the war has been entered upon, to be continued under the very shadow of the British flag, and when the Colonial Office cannot even put forth the excuse that it has not sufficient
('2', 397, 0, 1, 893772) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 398
('2', 397, 1, 2, 893814) control over the self governing Colonies?
('2', 397, 1, 3, 893856) For, neither the Transvaal nor the Orange River Colony has yet got self government.
('2', 397, 1, 4, 893940) We notice with much regret and misgiving that the King’s speech on the opening of Parliament pointedly refers to the equality of all the white races south of Zambezi, and a fair treatment of the native races, as the only objects in view at the time of the coming settlement.
('2', 397, 1, 5, 894215) Before the war, it used to be “equal rights for all the civilised races in South Africa”.
('2', 397, 1, 6, 894305) If, therefore, the change to “the whites” is deliberate, it suggests a cause for grave anxiety.
('2', 397, 1, 7, 894401) We attach hereto an abstract of the laws of the late Republican State affecting the Indians.
('2', 397, 1, 8, 894494) The question is most serious, our position most painful.
('2', 397, 1, 9, 894551) Labouring under the oppressive yoke, we feel too exhausted to make an effort ourselves.
('2', 397, 1, 10, 894639) We can only cry out in anguish.
('2', 397, 1, 11, 894671) It is for you to help us to be free from the grievous burden.
('2', 397, 1, 12, 894733) We have done, we hope, everything to deserve better treatment.
('2', 397, 1, 13, 894796) We have taken our share, however humble, side by side with the European Colonists in the war, and have endeavoured to show that, if we are anxious and ready to pray to be allowed to enjoy the rights and privileges of British subjects, we are not unmindful of our duty as such.
('2', 397, 1, 14, 895073) We have shown also, incontestably, that there is absolutely nothing in us to justify all the indignities we have to suffer in South Africa.
('2', 397, 1, 15, 895213) A great and combined effort on the part of the public bodies and the public press in India, and the friends in England, cannot fail to secure justice.
('2', 397, 1, 16, 895364) It is perfectly feasible in that, as there are, there can be no two opinions about the justness of our cause.
('2', 397, 1, 17, 895474) The time, too, is now or never; for, after the settlement has taken place, it is clear from experience that no amelioration would be possible.
('2', 397, 2, 18, 895617) We remain,
('2', 397, 3, 19, 895628) your obedient servants, MAHOMED CASSIM CAMROODEEN & CO
('2', 397, 4, 20, 895683) AND NINETEEN OTHERS
('2', 397, 5, 21, 895703) ABSTRACT [OF] LAWS
('2', 397, 6, 22, 895722) Of the late South African Republic and the Orange Free State affecting British Indians only
('2', 397, 7, 23, 895814) SOUTH AFRICAN REPUBLIC
('2', 397, 8, 24, 895837) Every Indian must take out a Registration Ticket for £3. When the officials treated the Indians as the natives of the soil, they insisted upon their taking out shilling travelling passes.
('2', 397, 8, 25, 896025) The railway regulations prevent Indians from travelling first or second class.
('2', 397, 8, 26, 896104) No Indian can own native gold, or take out a digging licence.
('2', 397, 8, 27, 896166) (This law has not operated as a hardship, as the Indians have not gone in for speculation.)
('2', 398, 0, 1, 896258) VOL 2: 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 399
('2', 398, 1, 2, 896300) Law 3 of 1885 gives the Government the right to point out to the Indians, for sanitary purposes, certain Locations for habitation.
('2', 398, 1, 3, 896431) An attempt was made before the war to sent away all the Indians in Johannesburg to a Location nearly five miles from the centre part of the town, where it was proposed to restrict their trade also.
('2', 398, 1, 4, 896629) Certain bye laws in Pretoria prevent the use, by the Indians, of footpaths and public vehicles.
('2', 398, 2, 5, 896725) N.B.—For fuller information hereon vide letter to the British Agent, 21st July, 1899, and memorial to the Secretary of State for the Colonies, May [16], 1899.
('2', 398, 3, 6, 896884) ORANGE FREE STATE
('2', 398, 4, 7, 896902) Chapter 33 of 1890 prevents any Asiatics from (1) remaining in the State for more than two months without permission from the State President; (2) owning landed property; (3) trading or farming.
('2', 398, 4, 8, 897097) Chapter 71 levies a poll tax of 10s.
('2', 398, 4, 9, 897134) per annum when permission to reside has been granted, subject to restrictions mentioned above.

('2', 401, 1, 2, 901859) 179. LETTER TO COLONIAL SECRETARY
('2', 401, 2, 3, 901893) 14, MERCURY LANE DURBAN, April 30, 1901
('2', 401, 3, 4, 901933) TO THE HONOURABLE THE COLONIAL SECRETARY PIETERMARITZBURG
('2', 401, 5, 5, 901991) I venture to address you on the Indian Immigration Amendment Act Bill published in this week’s Government Gazette.
('2', 401, 5, 6, 902106) The first section of the Bill provides that the rate of wages payable to any Indian woman under the Act of 1895 shall be one half of the respective rates provided therein, or such other special rate as may be agreed upon by the employer and the woman.
('2', 401, 5, 7, 902358) I presume the Government intend one half of the rates provided in the Act of 1895 to be the minimum, but I think such intention is not sufficiently clear from the wording of the section.
('2', 401, 5, 8, 902545) May I suggest the addition of “but in no case less than one half of the respective rates aforesaid”.
('2', 401, 6, 9, 902646) I beg to draw your attention to the fact that the Law 25 of 1891 provides for the wages of Indian women to be half those of men, and I hope the Government do not propose to make alteration in the minimum.
('2', 401, 7, 10, 902851) I have the honour to be,
('2', 401, 9, 11, 902876) your obedient servant, M. K. GANDHI
('2', 401, 10, 12, 902912) Pietermaritzburg Archives: C. S. O. 3486/1901.
('2', 401, 11, 13, 902959) 1 The suggestion was accepted.

('2', 402, 1, 2, 903032) 180. LETTER TO BOMBAY GOVERNMENT
('2', 402, 2, 3, 903065) DURBAN, May 4, 1901
('2', 402, 3, 4, 903085) TO THE HON’BLE R. J. C. LORD [GOVERNMENT OF BOMBAY BOMBAY]
('2', 402, 4, 5, 903144) [DEAR SIR,]
('2', 402, 5, 6, 903156) I am requested specially to forward the enclosed 1 to you and humbly to suggest that some action might be taken in the various Legislative Councils in India, and if that be not possible, in the Viceregal Council, though seeing that Bombay, Madras and Calcutta send a very large number of immigrants to South Africa, there is no reason why the local Governments should not take notice of the disabilities which the British Indians are labouring under.
('2', 402, 5, 7, 903607) This question is one of those about which there is a unanimity of Indian and Anglo Indian opinion; and I venture to think that united action on the part of the non official members will do much for our cause.
('2', 402, 5, 8, 903816) There is very little doubt that the official sympathy would also be with us, and under the strong and sympathetic Viceroy we have in Lord Curzon, the great question which underlies our disabilities (as put by the London Times)—”May the British Indians when they leave India have the same status before the law as other British subjects enjoy.
('2', 402, 5, 9, 904159) May they or may they not go freely from one British possession to another and claim the rights of British subjects in allied states”—cannot but be decided favourably if only it is sufficiently brought to His Excellency’s notice.
('2', 402, 6, 10, 904388) From Despatch No.
('2', 402, 6, 11, 904406) 35 of 1901 from the Government of India to the Secretary of State for India.
('2', 402, 7, 12, 904483) Colonial Office Records: South Africa, General, 1901.
('2', 402, 8, 13, 904537) 1 The circular letter of April 20, 1901. Gandhiji’s letter and its enclosure were sent by the Government of Bombay to the Government of India who transmitted them to the Seeretary of State for India.

('2', 403, 1, 2, 905075) 181. PETITION TO MILITARY GOVERNOR 1
('2', 403, 2, 3, 905112) P. O. BOX 4420, JOHANNESBURG, May 9, 1901
('2', 403, 3, 4, 905154) TO HIS EXCELLENCY COLONEL COLIN MACRENZIE MILITARY GOVERNOR JOHANNESBURG
('2', 403, 4, 5, 905227) MAY IT PLEASE YOUR EXCELLENCY,
('2', 403, 5, 6, 905258) We, the undersigned members of the Indian community of Johannesburg, beg respectfully to bring to your knowledge that an important Notice has appeared in the Johannesburg Gazette, wherein [it is stated that] an Indian Immigration Office has been opened to deal solely with all Asiatics, and whereby all such subjects have to get their passes changed, and to deal with all Government matters that they may be interested in.
('2', 403, 5, 7, 905681) We beg to point out that hitherto our dealings direct with His Imperial Majesty’s Authorities have been carried out without any complaint, and we fear that this new departure will lead to dissatisfaction amongst many of our fellow subjects.
('2', 403, 5, 8, 905922) We have not seen any notice regarding the changing of passes of the subjects of foreign countries, and we thus infer that a distinction is being made; if this be so, we shall be grieved thereat.
('2', 403, 5, 9, 906117) We have ever been loyal and desire to be direct under the Imperial Authorities, as heretofore, whose treatment and kindness we greatly appreciate.
('2', 403, 5, 10, 906264) Trusting that Your Excellency will give this matter your serious consideration and grant our humble request.
('2', 403, 5, 11, 906373) We subscribe ourselves,
('2', 403, 6, 12, 906397) Your Excelleney’s most humble

('2', 404, 3, 4, 906796) TO THE HONORARY SECRETARY EAST INDIA ASSOCIATION LONDON
('2', 404, 4, 5, 906852) DEAR SIR, I write this particularly to suggest the advisability of a deputation waiting on Sir Alfred Milner, if indeed not also on Mr. Chamberlain.
('2', 404, 4, 6, 907001) There is no doubt that most important matters will be discussed between the two statesmen and, if a strong deputation representing all shades of opinion and consisting of, say—Sir Lepel, 1
('2', 404, 5, 7, 907190) Mr. Dadabhai, Sir William Wedderburn, Sir Mancherji, Messrs.
('2', 404, 5, 8, 907251) Romesh Dutt, 2 Parameshvaram Pillay, Gust, etc., were to put the Indian question before them, it cannot but do good.

('2', 408, 6, 7, 911929) 189. JOINT ACTION FOR PERMITS 1
('2', 408, 7, 8, 911961) DURBAN, NATAL, June 1, 1901
('2', 408, 9, 9, 911989) The papers received this week contain news that Mr. Chamberlain, in reply to Mr. Caine’s question on the subject of the permits for the return of the Indian refugees to the Transvaal, informed him that at the request of Sir Mancherjee he had already cabled to Sir Alfred Milner in the matter.
('2', 408, 9, 10, 912282) Reuter’s message received this week says that, in reply to another question, Mr. Chamberlain said that the anti Indian laws of the late South African Republic would remain in force until modified.
('2', 408, 9, 11, 912479) Mr. Chamberlain does not seem to have added that the laws will not be enforced in practice as they were not under the old regime.
('2', 408, 9, 12, 912609) In the absence of any such understanding, the present state will be far worse than the old.
('2', 408, 9, 13, 912701) I confess this news has disappointed us.
('2', 408, 9, 14, 912742) Although the workers here have imbibed their zeal and ideas of duty from the self sacrificing devotion of the Congress leaders and are content to copy the Congress pattern, they have appealed to all parties for help and there seems to be no difference of opinion as to the justness of the cause.
('2', 408, 9, 15, 913038) Holding this view, we feel that it suffer for want of concerted action on the part of the different friends.
('2', 408, 9, 16, 913147) The East India Association has already suggested joint action and I respectfully submit that a large measure of success would be
('2', 408, 10, 17, 913276) 1 The contents of this letter and connected documents show that it was addressed to the British Committee of the Indian National Congress.
('2', 409, 0, 1, 913415) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 410
('2', 409, 1, 2, 913457) attained if a small committee of persons representing all shades of opinion were formed and a concerted move were always made.
('2', 409, 1, 3, 913584) An unsympathetic reply from the Colonial Secretary produces a bad impression here and encourages further opposition to the Indians.
('2', 409, 1, 4, 913716) The method, therefore, of obtaining information by letter to Mr. Chamberlain or a personal interview is, in my humble opinion, better adapted to the circumstances of our case.
('2', 409, 1, 5, 913892) Mr. Chamberlain’s reply, cabled by Reuter as above, is calculated to do some mischief.
('2', 409, 1, 6, 913979) The interpretation put upon it is that he will yield to popular clamour and give up the Indians entirely.
('2', 409, 1, 7, 914085) I know that we who are on the spot suffer from the nearness of vision and may consequently take merely a narrow and parochial view and may not give due attention to the situation there or the position of the leaders working in our behalf.
('2', 409, 1, 8, 914324) If, therefore, there is anything presumptuous in my suggestion, I trust you will be good enough to overlook it.
('2', 409, 1, 9, 914436) I am sending a copy of this letter to the Honourable Dadabhai Naoroji.
('2', 409, 2, 10, 914507) I remain,
('2', 409, 3, 11, 914517) yours truly,

('2', 410, 11, 13, 915532) 193. LETTER TO M. M. BHOWNAGGREE
('2', 410, 12, 14, 915565) P. O. BOX 182, DURBAN, NATAL, June 22, 1901
('2', 410, 13, 15, 915609) DEAR SIR MANCHERJI,
('2', 410, 14, 16, 915629) I acknowledged last week your two letters.
('2', 410, 14, 17, 915672) Since then I have received yours of the 24th ultimo.
('2', 410, 14, 18, 915725) Your letters have revived our spirits, and I beg to thank you on behalf of the poor sufferers in South Africa for the great work you are doing.
('2', 410, 14, 19, 915869) We on this side entirely agree with you that so far as possible the thing should be managed by friendly interviews, such as you have been having with Mr. Chamberlain and others, for an unsympathetic answer to a question in the House cannot but do a great deal of damage—where justice is entirely on our side, and no difference of opinion exists between the
('2', 411, 0, 1, 916226) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 412
('2', 411, 1, 2, 916268) several parties.
('2', 411, 1, 3, 916285) A constant reminder to the authorities and unwearing 1
('2', 411, 2, 4, 916340) vigilance are all that is needed in order to secure the desired result.
('2', 411, 2, 5, 916412) We have anticipated you in the suggestion as to a combined movement in India, and letters 2 have been addressed to the.
('2', 411, 2, 6, 916532) leaders on that side requesting them to promote memorials and put questions in the Viceregal Council.
('2', 411, 2, 7, 916634) At the same time, I am not very hopeful of success, owing to the absence there of any organized committee to deal exclusively with the South African Question, or rather with the question of grievances of the Indian emigrants.
('2', 411, 2, 8, 916860) But a combined powerful representation to the India Office from the East India Association and the Congress Committee may well supplement or take the place of what may be done in India.
('2', 411, 2, 9, 917046) I know that you feel very keenly in this matter of our disabilities, and that they are bad enough to arouse righteous indignation in the coolest head.
('2', 411, 2, 10, 917197) But may I ask you not to mar the sterling work you are doing there by precipitating a hot debate unless you are sure of success.
('2', 411, 2, 11, 917326) We fully realise that no man in England is more capable of doing justice to this matter than yourself owing to the warm interest you take in it, your position in the House, your influence with the authorities and above all your willingness to work.
('2', 411, 2, 12, 917575) The information supplied to Mr. Chamberlain by the authorities in the Transvaal with reference to the cablegram 3 sent to you as to the permits is, I venture to say, misleading.
('2', 411, 2, 13, 917753) I still affirm that the cablegram is correct.
('2', 411, 2, 14, 917799) The information was derived from the report sent to the local newspapers by their special correspondents.
('2', 411, 2, 15, 917905) I went over yesterday myself to see the Secretary of the Uitlander Committee and he told me emphatically that most of the shops are open, and that the requirement that the men shouldjoin the Rand Rifles is more or less a formality, and surely, if they don’t want the Indians to join the Rand Rifles, it should not, to say the least, be used as a bar against their return; and it should be recollected that many European ladies have been allowed to proceed, and that it is a daily occurrence to see a crowd of families entraining for the Transvaal.
('2', 411, 2, 16, 918453) I regret to have to inform you that up to the time of writing no further permits have been received, though six have been promised—four for Natal and two for Cape Town.
('2', 411, 2, 17, 918622) But, of course, the question of permits is, after all,

('2', 411, 3, 19, 918723) 2 These are not available.

('2', 412, 1, 2, 918827) insignificant, and only a temporary, though, while it lasts, a very severely felt, difficulty compared to the all absorbing question—what is to be the position of the Indians under the new regime?
('2', 412, 1, 3, 919024) There is yet no declaration to the effect that, at the very least, the existing legislation will be considerably modified.

('2', 412, 5, 8, 919406) 194. SPEECH AT INDIAN SCHOOL
('2', 412, 6, 9, 919435) The following is a brief press report of Gandhiji’s speech at a prize distribution function of the Government Higher Grade Indian School in Durban.
('2', 412, 6, 10, 919583) The Governor of Natal, Sir Henry McCallum, presided.
('2', 412, 6, 11, 919636) [DURBAN, prior to June 28, 1901]
('2', 412, 7, 12, 919669) Mr. M. K. Gandhi, in moving a vote of thanks to His Excellency, said he thought the Indian community might take just pride and feel very highly gratified in the fact that His Excellency, in the very early stage of his administration) should come in touch with them, and that in such an agreeable manner.
('2', 412, 7, 13, 919973) He recalled to mind the competition between the Irish Association and the Indian community on the occasion of the visit of Lord Roberts.
('2', 412, 7, 14, 920110) The Irish Association claimed His Lordship as an Irishman, and the Indians claimed him as an Indian.
('2', 412, 7, 15, 920211) His Excellency had already been claimed by the Scotchmen, but he thought they had good grounds for claiming Sir Henry to be an Indian by adoption.
('2', 412, 7, 16, 920358) He expressed the hope that the Government would let them have a gymnasium and singing classes they had promised.
('2', 412, 7, 17, 920471) He also hoped they would grant a girls’ school on the model of the Indian Higher Grade School.
('2', 412, 8, 18, 920566) The Natal Mercury, 28 6 1901

('2', 414, 6, 8, 921719) 199. ADDRESS TO ROYAL VISITORS
('2', 414, 7, 9, 921750) The following address, which was engraved on a silver shield, along with pictures of the Taj Mahal, the Karla Caves of Bombay, the Buddha Gaya temple; and of indentured Indians working in Natal Sugar Estates, was presented by Durban Indians to the Duke and Duchess of Cornwall and York when they visited Natal.
('2', 414, 7, 10, 922061) [DURBAN, August 13, 1901]
('2', 414, 8, 11, 922087) ADDRESS TO THEIR ROYAL HIGHNESSES THE DUKE AND DUCHESS OF CORNWALL AND YORK
('2', 414, 9, 12, 922163) MAY IT PLEASE YOUR ROYAL HIGHNESSES, We, the undersigned, on behalf of the British Indians residing in this Colony, humbly beg to welcome Your Royal Highnesses to these shores.
('2', 414, 9, 13, 922340) Among the countries visited by you during the present tour, Natal is one that has a large number of British Indians, and, seeing that India is not included among the countries to have the honour of the royal visit, it becomes a double duty incumbent on us to render homage to Your Royal Highnesses.
('2', 414, 9, 14, 922639) It shows the great regard His Majesty the King and Emperor has for his people that, amid the overwhelming grief which, in common with the royal family, has shrouded myriads of his subjects in the departure from our midst of our late beloved Kaiser i Hind, he has commanded Your Royal Highnesses to visit not only Australia, but also other parts of the great Empire, a visit which, we respectfully venture to say, has drawn tighter the silken cord that binds together the different parts of the British Raj.
('2', 415, 0, 1, 923146) 416 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 415, 1, 2, 923188) We fully realise the blessing of the munificent British rule.
('2', 415, 1, 3, 923250) It is because we are in the folds of the all embracing Union Jack that we have a footing outside India.
('2', 415, 1, 4, 923354) We humbly request you to assure His Majesty the King and Emperor, our Maharaja, of our loyal attachment to the throne, and.
('2', 415, 1, 5, 923478) we wish Your Royal Highnesses a pleasant time in this garden of South Africa and pray to the Almighty that He might guide you safelyhome on the termination of your tour, and may shower His choicest blessings upon you.
('2', 415, 2, 6, 923696) We remain,
('2', 415, 3, 7, 923707) Your Royal Highnesses’ humble and

('2', 415, 6, 10, 923845) 200. INDIANS AND THE DUKE
('2', 415, 7, 11, 923871) MERCURY LANE, DURBAN, August 21, 1901
('2', 415, 8, 12, 923909) TO THE EDITOR The Natal Mercury
('2', 415, 9, 13, 923941) SIR, I enclose copy, as supplied to me, of the resolutions and covering letter addressed to me as Chairman of “the Protest Meeting of English speaking and other Indians”, by the convener.
('2', 415, 9, 14, 924129) Chairman though I was of the meeting, I am not at all in sympathy with the resolutions, as they contain many material errors of statement, and are misleading.
('2', 415, 9, 15, 924288) But realizing that ventilation in the Press of grievances, fancied or real, is the best safety valve, I forward them, to be used as you may think fit.
('2', 415, 10, 16, 924439) I am, &c., M. K. GANDHI
('2', 415, 11, 17, 924463) [Resolutions]
('2', 415, 12, 18, 924477) At a protest meeting of the English speaking and other Indians which was held in the Congress Hall on the 2nd inst., Mr. J. L. Roberts, the convener, proposed, and
('2', 416, 0, 1, 924641) VOL 2 : 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 417
('2', 416, 1, 2, 924684) Mr. D. C. Andrews seconded, the following resolutions, which were carried unanimously.
('2', 416, 1, 3, 924771) Mr. M. K. Gandhi occupied the chair.
('2', 416, 1, 4, 924808) 1. That this meeting strongly disapproves of the manner in which the Indian representatives were chosen for the presentation of the address to their Royal Highnesses the Duke and Duchess of Cornwall and York, inasmuch as only the Mohammedans were apprised of the meeting, thus depriving the other Indians from participating in it.
('2', 416, 1, 5, 925139) 2. That this meeting strongly disapproves of the fact that the majority of representatives elected to attend the presentation of addresses to their Royal Highnesses are Mohammedans and that the other Indians in the Colony, being greater in number than the Mohammedans, should have had at least an equal number of representatives as the Mohammedans.
('2', 416, 1, 6, 925488) 3. That, out of the eight further representatives who were chosen to receive invitations (if the Reception Committee grant it), six are Mohammedans; thus, again, the other Indians do not receive a fair share in the representation.
('2', 416, 1, 7, 925719) 4. That this meeting strongly disapproves of the practice of the Mohammedans, who, after choosing men to represent themselves, should invariably choose one Mr. H. L. Paul to represent the English speaking and other Indians, thus acting in direct opposition to the wishes of the Indians in question.
('2', 416, 1, 8, 926018) 5. That copies of the foregoing resolutions should be sent to the secretary of the Duke and Duchess of York, the Indian Reception Committee, the Mayor of Durban, and the Press of Natal.
('2', 416, 2, 9, 926204) The Natal Mercury, 23 8 1901
('2', 416, 3, 10, 926233) 201. INDIAN OR COOLIE?
('2', 416, 4, 11, 926256) [LADYSMITH,] September 11, 1901
('2', 416, 5, 12, 926288) Mr. Gandhi asked to be allowed to appear at that late stage, as the case was important to the Indian community, and the Police seemed to be labouring under a delusion with regard to their status.
('2', 416, 5, 13, 926484) They had, a few days ago, arrested a number of Natal born Indians, who had from very shame forfeited their bail.
('2', 416, 5, 14, 926597) An attempt had been made to bring defendant, an Indian, who came to Natal of his own will, under the section of the law, by terming him a “coolie”.
('2', 416, 5, 15, 926745) The section read “after 9 P.M.,” “failing to produce a pass from the employer.” How could he do this, when he was his own employer?
('2', 416, 5, 16, 926877) He quoted Mrs. Vinden v.
('2', 416, 5, 17, 926902) Corporation of Ladysmith, in which the
('2', 416, 6, 18, 926941) 1 An Indian barber, Abarrah, was charged under the Pass Law.
('2', 416, 6, 19, 927002) On the day the case came up for decision before the magistrate of Ladysmith, Gandhiji appeared for the accused.
('2', 417, 0, 1, 927114) 418 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 417, 1, 2, 927156) Supreme Court laid down that the term could be translated “indentured Indian”.
('2', 417, 1, 3, 927235) His Worship said that, in view of the case quoted, he did not feel called upon to say anything further.
('2', 417, 1, 4, 927339) He could not lay down a hard and fast rule, for such cases had to be treated on their merits.
('2', 417, 1, 5, 927433) The law was difficult.
('2', 417, 1, 6, 927456) Though accused was plainly a coloured person, the law did not call him that, so he was discharged.

('2', 418, 8, 10, 929513) DURBAN, October 2, 1901
('2', 418, 9, 11, 929537) 18 of 1897 regulates & controls the issue of licenses to wholesale & retail dealers.
('2', 418, 9, 12, 929622) 1 of said Act includes in the licenses mentioned in sub section (a) sec.
('2', 418, 9, 13, 929695) 71 of Law.
('2', 418, 9, 14, 929706) 19, 1872, licenses to wholesale dealers, so as, it is contended, to give the control over licenses to wholesale dealers to the Corporations.
('2', 418, 9, 15, 929847) The expression, retail dealers, is specially made by sec.
('2', 418, 9, 16, 929905) 3 of the said Act to include hawkers, and therefore, by inference, it is contended, to exclude all others.
('2', 418, 9, 17, 930012) Is a baker or a butcher, in the opinion of Counsel, a retail or wholesale dealer within the meaning of the Act, & is his license governed by that Act?
('2', 418, 9, 18, 930163) Counsel’s attention is drawn to the fact that there is a separate
('2', 419, 0, 1, 930229) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 419, 1, 2, 930271) tariff for a baker’s & a butcher’s license from the tariff for a retail shopkeeper’s (dealer’s) license under Law No.
('2', 419, 1, 3, 930389) 19 of 1872, that a baker’s license does not, at any rate in the popular belief, cover transactions not incidental to a bakery, & that, similarly, a retail dealer’s license does not cover a baker’s business.

('2', 419, 4, 6, 930656) 205. LETTER TO COLONIAL SECRETARY
('2', 419, 5, 7, 930690) 14, MERCURY LANE, DURBAN, October 8, 1901 TO THE HONOURABLE THE COLONIAL SECRETARY PIETERMARITZBURG
('2', 419, 6, 8, 930790) SIR, I had the honour to write to the Government in the month of November last regarding the transfer to Mr. Jan Mahomed of Port Shepstone of a property in Port Shepstone.
('2', 419, 6, 9, 930962) The Government were pleased to decide that, if the conditions of the contract have been carried out, the transfer may be passed in the ordinary course.
('2', 419, 6, 10, 931114) All the instalments having been paid, I applied through my agent at P. M. Burg for the final deed of transfer and he wrote to me on the 21st August saying the Government declined to issue the title applied for, inasmuch as “the Building Clause set forth in the Certificate of Sale and purchase has not been complied With”.
('2', 419, 6, 11, 931437) I have been corresponding with my client and I find it is true that he has built wood and iron buildings without the previous written permission of the Magistrate, but I understand such buildings have been erected all over the place.
('2', 419, 6, 12, 931671) The Magistrate has, moreover, given his certificate as to the value of the building, which was produced before the Surveyor General.
('2', 419, 6, 13, 931804) I am further informed that the titles have been granted to others similarly situated, that my client, before he put up the wood and iron building, applied for permission to make bricks; that on the permission being refused he put up the wood and iron building; that the building in question is occupied by very respectable tenants, viz., the Standard Bank, and that my client is erecting brick or stone
('2', 420, 0, 1, 932207) VOL 2 : 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 421
('2', 420, 1, 2, 932250) buildings also on the land.
('2', 420, 1, 3, 932278) Under the circumstances, I request a reconsideration of my client’s application for registration of his title, and venture to trust that the Governor will be pleased to grant it.
('2', 420, 2, 4, 932457) I have the honour to be,
('2', 420, 4, 5, 932482) your obedient servant, M. K. GANDHI

('2', 420, 6, 7, 932563) 206. SPEECH AT FAREWELL MEETING
('2', 420, 7, 8, 932595) On the eve of his departure for India, Gandhiji was presented with addresses; on behalf of the Natal Indian Congress and other Indian organizations.
('2', 420, 7, 9, 932744) The large gathering in the Congress Hall, Durban, included several leading European citizens.
('2', 420, 7, 10, 932838) The following is a brief report of the speech Gandhiji made on the occasion:
('2', 420, 8, 11, 932915) [DURBAN,] October 15, 1901
('2', 420, 9, 12, 932942) Mr. Gandhi returned thanks from the bottom of his heart for the splendid and costly address.
('2', 420, 9, 13, 933035) 1 He thanked the donors of the many presents; and also those who had spoken so flatteringly of him.
('2', 420, 9, 14, 933135) He had not been able to find a satisfactory answer to the question of how he came to deserve all this.
('2', 420, 9, 15, 933238) Seven or eight years ago, 2 they embarked on a certain principle, and he accepted the gifts as an earnest that they would continue on the lines on which they then embarked.
('2', 420, 9, 16, 933411) The Natal Indian Congress had worked to bring about a better understanding between European and Indian Colonists.
('2', 420, 9, 17, 933525) They had progressed in that, if only a little way During the recent election speeches they heard much against the Indians What was wanted in South Africa was not a white man’s country; not a white brotherhood, but an Imperial brotherhood.
('2', 420, 9, 18, 933764) Everyone who was the friend of the Empire should aim at that.
('2', 420, 9, 19, 933826) England would never part with her possession in the East, and, as Lord Curzon had said, India was the brightest jewel in the British Empire.
('2', 420, 9, 20, 933967) They wished to show that they were an acceptable section of the community, and, if they continued as they started, they “would know each other better when the mists have rolled away”.
('2', 420, 9, 21, 934151) Mr. Gandhi

('2', 422, 7, 10, 936914) 208. LETTER TO PARSEE RUSTOMJEE
('2', 422, 8, 11, 936946) DURBAN, October 18, 1901 TO PARSEE RUSTOMJEE, ESQ.
('2', 422, 8, 12, 936997) HONORARY SECRETARY ADDRESS COMMITTEE DURBAN
('2', 422, 9, 13, 937041) DEAR MR. RUSTOMJEE, I have been thinking what written reply to give to the handsome and costly address presented to me by my fellow countrymen.
('2', 422, 9, 14, 937185) After deep consideration, I have come to the conclusion that, consistently with professions made by me from time to time, I must not be satisfied with merely saying that what I value is the affection that has prompted the gifts, not the gifts as such.
('2', 422, 9, 15, 937437) I have, therefore, decided to hand over the jewellery, as per accompanying schedule, to the African Banking Corporation with instructions to deliver the articles to the Natal Indian Congress against a receipt signed by the President and Honorary Secretary or Secretaries for the time being.
('2', 422, 9, 16, 937728) I make them over to the Congress on the following conditions: (1) The jewellery or its value should form an emergency fund to be utilized only when the Congress has no other funds to
('2', 423, 0, 1, 937911) 424 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 423, 1, 2, 937953) fall back upon without the two landed properties.
('2', 423, 1, 3, 938003) (2) I should have the right to withdraw any or such of the jewellery that may then not have been utilised for devoting same to any beneficial object, whether within or outside the scope of the Congress.
('2', 423, 1, 4, 938206) When the necessity for utilising the jewellery arises, and if it is possible, I would feel it an honour to be consulted by the Congress as to whether the object for which it is sought to utilise same is, in my opinion, an emergency within the scope of this letter.
('2', 423, 1, 5, 938471) But the Congress is free at any time to withdraw the jewellery without reference to me.
('2', 423, 1, 6, 938559) I have taken the above step deliberately and prayerfully.
('2', 423, 1, 7, 938617) I feel that neither I nor my family can make any personal use of the costly presents.
('2', 423, 1, 8, 938703) They are too sacred to be sold by me or my heirs, and, seeing that there can be no guarantee against the last contingency, in my opinion, the only way I can return the love of our people is to dedicate them all to a sacred object.
('2', 423, 1, 9, 938934) And since they are in reality a tribute to the Congress principles, to the Congress I return them.
('2', 423, 1, 10, 939033) Lastly, I repeat the hope that our people would translate into acts their good intentions (for the institution) of which the recent presentations were an earnest.
('2', 423, 1, 11, 939196) That the Congress may continue to serve the Empire and the Community and that my successors may receive the same support that was extended to me is my fervent prayer.
('2', 423, 1, 12, 939363) I remain, yours truly, [Schedule of jewellery] Gold medal presented in 1896. Gold coin presented in 1896 by the Tamil Indians.
('2', 423, 1, 13, 939490) Gold chain presented by the Johannesburg Committee in 1899. Gold chain, sovereign purse and seven gold coins presented by Mr. Parsee Rustomjee.
('2', 423, 1, 14, 939634) Gold watch presented by Mr. Joosub of Messrs Dada Abdoola & Co.
('2', 423, 1, 15, 939698) Diamond ring presented by the Community.
