('2', 425, 4, 8, 942509) 211. SPEECH IN MAURITIUS
('2', 425, 5, 9, 942534) On his way to India, Gandhiji stopped at Port Louis, Mauritius, where the Indian community gave him a reception.
('2', 425, 5, 10, 942647) The following version of his speech on the occasion is based on the local Press reports.
('2', 425, 5, 11, 942736) November 13, 1901
('2', 425, 6, 12, 942754) Mr. Gandhi thanked the guests at the gathering and especially the host.
('2', 425, 6, 13, 942826) He said that the sugar industry of the island owed its unprecedented prosperity mainly to Indian immigrants.
('2', 425, 6, 14, 942935) He stressed that Indians should regard it their duty to acquaint themselves with happenings in their motherland, and should take interest in politics.
('2', 425, 6, 15, 943086) He also laid much emphasis on the urgent need to pay attention to the education of their children.
('2', 425, 7, 16, 943185) The Standard, 15 11 1901 Le Radical, 15 11 l901
('2', 426, 0, 1, 943233) VOL 2 : 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 427
('2', 426, 1, 2, 943276) 212. APPEAL FOR DEPUTATION TO VICEROY
('2', 426, 2, 3, 943314) Gandhiji reached India in the middle of December.
('2', 426, 2, 4, 943364) This was his first public statement on the question of Indians in South Africa.
('2', 426, 2, 5, 943444) BOMBAY, December 19, 1901 TO THE EDITOR The Times of India BOMBAY
('2', 426, 4, 6, 943510) The Indians in South Africa are eagerly waiting to see in what direction the Indian public are going to help them in the struggle which they are carrying on for existence in that sub continent against awful odds.
('2', 426, 4, 7, 943723) The East India Association has, as you are aware, sent up a strongly worded memorial to Lord George Hamilton.
('2', 426, 4, 8, 943833) Sir Mancherjee Bhownaggree has been rendering a most useful service to the cause of the sufferers.
('2', 426, 4, 9, 943932) In season and out of season, within the House of Commons and without, by pen and voice, he has been asking for, not without success, a redress of our grievances.
('2', 426, 4, 10, 944094) You; Sir, have uniformly assisted us, and so the whole of the public, both Indian and Anglo Indian.
('2', 426, 4, 11, 944194) The Congress 1 has been passing resolutions year after year sympathising with us.
('2', 426, 4, 12, 944276) But, in my humble opinion, something more is required.
('2', 426, 4, 13, 944331) I have been asked by the leading Indians in South Africa to suggest a representative deputation to the Viceroy, similar to the one that some years ago waited on Mr. Chamberlain, and which was promoted by the late Sir W. W. Hunter.
('2', 426, 4, 14, 944562) It is evidently necessary to strengthen the hands of the Viceroy as well as the workers in England.
('2', 426, 4, 15, 944662) The authorities here and in Downing Street are not—cannot be— unsympathetic.
('2', 426, 4, 16, 944739) The Europeans in South Africa are doing all they can to bring pressure to bear upon the Colonial office.
('2', 426, 4, 17, 944844) They want absolute power to legislate as they will against the British Indians.
('2', 426, 4, 18, 944924) A deputation, therefore, backed if possible by public meetings, cannot fail to haveits effect.
('2', 426, 4, 19, 945019) Let there be no mistake as to the real situation.
('2', 426, 4, 20, 945069) Mr. Chamberlain has, let us hope, once for all laid it down that he would not allow an affront to be placed upon millions of His Majesty’s subjects in the shape of special disabilities on the Indians.
('2', 426, 4, 21, 945270) Natal has,
('2', 426, 5, 22, 945281) 1 The Indian National Congress.
('2', 427, 0, 1, 945313) 428 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 427, 1, 2, 945355) therefore, sought to carry out its object by indirect methods; e.g., Immigration Restriction and Dealers’ Licenses Acts, in theory applicable to all, but in practice mostly enforced against the emigrants from India.
('2', 427, 1, 3, 945571) In the Cape Colony, the legislators propose to impose restrictions similar to those in Natal.
('2', 427, 1, 4, 945665) In the Transvaal and the Orange River Colonies, very drastic anti Indian laws are in force.
('2', 427, 1, 5, 945757) In the former, the Indian cannot hold land, must live and trade in Locations only, cannot walk on footpaths, etc.
('2', 427, 1, 6, 945871) The latter he cannot even enter, except under special permission, and then only as a domestic servant or labourer.
('2', 427, 1, 7, 945986) Unlike the two old Colonies, which enjoy complete self government, the newly annexed territories are under the direct control of the Colonial Office; and it is there the question is most pressing.
('2', 427, 1, 8, 946183) Mr. Chamberlain, in answer to a question put by Sir Mancherjee, has given an answer which, though worded in a friendly spirit, is far from satisfactory.
('2', 427, 1, 9, 946336) He evidently does not wish at once to put the pen through the laws inherited from the late Republics.
('2', 427, 1, 10, 946438) Lord Milner has been charged with the task of considering what alterations should be made in those laws.
('2', 427, 1, 11, 946543) This, therefore, is the time for India to assert her position as an integral part of the British Empire, and to claim for her sons in South Africa the full rights of a British citizen.
('2', 427, 1, 12, 946728) The question is admittedly of Imperial importance.
('2', 427, 1, 13, 946779) Are the British Indians, in the words of the late Sir W. W. Hunter, as soon as they leave India, to enjoy the full status of British subjects or not?
('2', 427, 1, 14, 946929) The answer to that question would, to a very great extent, depend upon the action of the public in India.
('2', 427, 1, 15, 947035) Even the Colonies would not care to disregard, especially at a time when the Imperial wave is passing throughout the length and breadth of the British Empire, a unanimous, emphatic, temperate and continuous expression of the public opinion of India.
('2', 427, 1, 16, 947285) May I, then, on behalf of the Indian settlers in South Africa, appeal to you and your contemporaries to help us in the desired direction?
('2', 427, 1, 17, 947423) I would venture also to ask your contemporaries, if possible, to copy this letter.
('2', 427, 2, 18, 947506) M. K. GANDHI
('2', 427, 3, 19, 947519) The Times of India, 20 12 1901
('2', 428, 0, 1, 947550) VOL 2 : 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 429
('2', 428, 1, 2, 947593) 213. SPEECH AT CALCUTTA CONGRESS
('2', 428, 2, 3, 947626) At the 17th session of the Indian National Congress held in Calcutta, Gandhiji made the following speech while moving a resolution on the status of Indians in South Africa: [CALCUTTA, December 27, 1901] MR. President, and Brother Delegates, The resolution that I have to commend to your attention is as follows: That this Congress sympathises with the British Indian settlers in South Africa in their struggle for existence and respectfully draws the attention of His Excellency the Viceroy to the anti Indian legislation there, and trusts that while the question of the status of British Indians in the Transvaal and the Orange River Colonies is still under the consideration of the Right Hon’ble the Secretary of State for the Colonies, His Excellency will be graciously pleased to secure for the settlers a just and equitable adjustment thereof.
('2', 428, 2, 4, 948475) Gentlemen, I appear before you not as a delegate, but more as a petitioner on behalf of the hundred thousand British Indians in South Africa, and probably also of the future emigrants, who we wish would go outside of India and carry with them the status of British subjects.
('2', 428, 2, 5, 948750) Gentlemen, South Africa, as you are aware, is almost as big as India and has a British Indian population of one hundred thousand, fifty thousand of whom are absorbed in the Colony of Natal, the only Colony in South Africa that imports indentured labour, and it is that labour that raises this great question so far as South Africa is concerned.
('2', 428, 2, 6, 949095) Gentlemen, throughout South Africa, our grievances are twofold.
('2', 428, 2, 7, 949159) The first class of grievances arises from the anti Indian attitude of the European Colonists, and the second class of grievances arises from the reproduction of that anti Indian feeling in anti Indian Legislation throughout the four Colonies in South Africa.
('2', 428, 2, 8, 949418) To give you an instance of the first class of grievances, I may tell you that all the Indians, no matter who they may be, are classed as coolies.
('2', 428, 2, 9, 949564) If our worthy President1 were to go to South Africa, I am afraid, he too will be classed as a coolie, as a member of the semi civilised races of Asia.
('2', 428, 2, 10, 949715) Gentlemen, I will give you two illustrations to show how that term coolie has worked mischief throughout South Africa.

('2', 431, 3, 8, 956328) 214. SPEECH AT CALCUTTA MEETING 1
('2', 431, 4, 9, 956362) CALCUTTA, January 19,1902 Mr. Gandhi, after describing South Africa generally, explained the position of the British Indians in that sub continent.
('2', 431, 4, 10, 956510) He said that in Natal the Immigration Restriction Act, the law relating to licences and the state of education of Indian children were chiefly matters of concern.
('2', 431, 4, 11, 956673) In the Transvaal, the Indians could not own landed property nor could they trade anywhere except in Locations.
('2', 431, 4, 12, 956784) They could not even walk on the footpaths.
('2', 431, 4, 13, 956827) The Orange River Colony the Indians could not even enter except as labourers, and then under special permission.
('2', 431, 4, 14, 956940) He had to repeat many things concerning the treatment the Indians received in South Africa which had already appeared in the papers, but he observed that his mission before them was not to give the dark side of the situation, with which they were partially familiar, but the bright, the roseate side.
('2', 431, 4, 15, 957241) He then narrated how, since the war, they had been able to enlist the sympathy of some of the Colonials, and the cause of the Indians, he thought, was a little progressing.
('2', 431, 4, 16, 957414) He, however, strongly deprecated the latest anti Indian

('2', 432, 1, 2, 957609) measure which sought to exclude every Indian from the Colonies who could not read any of the European languages.
('2', 432, 1, 3, 957722) The gentlemen present at the meeting, who all knew at least the English language, might not fully appreciate the gravity of the situation, but its effect would be disastrous upon a people the vast majority of whom were unlettered and those who knew only the vernaculars of India.
('2', 432, 1, 4, 958002) The hatred of the Colonials against them was no doubt intense, but what Mr. Gandhi proposed was to conquer that hatred by love.
('2', 432, 1, 5, 958130) The speaker asked his audience not to treat the statement as merely a formality.
('2', 432, 1, 6, 958211) The Indians in South Africa believed in this maxim and they tried to follow it.
('2', 432, 1, 7, 958291) The war, which must have proved disastrous to others, came to them as a blessing, as it furnished the Indians with an opportunity to prove their mettle.
('2', 432, 1, 8, 958444) Before the war broke out, the Colonials often used to taunt them by saying that, in times of danger, the Indians would scuttle off like so many rabbits, and such were the people: who demanded privileges like them !
('2', 432, 1, 9, 958659) But the war showed that the Indians did not scuttle off; they put their shoulders to the wheel and were prepared to take equal responsibility with others.
('2', 432, 1, 10, 958814) When the war broke out, the Indians, irrespective of their opinion whether the war was right or wrong (for which the Sovereign, and the Sovereign alone, was responsible, they thought), agreed to give their services free to Government and with that view approached it with a petition, but their prayer was not granted Subsequent to this, however, Colonel Gallwey, who apprehended to a certain extent what the affair at Colenso would be, wrote to a leading Indian1 to organise an ambulance corps, and this was done with 36 Indians as leaders and 1,200 Indians as ambulance bearers.
('2', 432, 1, 11, 959394) What sort of service they rendered to the country was known to them all, and this had even drawn forth the admiration of the violent Colonials who, for the first time then, saw the good trait in the Indian.
('2', 432, 1, 12, 959601) Mr. Gandhi added that, in one sense, the Indians themselves were to blame for the feeling of hatred raised in the Colonials against them.
('2', 432, 1, 13, 959739) If the Indian settlers had been followed by better class Indians who could be the peers of the Colonials in every phase of life, so much bad blood would not have been created.
('2', 432, 1, 14, 959915) However, the feeling had now been improving.
('2', 432, 1, 15, 959960) It had improved so much that it enabled some of the Indians to start a national Famine Fund to help India in

('2', 435, 3, 4, 963709) MR. CHAIRMAN AND GENTLEMEN,
('2', 435, 4, 5, 963737) Last Sunday week I had the honour to address you on my experiences in South Africa.
('2', 435, 4, 6, 963821) In the course of my remarks, you will recollect, I said that the policy that was followed by our countrymen in South Africa in connection with their legal disabilities could be summed up in two maxims which guided it, viz., to stick to the truth at all costs and conquer hate by love.
('2', 435, 4, 7, 964106) This was the ideal to be realized.
('2', 435, 4, 8, 964141) I then implored you, as I implore you now, to believe that these are no catch phrases, but that we have all through these years tried to live up to the ideal.
('2', 435, 4, 9, 964300) The local Indian contribution to the present war is, perhaps, the very best illustration of that line of action.
('2', 435, 4, 10, 964413) When in the October of 1899, the Boers issued their ultimatum, the British Government, as you are aware, was unready.
('2', 435, 4, 11, 964531) According to their prearranged plan, the Boers crossed the Natal border immediately on the receipt of the reply from the British Government.
('2', 435, 4, 12, 964672) Sir W. Penn Symons, at the cost of his life, gave the enemy’s forces a temporary check at Talana Hill, and Sir George White 2 allowed himself and his 10,000 brave men to be surrounded in Ladysmith.
('2', 435, 4, 13, 964870) These events were as unexpected as they were surprising, and followed in such quick succession that the people had hardly any time to turn in and ponder over them.
('2', 435, 4, 14, 965034) Mafeking and Kimberley were besieged at the same time.
('2', 435, 4, 15, 965089) Half of Natal was in Boer hands.
('2', 435, 4, 16, 965122) And often did we hear that the Boers were going to take Maritzburg and capture Durban.
('2', 435, 4, 17, 965209) But strange as it may appear, Sir George White and his army saved Natal by allowing themselves to be besieged, thus occupying the Boer General and the flower of his army.
('2', 435, 4, 18, 965380) This was the contribution of British India to the Colony.
('2', 435, 4, 19, 965438) The calmness and fortitude with which the people of Natal contemplated these events reflect the highest credit and show the secret of British power.
('2', 435, 4, 20, 965587) There was no stir.
('2', 435, 4, 21, 965606) Business went on as if nothing had happened.
('2', 435, 4, 22, 965651) The Natal Government never flinched.

('2', 446, 3, 5, 988858) 223. LETTER TO G. K. GOKHALE 1
('2', 446, 4, 6, 988889) RAJKOT, March 4, 1902
('2', 446, 5, 7, 988911) DEAR PROFESSOR GOKHALE,
('2', 446, 6, 8, 988935) Having passed five nights in the train, I reached here on Wednesday last, i.e., only a day later than I would have had I not stopped at the intermediate stations.
('2', 446, 6, 9, 989098) It was with very great difficulty that I found a seat in one of the intermediate carriages and that after I offered to stand the whole night if necessary.
('2', 446, 6, 10, 989253) As it was, it was merely a trick on the part of the friends of some of the passengers.
('2', 446, 6, 11, 989340) The former had occupied all the spare room with a view to prevent any more passengers from getting in.
('2', 446, 6, 12, 989443) They got out as soon [as] the guard blew the whistle for the train to go.
('2', 446, 6, 13, 989517) There was absolutely no room in the 3rd class carriages.
('2', 446, 6, 14, 989574) You cannot adopt gentlemen’s time and travel 3rd.
('2', 446, 6, 15, 989624) From Benares, however, I travelled 3rd only.
('2', 446, 6, 16, 989669) In your words, it was only the first plunge that was difficult, the after effect was all pleasure.
('2', 446, 6, 17, 989768) The other passengers and I talked freely and at times became even chummy.

('2', 446, 6, 19, 989905) Corruption is rampant.
('2', 446, 6, 20, 989928) Unless you are prepared to bribe the police, it is very difficult to get your ticket.
('2', 446, 6, 21, 990014) They approached me as they approached others several times and offered to buy our tickets if we would pay them a gratuity (or bribe?).
('2', 446, 6, 22, 990149) Many availed themselves of the offer.
('2', 446, 6, 23, 990187) Those of us who would not, had to wait nearly one hour after the window was opened, before we could get our tickets and we would be fortunate at that if we did so without being presented with a kick or two from the guardians of law.
('2', 446, 6, 24, 990420) At Moghalsarai, on the other hand, the ticket master was a very nice man.
('2', 446, 6, 25, 990494) He said he knew no distinction between a prince and a peasant.

('2', 448, 11, 11, 993468) DEAR SIR,
('2', 448, 12, 12, 993478) I have just received your letter of the 14th instant.
('2', 448, 12, 13, 993532) At the request of the Editor, India, I have already prepared a brief statement of the position up to date of the British Indians in South Africa.
('2', 448, 12, 14, 993678) I enclose a copy thereof.
('2', 448, 12, 15, 993704) 2 Though, I presume, the request made by the Editor was on your behalf, I feel that to force a debate on the whole question on the treatment of the British Indians in various Colonies is likely to do more harm than good, for the situation in the different Colonies is not the same.
('2', 448, 12, 16, 993986) In Natal, for instance, the Immigration Restriction Act, the Dealers’ Licenses Act and such other Acts, of which copies have been supplied from time to time to the British Committee, are already in force.
('2', 448, 12, 17, 994191) The Natal model is being followed both in Australia and Canada.
('2', 448, 12, 18, 994255) Under the circumstances, it would be very difficult if not impossible to obtain repeal in Natal or altogether to frustrate the
('2', 448, 13, 19, 994382) 1 Member of the British Parliament.

('2', 449, 1, 2, 994578) attempt of Australia and Canada to copy Natal.
('2', 449, 1, 3, 994625) The key to this is to be found in Mr. Chamberlain’s address to the Conference of Premiers at the time of the Diamond Jubilee.
('2', 449, 1, 4, 994751) I enclose acopy of an extract therefrom for your perusal.
('2', 449, 1, 5, 994809) He has met the Colonies half way, but the half way is probably more dangerous than the whole, for his sanction of indirect legislation has opened up possibilities for mischief which were never dreamt of, as you will see from my statement.
('2', 449, 1, 6, 995048) Mr. Chamberlain’s latest utterances are hardly reassuring.
('2', 449, 1, 7, 995107) They will simply strengthen the Colonial Governments in their anti Indian attitude.
('2', 449, 1, 8, 995191) The remedy, therefore, so far as Natal is concerned, is for the Indian residents in that Colony to induce the Colonial Government to accord fair treatment, which is now more or less a matter of administration of the old laws, and where they may attempt to pass fresh restrictive measures, to appeal to the Home Government and for the friends to help them.
('2', 449, 1, 9, 995547) Continued pressure from the Colonial Office and a sympathetic discussion of the Natal [question] in the Home newspapers are the chief influences that are calculated to soften the Ministers in Natal.
('2', 449, 1, 10, 995746) In a measure, I think, by the aid of friends in England and India, we have succeeded there.
('2', 449, 1, 11, 995838) As to Australia and Canada, the remedy is to take up the proposed measures, the text of which, unfortunately, I have not seen, and to attack the details so as to make them as lenient as possible.
('2', 449, 1, 12, 996034) On the main points Mr. Chamberlain simply will not help and, if the debate is forced, he will make a speech which would embolden the Colonists in their anti Indian attitude.
('2', 449, 1, 13, 996208) For the new Colonies in South Africa, our position is and ought to be infinitely stronger than elsewhere.
('2', 449, 1, 14, 996314) The Colonial Office has a much freer hand.
('2', 449, 1, 15, 996357) The past remonstrances to Mr. Kruger on the very anti Indian legislation which is now being enforced will, for very shame, make Mr. Chamberlain take up an entirely different attitude.

('2', 449, 1, 17, 996634) He then did not help because he was powerless.
('2', 449, 1, 18, 996681) Now that he is all powerful, how can he help granting relief, and yet, unfair as it may appear to draw an inference not creditable to him, we are very much afraid that he has gone back upon his old love and may, if not properly watched, give away our position in the two new Colonies.

('2', 450, 4, 17, 998700) 226. NOTES ON THE INDIAN POSITION
('2', 450, 5, 18, 998734) [RAJKOT, March 27, 1902] CONFIDENTIAL NOTES ON THE PRESENT POSITION OF THE BRITISH INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA
('2', 450, 6, 19, 998841) Anything that appears hereunder only applies to the situation as it stood two months prior to the date hereof, seeing that letters from
('2', 450, 7, 20, 998977) 1 Presumably, a cutting of the Press report of Gandhiji’s speech of January 27, 1902.
('2', 451, 0, 1, 999063) 452 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 451, 1, 2, 999105) South Africa take a long time reaching here.
('2', 451, 1, 3, 999150) It is necessary to bear this in mind because, evidently, the Indians in South Africa are still passing through a crisis as would appear from the following.
('2', 451, 1, 4, 999306) Too much stress cannot be laid on the necessity of distinguishing between the Indian question in Natal and in the two new Colonies.
('2', 451, 1, 5, 999438) Cape Colony may, just for the present, be kept out of mind.
('2', 451, 1, 6, 999498) The double question asked in the House of Commons about the new Colonies in Natal was, in my humble opinion, a tactical blunder.
('2', 451, 1, 7, 999627) Mr. Chamberlain’s reply that he does not, at present, propose to make representations to the Natal Government with reference to its anti Indian legislation already in force has created, if anything, a bad feeling in the Colony and emboldened the Colonists in their anti Indian attitude.
('2', 451, 1, 8, 999914) The Pass legislation of Natal can, in the light of Mr. Chamberlain’s well known views, be only a subject of constant correspondence between him and the sympathising friends.
('2', 451, 1, 9, 1000088) As to Natal, then, the Immigration Restriction Act and the Dealers’ Licenses Act are the chief measures which are prejudicial to the British Indians.
('2', 451, 1, 10, 1000238) The latter more especially, because it gives unlimited powers to the licensing officer as to the issue of license without recourse to theSupreme Court.
('2', 451, 1, 11, 1000390) The latest advice and development in effect enable them to curtail the right of the Indians.
('2', 451, 1, 12, 1000483) The Natal Civil Service Act gives powers to the Civil Service Board to pass bye laws under it with reference to the examination of candidates, etc.; now the Constitution Act requires that all class legislation, before becoming law, must be sanctioned by His Majesty.
('2', 451, 1, 13, 1000750) Moreover, it is clear that no bye laws could be enacted under an Act so as to change its fundamental principles.
('2', 451, 1, 14, 1000863) The Natal Government have escaped going to the Colonial Secretary for sanction for class legislation by simply publishing a bye law which goes to the very root of the Natal Civil Service Act.
('2', 451, 1, 15, 1001055) The bye law in question prevents any person, among other things, who is disqualified from acquiring the Parliamentary franchise, from becoming a candidate for admission to the Civil Service.
('2', 451, 1, 16, 1001246) The disfranchising Act is well known and under it the Natal Government would say the British Indians are disqualified and, therefore, also disqualified to exercise the franchise to compete for the Natal Civil Service; of course, there are very few Indians who go in for that examination.
('2', 451, 1, 17, 1001534) Still the principle is there.
('2', 451, 1, 18, 1001564) And the method adopted to carry it out is most dangerous, and opens up a very wide latitude for
('2', 452, 0, 1, 1001660) VOL 2 : 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 453
('2', 452, 1, 2, 1001703) the Colonists to further harass the Indian settlers.
('2', 452, 1, 3, 1001756) The matter might be brought to Mr. Chamberlain’s notice by correspondence.
('2', 452, 1, 4, 1001831) As to the Transvaal and the Orange River Colony, the situation is most critical in view of Mr. Chamberlain’s reply.
('2', 452, 1, 5, 1001947) All the anti Indian laws in both the Colonies are in full force; under them, in the Transvaal, the Indians cannot own land or trade except in Locations, and must, like the Kaffirs, hold travelling and other passes.
('2', 452, 1, 6, 1002162) The Orange River Colony they cannot even enter except as domestic servants.
('2', 452, 1, 7, 1002238) It is regarding these laws that, according to Mr. Chamberlain’s answer, Lord Milner is to advise him, and His Excellency’s attitude, there are grounds to fear, is not quite so friendly as was at one time expected.
('2', 452, 1, 8, 1002452) He has proclaimed a Coloured Pass law which is supposed to be an improvement on the old Transvaal Pass law which it replaces; copy of the recent Proclamation is enclosed herewith.
('2', 452, 1, 9, 1002632) 1 It will be seen therefrom that the relief afforded by it can mostly be availed of only by the Kaffirs, though the term Coloured person therein, as of old, includes Indians also.
('2', 452, 1, 10, 1002812) Under the old regime, the Pass law was rarely in force against the Indians; what the position would be under the strict British authority can easily be surmised.
('2', 452, 1, 11, 1002974) If relief to be granted is to be of the above nature, it is evident that it would be no relief at all.
('2', 452, 1, 12, 1003077) In contravention of the 14th article of the London Convention, the Transvaal Government passed laws practically classifying Indians with the natives of the soil.
('2', 452, 1, 13, 1003239) It will be remembered that both the late Lord Loch and Sir Hercules Robinson protested against any such classification and, under the above article, claimed for the Indians the same rights as the other British subjects.
('2', 452, 1, 14, 1003459) (See South African Bluebook—Grievances of British Indians.) Therefore, even if all the anti Indian legislation in these two Colonies is not to be repealed, the least that could be done is to distinguish between the British Indians and the Zulus.
('2', 452, 1, 15, 1003705) Under the circumstances, all the available energy must, for the present, be devoted to the question in these two Colonies and, if full justice is done there, Natal would soon have to fall in with them.
('2', 452, 1, 16, 1003907) In preparing these notes, in order to avoid needless repetition of facts, a previous knowledge of the memorials, etc., on the part of the sympathising friends has been assumed.

('2', 456, 3, 12, 1009750) 231. LETTER TO MAURICE
('2', 456, 4, 13, 1009773) RAJKOT, March 31, 1902
('2', 456, 5, 14, 1009796) DEAR MR. MAURICE, I had your letters, two in Calcutta and a third redirected from Calcutta to Rangoon.
('2', 456, 5, 15, 1009899) I was surprised to learn from your last letter that even up to the date thereof you had not received my reply to your first letter.
('2', 456, 5, 16, 1010031) I hope, however, that before you embarked for South Africa, you had received it.
('2', 456, 5, 17, 1010112) I do not know that I deserve the thanks you have thought fit to express for anything that I may have done in Calcutta to make your visit as comfortable as possible.
('2', 456, 5, 18, 1010277) It was nothing but duty done, and I wish I could have done more.
('2', 456, 5, 19, 1010342) After tremendous difficulty, I was able to move the President of the Chamber of Commerce, and as a result, a very sympathetic reply from the Viceroy has been secured.
('2', 456, 5, 20, 1010509) But, of course, sympathy alone would do very little.
('2', 456, 5, 21, 1010562) In order to call forth action in accordance with it, great effort on the part of the Indian public is necessary.

('2', 458, 5, 8, 1013022) 234. INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA
('2', 458, 6, 9, 1013051) RAJKOT, April 22, 1902 TO THE EDITOR The Times of India
('2', 458, 7, 10, 1013107) SIR, Your issue of the 10th instant contains a cablegram to the effect that a Bill, which imposes on the children of indentured Indians in Natal the same disabilities as the parents themselves, has been read a second time in the Legislative Assembly of the Colony.
('2', 458, 7, 11, 1013372) In the absence of the full text, it is rather difficult to comment upon the measure; but as the delivery of letters from South Africa is so very uncertain, and as I know with what swiftness Bills can become the law of the Colony, I venture to offer a few remarks.
('2', 458, 7, 12, 1013636) It was, I think, in the year 1893 that delegates appointed by the Natal Government came to India to persuade the Indian Government to sanction legislation requiring indentured Indians to return to India after the completion of their indentures or to pay a poll tax of £25 per year.
('2', 458, 7, 13, 1013918) There is a long history behind this delegation which, although painfully interesting, I am obliged to omit, in order to be brief.
('2', 458, 7, 14, 1014048) The then Viceroy, His Excellency Lord Elgin, while he absolutely refused to impose a poll tax of £25, unfortunately accepted the principle by consenting to a reduced tax of £3. Had His Lordship known, as I fear
('2', 459, 0, 1, 1014259) 460 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 459, 1, 2, 1014301) he did not do then, that a similar attempt was made some twenty years back without avail, probably he would not have yielded.
('2', 459, 1, 3, 1014427) Now the present Bill is, I fear, in a measure intended to accomplish what the delegation failed to do in 1893. For under it all children of indentured parents (even infants in arms!) would be liable to pay the £3 tax, and if an indentured Indian happens to have seven children, by no means an unlikely event, between him and his children he would have to pay £24 per year, a thing that would be absolutely beyond his capacity.
('2', 459, 1, 4, 1014854) I shudder to contemplate the evil effects of such a measure on the moral tone of the community which is called upon to pay such heavy penalties for the mere permission to exist in the country to which they have been actually invited or, shall I say, allured.
('2', 459, 1, 5, 1015113) The iniquity of the measure sanctioned by Lord Elgin in 1893 was graphically described by you, as well as the late Sir W. W. Hunter, who called the state of indenture one of semi slavery.
('2', 459, 1, 6, 1015301) I would beg to quote the opinions also of the Natal legislators, given when the proposal to compel return of the labourers was first made.
('2', 459, 1, 7, 1015440) The late Mr. Saunders, a distinguished Colonist, sometime member of the Natal Legislative Council, made the following remarks on the proposal:
('2', 459, 2, 8, 1015583) Though the Commission has made no recommendation on the subject of passing a law to force Indians back to India at the expiration of their term of service unless they renew their indentures, I wish to express my strong condemnation of any such idea, and I feel convinced that many, who now advocate the plan, when they realise what it means, will reject it as energetically as I do.
('2', 459, 2, 9, 1015966) Stop Indian immigration and face results, but don’t try to do what I can show is a great wrong.
('2', 459, 3, 10, 1016062) What is it but taking the best out of servants (the good as well as the bad), and then refusing them the enjoyment of the reward!
('2', 459, 3, 11, 1016192) Forcing them back (if we could, but we cannot) when their best days have been spent for our benefit.
('2', 459, 3, 12, 1016293) Where to?
('2', 459, 3, 13, 1016303) Why, back to face a prospect of starvation from which they sought to escape when they were young.
('2', 459, 3, 14, 1016401) Shylock like, taking the pound of flesh, and Shylock like we may rely on meeting Shylock’s reward.
('2', 459, 4, 15, 1016500) The late Mr. Escombe, sometime Prime Minister of the Colony, at the time of giving his evidence before a Commission appointed to inquire into Indian matters, deposed as follows: With reference to time expired Indians, I do not think that it ought to be compulsory on any man to go to any part of the world save for a crime for which he is transported.
('2', 459, 4, 16, 1016852) I hear a great deal of this question; I have been asked
('2', 460, 0, 1, 1016908) VOL 2 : 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 461
('2', 460, 1, 2, 1016951) again and again to take a different view, but I have not been able to do it.
('2', 460, 1, 3, 1017028) A man is brought here, in theory with his own consent, in practice very often without his consent.
('2', 460, 1, 4, 1017127) He gives the best five years of his life, he forms new ties, forgets the old ones, perhaps establishes a home here, and he cannot, according to my view of right and wrong, be sent back.
('2', 460, 1, 5, 1017313) Better by far to stop the further introduction of Indians altogether than to take what work you can out of them and order them away.
('2', 460, 1, 6, 1017446) The Colony, or part of the Colony, seems to want Indians but also wishes to avoid the consequences of Indian immigration.
('2', 460, 1, 7, 1017568) The Indian people do no harm as far as I know; in certain respects they do a great deal of good.
('2', 460, 1, 8, 1017665) I have never heard a reason to justify the extradition of a man who has behaved well for five years.
('2', 460, 1, 9, 1017766) I do not think that the Indian, at the expiration of his five years’ service, should be placed under police supervision unless he is a criminal.
('2', 460, 1, 10, 1017911) I know not why Arabs should be placed under police supervision more than Europeans.
('2', 460, 1, 11, 1017995) In cases of some Arabs the thing is simply ridiculous.
('2', 460, 1, 12, 1018050) They are men of large means, large connections, who are always used in trade if they can be dealt with more profitably than others.
('2', 460, 1, 13, 1018182) I am aware that the honourable gentleman, after all, under pressure of electioneering circumstances, later on did “take a different view.” The above extracts deal with compulsory return, but seeing that the poll tax is meant to secure such a return of the indentured Indians they are applicable to it also, and the Bill under discussion would necessarily imply the return of the children, should they choose not to pay the tax.
('2', 460, 1, 14, 1018610) You as well as your other contemporaries have laid the Indian settlers under deep obligation by frequently ventilating their grievances.
('2', 460, 1, 15, 1018747) It, however, appears that European Colonists in Natal will not be happy until every Indian is driven out of Natal.
('2', 460, 1, 16, 1018862) It is, therefore, with the Indian a life and death struggle.
('2', 460, 1, 17, 1018923) His cause is admittedly absolutely just.
('2', 460, 1, 18, 1018964) There are many other circumstances favourable to justice being done.
('2', 460, 1, 19, 1019033) We have a very strong Viceroy.
('2', 460, 1, 20, 1019064) The Colonial Secretary has often expressed his sympathy.
('2', 460, 1, 21, 1019121) Will you kindly put all these forces in motion?
('2', 460, 1, 22, 1019169) It would not be premature to move now.
('2', 460, 1, 23, 1019208) Probably, by the time papers are received from Natal, the Bill, too, would have been received at the Colonial Office for sanction.
('2', 460, 1, 24, 1019339) There is, therefore, hardly time to wait.
('2', 460, 1, 25, 1019381) I may state that the Colonial constitution requires sanction from the Home Government for all Colour legislation.
('2', 460, 2, 26, 1019495) M. K. GANDHI The Times of India, 1 5 1902

('2', 463, 0, 1, 1023355) 464 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 463, 1, 2, 1023397) 238. NOTES ON THE INDIAN QUESTION
('2', 463, 2, 3, 1023431) RAJKOT, May 6, 1902
('2', 463, 3, 4, 1023451) In these notes, the Indian question as affecting Natal and the two new Colonies is alone considered.
('2', 463, 5, 5, 1023552) Natal is a self governing Colony whose constitution requires that all Colour legislation, before coming into force, must receive the sanction of His Majesty the King, and it provides generally that any laws passed by the Colonial legislature may be disallowed within two years of their passing.
('2', 463, 5, 6, 1023847) The Colony has a white population of about 60,000 and an equal number of British Indian settlers.
('2', 463, 5, 7, 1023945) The indigenous people, that is, the Zulus, are a fine body of men, but they are very lazy, and will with difficulty work at a stretch for six months.
('2', 463, 5, 8, 1024095) When, therefore, the white settlers were at their wit’s end with reference to the steady supply of reliable labour and the Colony was becoming bankrupt, the Legislature resorted to Indian labour and, after some negotiations, the Indian Government sanctioned the immigration of indentured Indians of Natal.
('2', 463, 5, 9, 1024401) This was nearly 40 years ago.
('2', 463, 5, 10, 1024431) The demand for Indian labour continued to increase and with it also the prosperity of the Colony.
('2', 463, 5, 11, 1024529) These men contracted to serve, for a period of 5 years, any master to whom they may be allotted at a monthly wage of 10s.
('2', 463, 5, 12, 1024651) for the first year, with an increase of Is.
('2', 463, 5, 13, 1024695) per year.
('2', 463, 5, 14, 1024705) The contract also included free lodging, medical attendance and a free return passage at the end thereof.
('2', 463, 5, 15, 1024811) The relations between the masters and the men are regulated by a special code which imposes some very stringent obligations on the men, a breach whereof becomes a criminal offence.
('2', 463, 5, 16, 1024992) These labourers were naturally followed by free Indian settlers, that is to say, those who paid their own passage and went to the Colony in pursuit of trade, etc.
('2', 463, 5, 17, 1025155) The indentured Indians, too, after becoming free, instead of availing themselves of a free return passage, for the best part elected to remain in the Colony and developed into mechanics, petty traders, farmers, etc.
('2', 463, 5, 18, 1025371) This aroused keen trade jealousy among the white men who found no difficulty in picking out weakest points, viz., the habit of overcrowding, communal insanitation and some crude customs or superstitions.
('2', 463, 5, 19, 1025575) These were terribly
('2', 464, 0, 1, 1025595) VOL 2 : 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 465
('2', 464, 1, 2, 1025638) magnified and were often, to our great disadvantage, discussed in the papers, and thus arose the popular prejudice against the Indian settlers who, being themselves unlettered and having no friend who would put their side of the question before the people, were unable to correct it.
('2', 464, 1, 3, 1025922) Before 1894, Natal was a Crown Colony, and attempts made to reproduce that prejudice in legislation were frustrated, but the Colony, having secured rights of complete self government, succeeded in passing anti Indian measures.
('2', 464, 1, 4, 1026149) The first attempt made was to pass laws.
('2', 464, 1, 5, 1026190) specially applicable to Indians; for instance, a Bill was introduced preventing Indians from exercising the right of franchise.
('2', 464, 1, 6, 1026318) This was objected to by the Indians and, ultimately, the Colonial Secretary disallowed it.
('2', 464, 1, 7, 1026409) At the time of agitating against the measure, the Indians made it absolutely clear that they did not desire to possess in the Colony any political power, but they objected to it on the ground that it was a preliminary step, as it afterwards proved to be, towards the curtailment of the rights of the British Indian settlers.
('2', 464, 1, 8, 1026734) To return, although the Bill was disallowed, it was replaced by another equally bad, if not worse, for the replacing Bill, which is now the law of the land, disqualifies those who have not hitherto exercised the Parliamentary franchise in their own country.
('2', 464, 1, 9, 1026992) Thus was opened the door to indirect legislation, such as the laws affecting immigration and dealers’ licenses.
('2', 464, 1, 10, 1027104) The Immigration Restriction Act prohibits the entry into the Colony of all those who, not having been previously domiciled there or not being wife or minor children of such persons, are unable to write out in one of the European languages an application in terms of the form attached to it.
('2', 464, 1, 11, 1027395) The Dealers’ Licenses Act gives absolute powers to the Licensing Officers appointed thereunder to refuse or to grant trading licenses.
('2', 464, 1, 12, 1027530) Their decisions are appealable only before the Municipal Corporations which appoint them and which, consisting as they do chiefly of tradespeople, try to do away with as many Indian licenses as possible.
('2', 464, 1, 13, 1027734) As a matter of fact, these bodies even instruct their officers whether to grant particular licenses or not.
('2', 464, 1, 14, 1027842) The inherent jurisdiction of the Supreme Court has been specially taken away.
('2', 464, 1, 15, 1027920) The licensing law is a matter of eternal soreness and, as the licenses must be renewed every year, the Indian trader has to tremble on the approach of every new year.
('2', 464, 1, 16, 1028087) Notwithstanding these vexing disabilities, nothing, I am afraid, can be directly done for the present, seeing that they are all laws of Natal duly accepted by the Home Government, but the Europeans are not satisfied with what they have gained.
('2', 464, 1, 17, 1028331) They are anxious to impose
('2', 465, 0, 1, 1028358) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 465, 1, 2, 1028400) further disabilities by indirect means.
('2', 465, 1, 3, 1028440) I see from the papers received from Natal that the Natal Civil Service Board has lately passed a bye law regulating the admission of candidates for that examination, and it provides that children of parents.
('2', 465, 1, 4, 1028648) affected by the disfranchising law above referred to shall not be admissible as candidates.
('2', 465, 1, 5, 1028740) In my opinion, this bye law is illegal, going as it does to the root of the Constitution of the Colony.
('2', 465, 1, 6, 1028844) For, if it were an Act of the Colonial Legislature, it would require the sanction of the Home Government.
('2', 465, 1, 7, 1028950) Moreover, on general principles the bye laws cannot be allowed to widen or restrict the scope of the Act under which they are framed.
('2', 465, 1, 8, 1029084) I have seen the Civil Service Act and in it I read no warrant for such a bye law.
('2', 465, 1, 9, 1029166) I cite this instance just to show to what length the principle of indirect legislation has been carried.
('2', 465, 1, 10, 1029271) Of course, our people in Natal will have, if necessary, to test its legality.
('2', 465, 1, 11, 1029349) I have also advised them to memorialize the Governor of the Colony.
('2', 465, 1, 12, 1029417) The recently published cablegram 1 in the papers shows the activity of the Europeans in another direction.
('2', 465, 1, 13, 1029524) In 1895, the indentured immigration law was amended so as to lengthen the period of indenture to 10 years and to compel the return to India after the completion of the indenture or, in lieu thereof, to an annual poll tax of £3. Now according to the cablegram, they propose to exact the poll tax not only from the indentured immigrant but also from his children.
('2', 465, 2, 14, 1029886) TRANSVAAL AND THE ORANGE RIVER COLONY
('2', 465, 3, 15, 1029924) In the Transvaal, the Indians cannot own land or live except in Locations.
('2', 465, 3, 16, 1029999) They cannot walk on the footpaths, must take out passes like the Kaffirs.
('2', 465, 3, 17, 1030073) Now when the Location law was passed, Mr. Chamberlain, in reply to the Indian memorial protesting against it and the subsequent stages, gave a very sympathetic reply.
('2', 465, 3, 18, 1030240) He even suggested he might have granted tangible relief had his hands not been tied down by the acts of his predecessor.
('2', 465, 3, 19, 1030361) Moreover, Lord Lansdowne has been reported to have given the disabilities of the Indians as one of the causes of the present war.
('2', 465, 3, 20, 1030491) Under such circumstances, it was naturally expected that, after the country passed into British occupation, the disabilities of the Indians would be swept away, but it is feared that the expectation may not be realised.
('2', 465, 3, 21, 1030711) Mr. Chamberlain appears to be shuffling.
('2', 465, 3, 22, 1030752) He talks of
('2', 465, 4, 23, 1030764) 1 Vide “Letter to The Times of India”, April 22, 1902.
('2', 466, 0, 1, 1030819) VOL 2 : 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 467
('2', 466, 1, 2, 1030862) conferring with Lord Milner and asking him what changes are possible in the old legislation inherited by the British.
('2', 466, 1, 3, 1030980) Such an attitude is very dangerous.
('2', 466, 1, 4, 1031016) Why should there be any such reference at all?
('2', 466, 1, 5, 1031063) Surely, the very first thing to do should be to equalise the status of all British subjects and then consider whether any section merits special treatment.
('2', 466, 1, 6, 1031219) I understand, and to a certain extent, even sympathise with, this position.
('2', 466, 1, 7, 1031295) In 1896, when he penned his dispatch referred to above, he little thought that the war would be coming so soon and that, too, in such an acute form as to throw the whole country into his hands.
('2', 466, 1, 8, 1031489) Now he must find it difficult, on the one hand, to conciliate the very reasonable and absolutely just demands of the Indians as well as to act according to the terms of his despatch, and, on the other hand, to satisfy the anti Indian prejudice.
('2', 466, 1, 9, 1031734) He also probably seems to be on the verge of seeing, in his own lifetime and during his term of office, the South African Federation completed.
('2', 466, 1, 10, 1031878) The Indian question must stand in his way, and, if he can harmonise anti Indian legislation in South Africa, that difficulty is removed.
('2', 466, 1, 11, 1032015) It is, if I am not mistaken, for this reason that he is “tacking”.
('2', 466, 1, 12, 1032082) He wants to sound the Cape and Natal on the question and modify the old legislation only so far as it is acceptable to the two Colonies.
('2', 466, 1, 13, 1032219) It is, then, clear what should be the modus operandi on the part of the Indian publicists.
('2', 466, 1, 14, 1032310) All the available energy has to be directed towards the new Colonies, and, if a satisfactory solution can be secured, the Colony of Natal must necessarily yield, and, in my humble opinion, the way theagitation [ .
('2', 466, 1, 15, 1032524) .] 1 the Indian papers to keep the matter constantly before the public and the Government.
('2', 466, 1, 16, 1032615) Anglo Indian sympathy in this matter is with us and that must at all hazards be retained.
('2', 466, 1, 17, 1032705) I attach hereto a copy of the letter from the Viceroy addressed to Mr. Turner which shows his views and which shows also that the Bengal Chamber of Commerce is prepared to move.
('2', 466, 1, 18, 1032883) The public associations must combine.
('2', 466, 1, 19, 1032921) And, if one association were to.
('2', 466, 1, 20, 1032954) make the question of foreign emigration its special study, it can direct in proper channels the whole agitation such that the Home Government cannot easily disregard it.
('2', 466, 1, 21, 1033124) In South Africa, we are engaged in a struggle for existence with a race that is intensely active and rich, and which does not brook a defeat.
('2', 466, 1, 22, 1033266) A corresponding activity continually is required on our part, and success is ultimately bound to come.
('2', 466, 2, 23, 1033369) 1 Not decipherable.

('2', 468, 1, 2, 1035355) 240. INDIANS IN NATAL
('2', 468, 2, 3, 1035377) RAJKOT, May 10, 1902 TO THE EDITOR The Times of India BOMBAY
('2', 468, 3, 4, 1035438) SIR, With reference to my letter about the position of the British Indians in Natal published in your issue of the 1st instant, I have now received from Natal the papers containing the text of the Bill, which I beg to give below: Bill to amend the Indian Immigration Amendment Act, providing that every Indian child, on attaining the age of majority (males 16, females 13), shall be obliged (a) to go to India, or (b) to remain in Natal under indentures similar to and renewable in the same manner as the re indenture referred to in Act No.
('2', 468, 3, 5, 1035979) 17, 1895, as amended by subsequent Acts, or (c) to take out year by year, in terms of Section 6 of Act No.
('2', 468, 3, 6, 1036086) 17, 1895, a pass or license to remain in the Colony.
('2', 468, 3, 7, 1036139) Provided, however, that if such child attains majority before the completion of his father’s first or any subsequent indenture, the operation of this section shall be suspended until the completion of such indenture.
('2', 468, 3, 8, 1036356) In the case of a child whose father is dead or not in Natal, or whose mother was unmarried at the time of the child’s birth, the above reference to the father’s indenture shall be deemed to apply to the mother’s indenture.
('2', 468, 3, 9, 1036579) A child to whom this Act applies shall be entitled to a free passage to India in order to enable him to proceed thither at the end of the first or any renewed term of indenture of his father (or of his mother, as the case may be).
('2', 468, 3, 10, 1036810) The right to a free passage shall however be lost (a) if the father, or, as in the above case, the mother, shall have completed a term of indenture during the child’s minority, and shall not have returned to India or entered into a fresh indenture in terms of Act No.
('2', 468, 3, 11, 1037078) 17, 1895, (b) if the child does not go to India by the first opportunity available to him after attaining his majority or after the end of a term of indenture entered into under this Act.
('2', 468, 3, 12, 1037266) The Act does not apply to persons who have attained the age of majority previous to the date of taking effect of the Act, but it makes no difference whether the child is born before or after arrival of parents in Natal.
('2', 468, 3, 13, 1037486) The Bill, then, if it is any satisfaction to know the fact, is not to apply to infants in arms.
('2', 468, 3, 14, 1037582) The more, however, one considers it, the more unjust it is found to be.
('2', 468, 3, 15, 1037654) It is worthy of note that the children who have received an
('2', 469, 0, 1, 1037714) 470 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 469, 1, 2, 1037756) elementary education in the Colony are expected by the Bill to serve at a rate of wages far below the market rate, like well built men as field labourers from “sunrise to sunset”, and that the children born of the so called unlawful connections, too, are brought under the Bill.
('2', 469, 1, 3, 1038035) Thus, the children of an indentured woman married according to the religious rites of her sect to a free Indian, but whose marriage is not registered and not recognised in the Colony, will be under the same restrictions as indentured Indians.
('2', 469, 1, 4, 1038278) But it is hardly worth while to examine the details of a measure whose principle is repugnant to the ordinary rules of justice as it is known to those brought up under the British Constitution.
('2', 469, 1, 5, 1038472) The same mail that has brought the papers containing the text of the Bill also brings the news that Indian children, attending the schools in the Colony, are to be debarred from receiving the Coronation commemoration medals which are to be presented by the Government in June next to all the European children attending the schools.
('2', 469, 1, 6, 1038805) The exclusion is certainly not based on grounds of economy, for the Indian children are, I think, about 3,000 against 20,000 European children.
('2', 469, 1, 7, 1038949) Evidently, the Coronation celebration day is to be marked out for the Indian children to realise as vividly as possible that the possession of a brown skin is a sure mark of humiliation and degradation in the estimation of the Government of the Colony.

('2', 471, 9, 18, 1042085) RAJKOT, May 20, 1902 [TO THE EDITOR The Englishman]
('2', 471, 10, 19, 1042137) [SIR,] I venture to ask for a short space in your paper to enable me to draw the attention of the public to the latest attempt of the Natal Legislature to impose further disabilities on the British Indian settlers in that Colony.
('2', 471, 10, 20, 1042367) The Natal Parliament has passed a Bill which makes the children (males 16, and females 13 years old) of indentured Indians liable, like
('2', 471, 11, 21, 1042503) 1 Vide footnote above.
('2', 472, 0, 1, 1042526) VOL 2 : 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 473
('2', 472, 1, 2, 1042569) their parents,
('2', 472, 2, 3, 1042584) (a) to return to India, or
('2', 472, 3, 4, 1042611) (b) to enter into indentured service, or
('2', 472, 4, 5, 1042652) (c) to pay the annual poll tax of £3.
('2', 472, 5, 6, 1042690) During Lord Elgin’s viceroyalty, a deputation 1 came all the way from Natal to induce His Lordship to sanction legislation terminating the indentures in India, thus preventing their permanent settlement in the Colony, or imposing a poll tax of £25 per year on each indentured Indian who may wish to remain in the Colony as a free man.
('2', 472, 5, 7, 1043025) Happily, His Lordship would not listen to any such proposal, but unfortunately, and, I believe, because His Lordship was probably un aware of certain circumstances, reluctantly accepted the principle of taxation as a price for freedom by sanctioning the imposition of the £3 annual tax.
('2', 472, 5, 8, 1043312) Now if the Bill in question becomes law, the Natal Government would have very nearly succeeded in attaining what they failed to get 8 years ago.
('2', 472, 5, 9, 1043457) Imperialism is on the lips of everybody, more especially in the Colonies.How to weld the different parts of the British Dominions into one beautiful unbreakable whole is a problem which the greatest British politicians of the day are endeavouring to solve, and yet, here is a Colony which is making invidious distinctions between one class of British subjects and another in a most aggravating manner.
('2', 472, 5, 10, 1043859) The attitude of the Natal Government towards the indentured Indians is indefensible from every point of view.
('2', 472, 5, 11, 1043969) These men go to Natal at the invitation of the Colony to materially help forward its ad vancement.
('2', 472, 5, 12, 1044068) Only last month you published a cablegram stating that the Premier of the Colony, in reply to the proposal to stop indentured emigration from India to the Colony, said that such a thing would paralyse its industries.
('2', 472, 5, 13, 1044285) It was,“when”, in the words of a Natal Legislator, “the fate of the Colony hung in the balance,” that “In dian labourers were introduced, up went the prices, and up again went the revenue, wages and salary.” It hardly accords with justice and fair ness to tax the people who have thus given the best 5 years of their lives to the Colony at a rate of wages far below the market rate.
('2', 472, 5, 14, 1044668) Even in the Colony, though it was a voice in the wilderness, there was one
('2', 472, 6, 15, 1044743) 1 The Binns Mason Commission of 1893 4.
('2', 473, 0, 1, 1044783) 474 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 473, 1, 2, 1044825) gentleman, an ex Attorney General, Mr. Morcom, K.C., who protested against the Bill in the following terms.
('2', 473, 1, 3, 1044933) He said
('2', 473, 2, 4, 1044941) that Indian children who happened to be born in the Colony would have to be deported, or indentured for life, or pay the license [fee] of £3 a year.
('2', 473, 2, 5, 1045090) The way in which the Colony was flooded with Indians for labour might induce many undesirable circumstances but it was utterly impossible for the House, without disregard of justice or constitutional propriety, to deport these children who had had the misfortune to be born in the Colony.
('2', 473, 2, 6, 1045379) So long as there are men in Natal who, like Mr. Morcom, are not blinded by prejudice, so long will there be hope for justice being ultimately secured, but, until public opinion there has veered round in favour of justice and fairness, it is very essential that the Indian public should remain on the alert, and that the Home Government firmly insist on justice being done to the Indians.
('2', 473, 2, 7, 1045767) In the words of Mr. Morcom, “the idea seems to be to get all the advantages out of the system without regard to its drawback.” Would it not then be “better by far”, in the words of another Natal Legislator, “to stop the further introduction of Indians altogether than to take what work you can out of them and then order them away”?
('2', 473, 2, 8, 1046100) This is a question on which there is, there can be, no division of opinion.
('2', 473, 2, 9, 1046176) May I ask you to raise your powerful voice against the con templated injustice?
('2', 473, 2, 10, 1046256) I may state that the Bill has been specially reserved for sanction from the Home Government before it can become law of the Colony.

('2', 473, 4, 12, 1046439) 245. INDIA AND NATAL 1
('2', 473, 5, 13, 1046462) The Imperial wave is passing rather furiously over the British dominions.
('2', 473, 5, 14, 1046536) There will be hearty rejoicings wherever the Union Jack floats, during the Coronation.
('2', 473, 5, 15, 1046623) At such a time, peace and good will unto all British subjects should be the desire of everyone owning the sovereignty of King Edward VII.
('2', 473, 5, 16, 1046761) There can be no true imperialism
('2', 473, 6, 17, 1046794) 1 This article by Gandhiji (vide “Indians in Natal”, 31 5 1902, infra), was first published in The Voice of India.
('2', 473, 6, 18, 1046909) Harijan, 23 10 1949, reproduced it from an earlier, typewritten draft (with several verbal variations) in the possession of Chhaganlal Gandhi, Gandhiji’s nephew and associate in South Africa.
('2', 474, 0, 1, 1047101) VOL 2 : 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 475
('2', 474, 1, 2, 1047144) unless we have oneness, harmony and toleration among all classes of British subjects.
('2', 474, 1, 3, 1047230) Let us see, then, how the Colony of Natal, which prides itself on being the most British Colony in South Africa, pro poses to help in realizing this imperial brotherhood and in spreading peace and good will among all.
('2', 474, 1, 4, 1047448) Attention has already been drawn to the piece of injustice sought to be perpetrated by the Natal Gover nment on the British Indian settlers in that fair land.
('2', 474, 1, 5, 1047607) To understand thoroughly the gravity of the situation, it would be well to know the history of Indian emigration to Natal.
('2', 474, 1, 6, 1047730) As early as 1862, the Colony found, after several experiments, that it could not “stand on its legs” unless it imported Indian labour in order to develop its agricultural resources.
('2', 474, 1, 7, 1047912) The natives of the soil, 400,000 in number, were found to be too lazy to work.
('2', 474, 1, 8, 1047991) The climate was too trying for the white men to do much out door work.
('2', 474, 1, 9, 1048062) When, therefore, the “fate of the Colony hung in the balance,” the Indian Government were approached to help it out of its difficulty.
('2', 474, 1, 10, 1048197) All kinds of inducements were offered to the first Indian settlers, and a con tinual stream of emigrants flowed into the Colony from India.
('2', 474, 1, 11, 1048337) Later on, when misgivings arose as to the utility of introducing the Indian element into the Colony, a Commission was appointed to examine the whole question, and one of the Commissioners, Mr. Saunders, thus recorded his opinion:
('2', 474, 2, 12, 1048567) The Indian immigration brought prosperity, prices rose, people were no longer content to grow or sell produce for a song; they could do better; war, high prices for wool, sugar, etc., kept up prosperity ant prices of local produce In which the Indians dealt.
('2', 474, 3, 13, 1048826) Our records prove, as do those of other Colonies, that the introduction of coloured labour which develops and draws out the hidden capabilities of the soil and its unoccupied acres, opens out at the same time numerous unforeseen fields for the profitable employment of white settlers.
('2', 474, 3, 14, 1049111) If we look back to 1859, we shall find that the assured promise of Indian labour resulted in an immediate rise of revenue.
('2', 474, 3, 15, 1049234) But a ‘few years later, alarm arose that it will be suspended simultaneously; down went the revenue; .
('2', 474, 3, 16, 1049337) and yet another change, a fresh promise of renewed Indian immigration created is effect, and up again wentthe revenue.
('2', 474, 3, 17, 1049456) Records like these ought to tell their own tale and silence childish sentimentalities and mean jealousies.
('2', 474, 4, 18, 1049563) The present Premier of the Colony has informed us only lately that a stoppage of Indian emigration would paralyze its industries.
('2', 474, 4, 19, 1049693) The Indian labourer, then, is admittedly indispensable to the welfare of the Colony.
('2', 474, 4, 20, 1049778) As in 1862, so in 1899, it was India which came to the
('2', 475, 0, 1, 1049833) 476 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 475, 1, 2, 1049875) rescue in its hour of need.
('2', 475, 1, 3, 1049903) Without Indian labour in 1862 the Colony would have become bankrupt, if its own legislators have given us correct information.
('2', 475, 1, 4, 1050030) In 1899, as the whole world knows, without an Indian army, its capital and its port would have been in Boer hands.
('2', 475, 1, 5, 1050145) As a reward for all these services, the Natal Parliament has passed a Bill, imposing an annual tax of £3 on the children of indentured Indians (males 16 years, females 13) unless, on attaining the artificial majority, they either deported themselves from the Colony or entered into a series of indentures during their stay in the.
('2', 475, 1, 6, 1050476) Colony!
('2', 475, 1, 7, 1050484) It maybe remarked in passing that the indenture wage is 10s.
('2', 475, 1, 8, 1050545) per month the minimum, and £1 per month the maximum—a rate which is far below the market rate; moreover, breaches of these indentures on the part of the indentured men become criminal offences which, under ordinary contracts, can only be dealt with civilly.
('2', 475, 1, 9, 1050803) It is painful to recall the fact that it was Lord Elgin’s Government that paved the way for the imposition of a poll tax on the children of the immigrants by consenting to a levy of the tax on the parents; but we have no hesitation in saying that the parents’ liability to pay the tax cannot justify a similar imposition upon the children, for, the former, at any rate, are presumed to know the conditions under which they go to Natal, and lawyers may say, that if they choose to accept very onerous conditions, it is their look out.
('2', 475, 1, 10, 1051337) But are the children presumed to know any such conditions?
('2', 475, 1, 11, 1051396) That they are born of such parents is no doubt a grievous misfortune.
('2', 475, 1, 12, 1051466) Unfortunately, they cannot help themselves.
('2', 475, 1, 13, 1051510) The parents, again, know what indentured labour is, they know what India is; but the same cannot be said of their children born in the Colony.
('2', 475, 1, 14, 1051653) To expect them, after they have, perhaps, received some education, and known its worth in the Colony, either to go to India or to accept a status described by the late Sir W. W. Hunter as that of semi slavery, is cruel in the extreme.
('2', 475, 1, 15, 1051888) Evidently, the Colony wants to get all it can out of the poor Indian, and at the same time to avoid the consequences of the in troduction of Indian labour.
('2', 475, 1, 16, 1052044) A more straightforward course to adopt would be, if it did not care to have the Indian as he is, to do away with his labour altogether—an attitude which would be at once intelligible and satisfactory.
('2', 475, 1, 17, 1052245) We have no wish to force our countrymen on them, but it is fair to expect a just British treatment for those who are invited to the Colony; and if it is impossible for the Indian Government to
('2', 476, 0, 1, 1052438) VOL 2 : 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 477
('2', 476, 1, 2, 1052481) secure for the settlers a fair treatment, and if the Colony will not, of its own accord, stop the State regulated importation of Indian labour, it is clearly the duty of our Government to help it to do so.
('2', 476, 1, 3, 1052687) We have fortunately a vigilant andmasterful Viceroy in Lord Curzon, and we hope His Excellency will not allow any serious injustice to be perpetrated.
('2', 476, 1, 4, 1052838) May we not also appeal to sober minded people in the Colony itself?
('2', 476, 1, 5, 1052906) We see that one member at least of the Natal Parliament, Mr. Morcom, would have nothing to do with the Bill, the un British character of which he showed up in forcible language.
('2', 476, 1, 6, 1053084) We are sure there must be many who think like Mr. Morcom.
('2', 476, 1, 7, 1053142) Why will they not all speak out like him and break down the barrier of prejudice against the poor British Indian?
('2', 476, 1, 8, 1053256) In the meanwhile, however, we have a right to look up to Mr. Chamberlain to exercise his powerful influence ii the Colonies on the side of justice and fairplay.
('2', 476, 1, 9, 1053417) The Voice of India, 31 5 1902

('2', 477, 4, 8, 1054788) 247. LETTER TO NAZAR AND KHAN
('2', 477, 5, 9, 1054818) RAJKOT, June 3, 1902
('2', 477, 6, 10, 1054839) DEAR MESSRS NAZAR AND KHAN,
('2', 477, 7, 11, 1054867) I now enclose herewith a memo of expenditure 1 on account of the Natal work.
('2', 477, 7, 12, 1054944) You will notice that it amounts to Rs. 378 7 9, a trifle over Rs. 375 realised from the draft.
('2', 477, 7, 13, 1055039) Of late, South African work has increased considerably.
('2', 477, 7, 14, 1055095) I returned from Calcutta at the end of February, and since that time I have engaged a clerk on the usual terms, namely, that he gets copying charges which are for the most part paid by the clients.
('2', 477, 7, 15, 1055293) At present I am supposed to be taking rest, nor would there be much work for me in Kathiawar even if I opened a regular office.
('2', 477, 7, 16, 1055421) The real use I can make, therefore, of clerical assistance is with reference to public work.
('2', 477, 7, 17, 1055514) Now about 100 sides of type written matter have been already copied, not including carbon copies, besides a lot of Gujarati correspondence and other work.
('2', 477, 7, 18, 1055669) As copying fees for this work, I have so far paid only Rs. 15. The usual charges here are half a rupee per each written side.
('2', 477, 7, 19, 1055795) I think I am understating the work when I say that he has had to devote on an average 3 hours per day.
('2', 477, 7, 20, 1055898) Under the circumstances, I consider the payment to be very small.
('2', 477, 7, 21, 1055964) I should like to be able to pay him at least Rs. 40 for the whole of the work up to date.
('2', 477, 7, 22, 1056054) Moreover, the work continues.
('2', 477, 7, 23, 1056084) Had I got funds, I should have been able to distribute literature more widely.
('2', 477, 7, 24, 1056163) As it is, I am obliged to work as if I had no funds.
('2', 477, 7, 25, 1056216) I should very much like to subscribe to one or two papers, for instance India, Englishman, etc., which are not to be had in the Rajkot Library; also to directories.
('2', 477, 7, 26, 1056381) Soon after reaching Bombay, I invested in a typewriter Rs. 200. The machine has been wholly used for public work.
('2', 477, 7, 27, 1056495) I have, therefore, to submit the following three propositions to the Congress: 1st.
('2', 477, 7, 28, 1056579) It should vote the balance of my account and Rs. 25 extra
('2', 477, 8, 29, 1056637) 1 This is not available.
('2', 478, 0, 1, 1056662) VOL 2 : 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 479
('2', 478, 1, 2, 1056705) for clerical fees, i.e., Rs. 28 7 9. 2nd.
('2', 478, 1, 3, 1056747) It should buy over the typewriter, to be taken over by me whenever I am in a position to do so, at the same price, unless, it is sooner taken away by the Congress from me.
('2', 478, 1, 4, 1056919) The Congress should vote a further sum of £25 to cover future expenses.
('2', 478, 2, 5, 1056991) If all the three propositions are accepted, you will have to send me £25, and the cost of the typewriter plus Rs. 28 7 9. I am thoroughly aware that any expense beyond £25 is undertaken at my own risk and, at the time of buying the typewriter, I had absolutely no thought of making the proposal I am now making, as I did not then expect my pecuniary position to be so bad as it is.
('2', 478, 2, 6, 1057373) It is, therefore, entirely at the option of theCongress whether to accept or to reject the first two proposals, by which I mean the Congress must not think of sanctioning them, because they are my proposals.
('2', 478, 2, 7, 1057581) If, on their merits, they appear to be reasonable and if it was a matter of buying a new typewriter, the Congress would still invest in it, then alone should the 2 proposals be considered.
('2', 478, 2, 8, 1057770) I may also state that the clerk working with me is my nephew and, but for the volume of work, I should not have thought of paying any clerical charges to him.
('2', 478, 2, 9, 1057929) He is not a volunteer who may be expected to work to any extent without pay.
('2', 478, 2, 10, 1058006) He has no source of income except through me, As to the 3rd proposal, if it is accepted, it will enable me the better to carry on the public work, whenever any expenses are necessary.

('2', 479, 4, 5, 1059130) 248. LETTER TO MADANJIT 1
('2', 479, 5, 6, 1059156) RAJKOT, [June 3, 1902] 2
('2', 479, 6, 7, 1059181) DEAR MADANJIT,
('2', 479, 7, 8, 1059196) Happening to go to Junagadh, I met there your brothers, mother in law and brother in law.
('2', 479, 7, 9, 1059286) I did my best to explain the position and have pacified them.
('2', 479, 7, 10, 1059348) Your mother in law complained that they had had no letter from you.
('2', 479, 7, 11, 1059416) This is not proper.
('2', 479, 7, 12, 1059436) You ought to write to her from time to time.
('2', 479, 7, 13, 1059481) That gives satisfaction as well as consolation.
('2', 479, 7, 14, 1059529) Most probably, Labhshanker will bring your wife with him.
('2', 479, 7, 15, 1059587) If, however, your mother in law does not at all agree to this, he will come alone.
('2', 479, 7, 16, 1059670) You may come here and take her with you when she is in a position to attend to household work.
('2', 479, 7, 17, 1059765) It seems your mother in law is opposed to sending her with anyone else.
('2', 479, 7, 18, 1059837) Please read the letter I have written to Mr. Nazar to day.
('2', 479, 7, 19, 1059896) From that you will understand how great must be my need of money.
('2', 479, 7, 20, 1059962) For the present, I think, it will be possible for me to stay in Bombay only if the amounts due start coming in from your end regularly.
('2', 479, 8, 21, 1060098) From the photostat of the office copy in Gujarati: S.N. 3958.
('2', 479, 9, 22, 1060160) 1 Madanjit Vyavaharik, a co worker of Gandhiji in South Africa.
('2', 479, 9, 23, 1060224) He set up the International Printing Press in Durban, in 1898, at Gandhiji’s suggestion and with his help started in 1903 the Indian Opinion, which Gandhiji took over in 1904. 2 The date is determined by the reference in this letter to the one he addressed the came day to Nazar and Khan.
('2', 480, 0, 1, 1060513) VOL 2 : 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 481
('2', 480, 1, 2, 1060556) 249. MEMORIAL TO LORD HAMILTON 1
('2', 480, 2, 3, 1060589) BOMBAY PRESIDENCY ASSOCIATION APOLLO BUNDER, BOMBAY, June 5, 1902
('2', 480, 3, 4, 1060655) TO THE RIGHT HONOURABLE LORD GEORGE HAMILTON H.M.’S PRINCIPAL SECRETARY OF STATE FOR INDIA IN COUNCIL LONDON
('2', 480, 4, 5, 1060764) YOUR LORDSHIP,
('2', 480, 5, 6, 1060779) By direction of the Council of the Bombay Presidency Association, we beg to draw Your Lordship’s attention to a Bill which has passed its second reading in the Legislative Assembly of Natal and which is termed “The Bill to Amend the Indian Immigration Amendment Act”.
('2', 480, 5, 7, 1061047) The Bill in effect purposes to bring [under it] the major children (males 16 years and females 13) of the British Indians, indentured under the Act No.
('2', 480, 5, 8, 1061199) 17 of 1885 of the Natal Legislature, and would, therefore, like their parents, render them liable: (a) to return to India at the Colony’s expense or (b) to enter into indentured service or (c) to pay the annual poll tax of £3. It is difficult to say whether the Bill will be finally passed by both the Houses and reach the Colonial Office for sanction.
('2', 480, 5, 9, 1061552) But, in view of the uncertainty of postal delivery of letters from South Africa, the Council deems it right, even at this somewhat premature stage, to enter this humble protest against this latest attempt of the Natal Government to impose restrictions of a harsh character on the liberty of the British Indians.
('2', 480, 5, 10, 1061864) As Your Lordship is aware, it was with great reluctance that HisExcellency Lord Elgin, the then Viceroy, sanctioned in 1894 the imposition on the indentured Indians of the £3 tax, euphemistically called a pass or licence, to remain in the Colony.
('2', 480, 5, 11, 1062111) That tax is admitted
('2', 480, 6, 12, 1062132) 1 An advance copy bearing the date May 24 was sent to India, but the memorial was submitted to the Government of Bombay under the date June 5, for transmission to the Secretary of State for India.
('2', 481, 0, 1, 1062329) 482 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('2', 481, 1, 2, 1062371) to be severe enough, though the original proposal of the Natal Government was to secure permission to levy a £25 tax.
('2', 481, 1, 3, 1062489) It is now evidently sought to reach the same figure as much as possible by taxing the children of the indentured men after they have attained the artificial majority.
('2', 481, 1, 4, 1062656) The object of regulating by law the emigration of the population of India is, the Council understands, to foster foreign settlement and 40 protect such settlers.
('2', 481, 1, 5, 1062818) This object would be obviously frustrated if the labourers, after they had given, in the words of the Natal legislators, the best 5 years of their lives to the Colony, are compelled to return to India.
('2', 481, 1, 6, 1063020) And if it is a hardship on the men who have been brought up in India to return to India, how much more so must it be for those who went to the Colony as infants or were born there.
('2', 481, 1, 7, 1063201) The object of the Bill cannot be mistaken.
('2', 481, 1, 8, 1063244) The tax is to be levied not for the purposes of revenue.
('2', 481, 1, 9, 1063301) The intention is to make it sufficiently severe to oblige those coming within the scope of the intended legislation to return to India.
('2', 481, 1, 10, 1063437) Indeed, Europeans in Natal are endeavouring to secure such legislation as would make the indentures terminate in India.
('2', 481, 1, 11, 1063557) The Prime Minister of the Colony has, as it appears from recent cablegrams, stated that the stopping of Indian immigration would paralyse the industries of Natal.
('2', 481, 1, 12, 1063720) The Council asks respectfully, whether the people, who are so indispensable to the welfare of the Colony, and who have materially helped to make it what it is, are to be singled out for special taxation.
('2', 481, 1, 13, 1063924) The Council, moreover, begs to draw Your Lordship’s attention to the fact that these very indentured Indians, at a time when their service was imminently required, voluntarily came forward to help the military authorities as stretcher bearers.
('2', 481, 1, 14, 1064168) The work of the Natal Volunteer Indian Ambulance Corps is well known to Your Lordship.
('2', 481, 1, 15, 1064255) It has been favourably mentioned in Despatches.
('2', 481, 1, 16, 1064303) The Council ventures to think that such men deserve a better treatment than being subjected to an annual tax of the character above described The principle of the measure is so manifestly unjust that the Council does not consider it necessary to enter into an examination of its details.
('2', 481, 1, 17, 1064591) Ever since the Colony has obtained self government, the Indian
('2', 482, 0, 1, 1064654) VOL 2 : 13 JANUARY, 1897 11 JULY, 1902 483
('2', 482, 1, 2, 1064697) settlers there, whether free or indentured, have not had rest from “pin prick’, legislation of the character to which Your Lordship’s attention has been drawn by various public bodies, including the Association.
('2', 482, 1, 3, 1064909) If it is found difficult to restrain the self governing Colony from riding rough shod over imperial considerations and treating British subjects as aliens, the Council of the Association, in common with the East India Association, which has only recently approached Your Lordship, respectfully considers that it is time Your Lordship should adopt measures to suspend State regulated emigration from India to the Colony, the moreso now, seeing that it is these very people who are touched by the Bill in question.
('2', 482, 1, 4, 1065422) We remain, &c., PHEROZESHAH M. MEHTA President DINSHAW EDULJI WACHA AMEEROODIN TYABJI CHIMANLAL SETALVAD Honorary Secretaries
('2', 482, 2, 5, 1065548) Colonial Office Records: C.O. 179, Volume 225, India Office.
